Medium.AbsText: Despite the numerous scholarly interest and research on the American black civil rights movement, there is a lack of research and understanding on how they approached citizenship. This paper argues that competing black political projects made "symbolic citizenship" claims: how social movements create the normative ideas of good citizenship they claim to represent by fashioning styles of political rhetoric, civic practice, bodily posture and affective self-mastery. Based on archival research of primary source text (training manuals, organizing pamphlets, minutes to meetings, speeches/writings) and discursive and comparative methods, this paper uses the two dominant civil rights political projects, the rights and black nationalist projects, as empirical cases to distinguish a set of historically embedded categories of black political practice. On the one hand, the rights project appealed to the idea of good American citizenship and used discourses of good black citizenship as a deracializing strategy to associate blacks with idealized American citizenship. On the other hand, the black nationalist project rejected universalistic claims of good America citizenship and used discourses of black authenticity to produce an idea of an racially pure, or authentic black political agent, in opposition to ideas of whiteness and deracializing strategies. Rather than produce a set of ethical practices that attached the black self with American nationhood, the black nationalists shaped a set of ethical practices to secure control of and govern all black communities. Based on their different symbolic citizenship strategies and understandings of American citizenship, this dissertation analyzes how the competing projects produced an competing ideals of good black citizens and authentic black citizens, evidenced in how they differed in (1) directing their political practice at the national or local level for continued reform, (2) how each political project organized movement programs and 'measured' black citizenship, (3) the pedagogical techniques that instructed blacks how to master personal, social and civic ethics, and (4) how they approached economic reform and urban revitalization. The legacy of the political projects normative claims on contemporary representations of black citizenship have bifurcated black political practice that demands techniques of deracialized self to integrate on a national level, while local representations of authentic black citizenship are anchored to the margins. The contemporary implications represent how understandings of citizens continue to be an important, yet overlooked, aspect of how social movements and minority groups makes claims for civic inclusion.

ABSTRACT

Despite the numerous scholarly interest and research on the American black civil rights movement, there is a lack of research and understanding on how they approached citizenship. This paper argues that competing black political projects made "symbolic citizenship" claims: how social movements create the normative ideas of good citizenship they claim to represent by fashioning styles of political rhetoric, civic practice, bodily posture and affective self-mastery. Based on archival research of primary source text (training manuals, organizing pamphlets, minutes to meetings, speeches/writings) and discursive and comparative methods, this paper uses the two dominant civil rights political projects, the rights and black nationalist projects, as empirical cases to distinguish a set of historically embedded categories of black political practice. On the one hand, the rights project appealed to the idea of good American citizenship and used discourses of good black citizenship as a deracializing strategy to associate blacks with idealized American citizenship. On the other hand, the black nationalist project rejected universalistic claims of good America citizenship and used discourses of black authenticity to produce an idea of an racially pure, or authentic black political agent, in opposition to ideas of whiteness and deracializing strategies. Rather than produce a set of ethical practices that attached the black self with American nationhood, the black nationalists shaped a set of ethical practices to secure control of and govern all black communities. Based on their different symbolic citizenship strategies and understandings of American citizenship, this dissertation analyzes how the competing projects produced an competing ideals of good black citizens and authentic black citizens, evidenced in how they differed in 1) directing their political practice at the national or local level for continued reform, 2) how each political project organized movement programs and 'measured' black citizenship, 3) the pedagogical techniques that instructed blacks how to master personal, social and civic ethics, and 4) how they approached economic reform and urban revitalization. The legacy of the political projects normative claims on contemporary representations of black citizenship have bifurcated black political practice that demands techniques of deracialized self to integrate on a national level, while local representations of authentic black citizenship are anchored to the margins. The contemporary implications represent how understandings of citizens continue to be an important, yet overlooked, aspect of how social movements and minority groups makes claims for civic inclusion.

IV

CHAPTER 1: A CULTURAL SOCIOLOGICAL REVIEW AND CRITIQUE OF THE BLACK CIVIL RIGHTS LITERATURE

The 1965 Voting Rights Act, which provided black Americans with federal

protection from state techniques designed to restrict them from voting, was the

final political right won in over a decade political struggle that started in

Montgomery, Alabama in December 1954. Four years after the Voting Rights

Act, the civil right had limited influence in American political culture. Since the

decline of the civil rights movement, it sociologists have studied the movement in

order to understand how movements start, develop, decline, and form political

identities. This dissertation uses past civil rights scholarship as a point of

departure to consider how competing political project produced normative ideals

of political practice. It is an analysis of how cultural forms of resistance shape

the body politic. My use of the concept "political project" refers to the normative

ideas, discourses, narratives, practices, and forms of knowledge produced by

historically embedded political ideas of how political life should be, and how it

should operate. In contrast, I define "social movements" as a collection of

heterogeneous political agents temporarily bounded together by the political

projects normative ideas. A political project provides a social movement with a

language to produce the ideas they claim only to represent while making claims

for equality, rights, freedom etc. By distinguishing the social movement from the

larger political projects, I propose that social movements are not autonomous

from the larger political project, and that social movements are the historically

situated manifestation of political projects.

1

This dissertation argues that competing political projects in the civil rights movement, a rights political project and a black nationalist political project, used competing discourses to make 'symbolic citizenship' claims. By symbolic citizenship, I am referring to how social movements define and create the representations of those on the margins they claimed to represent, subsequently producing the historically situated normative political agents. The rights political project used discourses of good black citizenship as a deracializing strategy to associate blacks with an idealized American citizenship. This included training the body to master a set of ethical practices, which limited affective outburst and the use of violence, which produced an idea of a good black citizen. In contrast, the black nationalist political project used discourses of black authenticity to produce an idea of an racially pure, or real black citizens, in opposition to ideas of whiteness and deracializing strategies. Rather than produce a set of ethical practices that attached the black self with American nationhood, the black nationalist project created an idea of an authentic revolutionary black agent attached to the racial group. Thus, the differences in how each project approached citizenship reflect the differences in liberal understandings of citizenship that defines citizenship as the property of autonomous individuals, and multicultural understandings of citizenship that critiques universalizing ideals of citizenship in favor of defining citizenship as the property of social groups.

The rights political project had a history in black American political culture. On the one hand, modern black civic practice begins to take shape in new deal political culture. The idea behind the new deal was to expand the federal

2

government role in providing economic stability through social services aimed at the American poor and working class. Situated in the 'great depression', pro-new dealers were responsible for passing America's first social security and minimum wage acts. On the other hand, America was in the midst of a changing political culture, as the Americans and Russians were entering to the 'cold war', and former colonial powers declined. Changes in postwar democratic culture, in part, created openings to reconsider the question of who and what counts as American citizenship. Blacks felt that the privileges of American citizenship should no longer be based on race in light of domestic and global developments. The development of the rights project produced new forms of civic practice. 1940's black activists Bayard Rustin, A. Phillip Randolph and E. D. Nixon introduced strategies of boycott, marches and ideas of nonviolence to black protest a decade before Martin Luther King and the Southern Christian Leadership Conference (SCLC). More importantly, the idea of using nonviolent civic practices a shift in black political thought. Prior to the 1940s, debates between Booker T. Washington's vocational training W.E.B. Dubois's talented tenth, and to an extent Marcus Garvey's back to Africa Movement, guided black political struggle. The struggle for racial equally was generally sought through increased black economic standing. While not abandoning ideas of economic achievement, Rustin and Randolph introduced ideas of mastering affective responses and civic inclusion strategies. For example, in two essays published in 1942, titled "Nonviolence vs. Jim Crow" and "The Negro and Nonviolence", Bayard Rustin argued that nonviolence was a way for blacks to overcome the

3

fear of whites. Challenging legal approaches of the NAACP, he noted, "Those who argue for an extended educational plan are not wrong, but there must be a plan for facing immediate conflicts" (Rustin [1942] 1971:11). The Rustin text illustrated how the black movement began to consider black affective responses to whites, especially fear and anger, which jeopardized the effectiveness of black civic practice. A. Phillip Randolph's March on Washington Movement considered explicit cultural forms of non-violent practices to challenge Jim Crow laws and racial inequality. Randolph portrays blacks as non-violent and willing driven by ideas of civic reform and equality rather than revolution. Noting the movement must be all black, but not anti-white, he argues it will "It helps to break down the slave psychology and inferiority complex in Negroes which comes and is nourished with Negroes relying on white people for direction and support" ([1942] 2002: 57). Rustin and Randolph provided blacks with an alternative to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) rejection of direct action in favor of legal and juridical battles to for constitutional amendments to end segregation.

The black civil rights movement emerged as a national political force during the Montgomery bus boycott. Although not the first bus boycott protesting segregation, it did capture the American, and worlds, attention with their ideas of good citizenship and nonviolent civic practice. Under the leadership of Martin Luther King Jr., the civil rights movement used discourses of good black citizenship as a deracializing strategy that sought to associate blacks with idealized American citizenship. No longer concerned solely with issues of

4

economic equality, King in particular begins to ask the question of what counts as good American citizenship. Nonviolent civic practice would guide black civic practices through bus desegregation struggles in Montgomery and the sit-ins and freedom rides throughout the south. Additionally, it influenced how direct action operated in the Birmingham and Selma campaigns for civil and political rights, Chicago and the 'Poor Peoples Campaign' for expanding economic rights for blacks and poor whites. However, the idea of nonviolence was more than a framing strategy or a collective action repertoire on how to protest. Thus, nonviolent civic practice was one ethical practice used to make symbolic citizenship claims that blacks are good citizens deserving of rights. It associated blacks with an idealized American citizenship, and challenged the broader civic polity to consider the role of violence in preventing minority rights.

Despite dominating 1960s public discourse on racial equality, the black nationalist political project challenged the rights political project, producing its own normative ideal of black citizenship in relation to whiteness and deracializing strategies. In contrast to the rights political project, the black nationalist project produced a set of ethical practices that attached the black self to the racial group rather than the nation-state. This included adopting self-defense and revolutionary practices in favor of non-violence and civic reform practices. The normative ideal of the authentic black political agent is represented in the text of Malcolm X. Malcolm drew from ideals of Garveyism and violent African post-colonial struggles of independence, and assumptions about ethnic white communities and the 'American Dream'. During the Selma movement, the

5

Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (SNCC) began using discourses of black authenticity to reject deracializing and nonviolent practices, causing a split within the movement. Blacks associated with the black nationalist project rejected the idea of blacks as individual good citizens struggling for racial equality in favor of emphasizing the blacks, as a racial group, in a struggle for power. After the Selma movement and 1965 Voting Rights Act, the normative ideals produced by the rights political project and black nationalist political project competed for influence in subsequent black political struggles.

The point of this first chapter is to review the theoretical and empirical research on the black civil rights movement. It will provide a context for understanding the conceptual arguments and limitations associated with social movement theory and the civil rights movement. After discussing the movement literature, I present my argument on how a symbolic citizenship allows us to understand the movement in terms other than social structure, state and/or organizational reductionism. Following the cultural turn in social movement research, my argument is that the black movement established a set of competing ethical civic practices, organized around shaping bodily demeanors, which produced two normative ideals of a black political agent. CONSIDERATIONS OF THE BLACK CIVIL RIGHTS MOVEMENT LITERATURE

The civil rights movement has been a benchmark case in the study of social movements and social movement theory. Scholars across academic disciplines generally focus on three empirical research questions. These questions also reflect the major theoretical debates within the civil rights literature

6

over the role of organizations, economic and political structures, 'intermediate' social processes like framing, and the cultural turn in social movement theory.

The first research question is how the black civil rights movement organizes activities and mobilizes supporters? By focusing on the role of organizations, sociologists have explained the movement in terms of the presence and readiness of social movement organizations (SMOs). The question of organization been centered on three sub-debates. First, were black organizations necessary to produce large scale social change? The debate is centered on how organizations centralized, controlled and produced the necessary resources (money, leadership, expertise, office space) for a movement to succeed. The analytical focus on black organizations has been used to analyze the extent of northern white liberal influence/control.

The second organizational debate is how organizations 'professionalize' black political actions. Professionalizing black politics is conceptualized as how much and where the organizations obtained resources. For instance, analyzing where SMO'a obtain external funding and support came is used to explain how some organizations had access to political channels and elites without using direct action. Specifically, SCLC and the NAACP are credited with professionalizing black protest, which gave them access to the dominant American political culture and public sphere. Although SNCC was considered more 'radical' than SCLC, SNCC's style of creating leaders from below also professionalized black protest. Mississippi's blacks involved with SNCC were

7

more likely to secure federal funds for community development than black communities not involved with the movement (Andrews 2001).

The third sub-organizational debate is the extent of SCLC's bureaucratic structuring versus SNCC's grassroots structuring can provide a causal model for the effectiveness of movement strategy and outcomes. By bureaucratic, I am referring to how SCLC represented an SMO/advocacy group model that solicited money from members who are not directly involved in the movement. In contrast, SNCC represented a voluntary organization whose 'success' depended on the quality and quantity of its members labor and commitment. This debate highlights the relationship between organizations and ideology. That is, does organizational ideology determine decision-making or does the local culture determine the organizational form and ideology. In addition to ideology, different structures are said to create different types of leadership. SCLC and SNCC differed both on the role of leaders and how they recruited them. SCLC drew heavily from the minister ranks of the black church. SNCC drew from black students who sought to create leaders from the general black public.

The second research question is how the black movement takes the specific form it does under King's leadership. The conceptual focus is how King links the black struggle to the broader American civic culture. Specifically, researchers analyze King's rhetorical skills, how he situates black claims in democratic and Christian 'frames', and his role in forming a black collective identity. The analysis of King's rhetorical skills focuses on the delivery style of his speeches and the use of narrative. His use of religious narratives tied the

8

civil rights movement with an idea that black struggle was part of a natural and divine inspired social progress. Structural approaches primarily look at the role of class and race in forming movement strategy. By distinguishing 'radical' from moderate 'factions' of the movement, scholars explained how whites supported moderate groups like SCLC at the expense of more radical ones like SNCC. White support made the moderate groups more influential in the broader public sphere. The framing perspective looks at how blacks framed their ideology and strategy in terms of democracy and Christianity, which resonated with broader American public values. Collective identity refers to how individuals share a real or imagined status, as expressed through symbols, ideals and rituals. Movements develop collective identities to distinguish the movement from an adverse other.

The final question is why and how the movement succeeded and declined when it did. The idea behind the black movements' decline is that the movement was unfinished and forced to prematurely decline due to the same structural changes that made it possible. Specific reasons vary. The most prominent explanation is the federal government's level of receptivity and support offered to blacks declined. King's anti-Vietnam war stance encouraged the Johnson administration to ignore the black community. Black organizational infighting between the 'big six' made for ineffective and divergent political strategy. A third reason was the movement switches its attention to the northern ghettos and slums rather than southern rural population. The north, it is argued, was governed by a more complex and subtle form of racial politics the movement was

9

not ready for. Cultural approaches note the decline of the movement coincides with the disintegration of the movement's unified collective identity. Once new black power identities begin to emerge, different forms of political strategy and action develop. Next I will trace the filiations of black civil rights scholarship, illustrating how the above debates are situated in divergent theoretical traditions. POLITICAL PROCESS THEORY AND THE BLACK MOVEMENT

I group three analytically distinct sociological approaches to studying the civil rights movement under the single heading of political process theory. The three approaches are resource mobilization, political opportunity structure and frame alignment. I group them together based on their common emphasis of the structural processes that provide the causal explanatory framework for why the black civil rights movement developed and was successful. While each theoretical aspect is analytically distinct, they represent a continuation of a single tradition and provide a consensus or 'strong program' for social movement scholarship. Mobilization

The resource mobilization perspective takes shape as scholars were trying to account for the social power of money and economic relations. This included how social movements solicited money from various publics, and how movements used the money for training activists, office space and publishing movement literature. The emergence of resource mobilization should be read in relation to social psychological approaches which explained social movements in terms of an 'irrational social actor' reacting to a temporary disturbance in the

10

social system (see McAdam 1999: 5-35 and Jasper 1997: 23-33). By focusing on the role of money and resources, early mobilization theorists hoped to further the argument that social movements were 'normal' and 'rational' avenues for political discontent.

The importance of resources in the black movement was tied into the question of organizations. McCarthy and Zald (1977) theorized that the 1960s and 1970s introduced a new type of professional Social Movement Organization (SMO). Old SMOs were voluntary organizations. They tended to be grassroots and relied on local memberships. New SMOs were professional, in that they consisted of a paid staff, outside leaders, and passive constituent participation. Resource mobilization scholars argued that the movement was only possible because of an influx of skills and money into the black community. Resources provided resource mobilization theorists with structural indicators they deemed necessary for blacks to politically mobilize. Federal policies created resources that provided economic opportunities for blacks. Although McCarthy and Zald did not apply their SMO model to any specific social group, they did note that the welfare state provided society with steady employment and access to higher education. Anthony Oberschall (1973) argued that the most important move by the American state was the Fair Employment Practice Commission (FEPC). FEPC created a new black 'middleclass' by opening federal jobs to blacks. This new black middle class, when coupled with financial support from the north, provided the financial base for forming and supporting movement organizations.

11

Thus the importance of organizations and resources in the black movement were a way of taking into account economic indicators.

Not all sociologists agreed the role of organizations were necessary or even beneficial for blacks. Arguably the most influential and controversial work over the role of organizations in social movements is Francis Scott Piven and Richard Cloward's (1977) Poor Peoples Movement. They theorized that organizations alone did not provide blacks with the means of staging a feasible social movement, and challenged the assumption that blacks benefited from developing large-scale political organizations. They noted that the black movements' biggest gains came early on in the movement, prior to forming SCLC and SNCC. In effect, the movement suffers from what Robert Michels identified as the 'iron law of oligarchy' - how leftist organizations become more conservative the larger and more bureaucratic the organization gets. Rather than organizations and resources, Piven and Cloward argue the black movement benefited from large-scale economic and political structural transformations that 'modernized' the south. Specifically, they pointed to the decline of the southern cotton industry and rise of more industrial manufacturing. Their theory on political and economic modernization provided the causal model for subsequent black strategy and behavior. This included how black migration to the north made blacks politically useful to democrats looking to offset defections of southern Democrats to the Republican Party. Echoing these claims, Jack Bloom (1987) elaborates their approach by arguing that political and economic modernization changes the southern class structure, which subsequently

12

produced changes in race relations. The most significant change is the creation of a new white middle class that displaced the old southern white agrarian elites. Bloom argued that this new white middle class was more open to providing rights to blacks so as not to interfere with the South's industrialization. Political Opportunity Structures

The theories on the opening and closing of political opportunities intertwined with changes in the state and the economy developed from the limitations of resource mobilization theory and the debate over organizations. Conceding that resource mobilization places too much emphasis on a movement's dependency for elites' money/funding to explain how movements develop, political opportunity structure theorists developed a conceptual model that incorporated economic structures, political structures, organizations, and frame alignment. Economic structures are unemployment rates and patterns of urban migration, which explained the decline of a southern agricultural economy and rise of southern industrialization. Political structures are the state and changing relationships between political elites, which would foster a political opening for blacks as a voting block. Organizations are deemed necessary for movements to centralize their resources, ideology, and readiness for political action. Frame alignment explains how the movement situated their inequality claims in democratic and Christian frames that resonate with the broader American civic culture in order to gain white support.

Black organizations become a primary explanatory variable with Aldon Morris's (1984) research on the role of the black church in the civil rights

13

movement. His research is the first to downplay the extent of northern white elite

influence in favor of emphasizing blacks' role in their struggle for civil rights. His

theoretical criticized Piven and Cloward's claims that black organizations were

more of a detriment than an asset for blacks. He noted that "implicit in the work

of a number of civil rights movement scholars, including Piven and Cloward and

Anthony Obershall, is the assumption that subordinate groups are usually without

organizational resources and skills" (Morris 1984: 76). Morris argued that the

reason for black's success was their ability to organize their "indigenous base"

independently of whites,

it is within this indigenous base that the basic funding patterns, social resources, and organized masses are concentrated and activated for protest... internal organization was the critical factor that enabled the movement to gather momentum and endure in the face of state power and widespread repression (Morris 1984: xii).

Morris is critical of two prior claims made on the movement. The first is that

northern white liberals directed and controlled the movement. This claim is

based on the idea that northern whites were providing all the resources,

especially money, to fund black protest efforts. Second, Morris argued that

downplaying the role of the black church resulted from a poor understanding of

the church's role in producing black leaders and church's political influence over

the black community. Morris's study empirically challenges both claims by

showing that money and resources overwhelmingly came from the black

community, noting that "much of the 'outside' money was raised by black

churches, [black] organizations, and [black] individuals in the North" (1984: 57).

Since black ministers did not work for whites, black churches provided space to

14

develop leadership skills and a safe outlet to criticize white racism. Without the functions of the black church, Morris argued the movement would not have started or been able to sustain itself.

Furthermore, Morris argued that black organizations were important because they were primarily responsible for providing the movement's leadership and ideology. This made SCLC especially important because it was intertwined with the broader infrastructure of the black church. Morris argues SCLC "functioned as the decentralized arm of the mass-based church movement" (Morris 1984: xiii). For him, the black church provided the leadership, funding and 'institutionalized charisma' for the movement. The SCLC merely "supplied the political dimension that pulled churches directly into the movement and made it a dynamic force" (Morris 1984: 78). Leaders, then, enjoyed the association with charisma due to their positioning in the black church. This helped the movement gain political influence with blacks, in part, because the ministers had a ready-made and willing audience. Since black ministers were firmly situated at the top, SCLC could operate as umbrella organization made up of many smaller affiliates, with its president King at the top of it all. For Morris, then, situated and reduced the question of leaders, ideology and organization to the importance of black organizations.

Echoing Morris's claims on the importance of black organizations, McAdam argued that Piven and Cloward "base their pessimistic conclusion on a view that equates the development of movement organization with certain processes destructive of insurgency. The problem with their conclusion is in the

15

inevitably they ascribe to these processes" (McAdam 1999: 54). Unlike Morris, McAdam claimed a synthesis of economic and political structures, organizations and a social psychological approach of 'cognitive changes' to explain the various aspects of the civil rights movement. McAdam attempted to find common ground to account for both black efforts and structural changes. For instance, he argued the decline of cotton based southern economy, when coupled with fewer European immigrants, spurred northern migration based on the dependency of black labor to undermine unions. This change in economic standing created a black North-South alliance that decreased southern oppression. This, in turn, provided money and time needed for the development of black organizations and the consolidation of black political power in parts of the North e.g. Harlem, Chicago.

Once a civil rights organization is in place, McAdam argued that the organizations importance is not just the leaders, but also the characteristics of the organization and its degree of 'organizational readiness.' That is, blacks were sufficiently organized and prepared to take advantage of political opportunities. By 1955, blacks enjoyed 'active' black churches and black colleges. The NAACP served as an avenue to express discontent. He argues that "by building the movement out of established institutions, insurgent leaders were able to recruit en masse along existing lines of interaction, thereby sparing themselves the much more difficult task of developing a membership from scratch" (McAdam 1999: 129). Once the organizations were established, blacks were able to take advantage of 1960s political opportunities. For instance,

16

blacks were perceived by democrats as a coveted voting block to offset post-war republican gains in the house under the Roosevelt administration, and cold war politics put a spotlight on the contradictions of racism and democracy. Subsequently, the closing of political opportunities after 1965 and the disintegration of interorganizational cooperation lead to the decline in the movement. Specifically, McAdam argued, "at root of the disintegration was a growing disagreement within insurgent ranks over the proper goals of the movement and the most effective means of attaining them" (McAdam 1999: 183).

Political process theory incorporated a cultural level to explain the 'subjective' aspects of the movement. McAdam originally considered the 'subjective' meaning of collective action with the idea of cognitive liberation - or how the movement understands itself as a movement. He argued, "before collective protest can get underway, people must collectively define their situation as unjust and subject to change through group action" (McAdam 1999: 51). However, McAdam (1996) abandoned cognitive liberation in favor of framing theories, in an attempt to account for culture and agency within the political process tradition.

The framing perspective developed around the idea that cognitive schemes are created to influence how activists and the larger pubic make sense of a social movement's collective action (Snow et al 1986, Snow & Benford 1988, 1992, Benford & Hunt 1992, Benford 1993, Benford & Snow 2000, Gamson 1988, 1992). Framing theorists argue that social movements use frames to provide a 'diagnosis' of the problem, a 'prognosis' or solution to the problem, and

17

a 'rationale' for how to solve it. This helps, among other things, to distinguish a sense of "us against them" (McAdam, McCarthy and Zald 1996) and how collective action events take on different meanings as they are incorporated into existing frames (Ellingston 1995). The framing literature approached the civil rights movement as operating under a single "master frame". Snow and Benford (1992) defined a master frame as a foundational frame based on a common norm of society, which dictated movement goals, tactical innovation, and created successes and failures. They argud civil rights protesters, as well as other social movements of the 1960s, use 'rights' as the master frame. Regarding the civil rights movement, Snow and Benford argue "its master frame, as initially espoused by Martin Luther King Jr. and his associates, accented the principle of equal rights and opportunities regardless of ascribed characteristics and articulated it with the goal of integration through non-violent means" (1992: 145).

The framing process is incorporated into the study of structural changes to account for how movements create 'meaningful accounts' of their strategy and protest. McAdam argued that the potential for successful social change in the black movement depended on how it framed its actions. Opposed to the idea of a single democratic 'master frame' because of its emphasis on ideology at the expense of tactics, he argued that how King framed his speeches in Christian and democratic frames grounded "the movement in two ideational bedrocks of American culture" (McAdam 1996: 347). Christian and democratic frames explain King's assent to the dominant movement leader. McAdam says "Quite simply, no black leader had ever sounded like King before. In his unique

18

blending of familiar Christian themes, conventional democratic theory, and the philosophy of non-violence, King brought an unusually compelling, yet accessible, frame to the struggle" (1996: 347). Thus, King's use of democratic and Christian frame as ideology and tactics provided a way for blacks to be included into the mainstream public sphere and take advantage of political opportunities.

McAdam (1999) argued that the movement's decline resulted from the same structural processes that created its success - organizational readiness, a change in state/political structure, black's prospects for future success, and the response from external white groups. Up until Selma, the civil rights organizations were centralized under the leadership of King and the SCLC. However, the centralized leadership and interorganizational cooperation disintegrated over differences in goals, wasted resources, and fighting and arguing amongst one another. With voting rights legislation secured, the movement lacked any uniform goals to direct common political action. The federal response to the movement also changed. McAdam noted that white ethnics began leaving the Democratic Party for the Republican Party, who campaigned against race issues. On the strength of the 'white backlash' Nixon was elected in 1968, which caused Democrats began to 'devalue' the black vote. Changes in state support make blacks pessimistic and less willing to be engaged. Coupled with the race riots of the mid-60s, and white liberals withholding funding and support from SNCC and CORE, the movement found itself with few resources in the form of allies, money and volunteers. Besides

19

changes in the state, McAdam (1996) argued the movement found it harder to frame their message of nonviolence in the north than in the south, which made the movement's mains strategy mute. SNCC, Black Power, and Political Process Theory

Early sociological research on the black civil rights movement centered on the importance and contributions of the black church, King and SCLC on the movement. Other scholars working within the political process tradition extended their studies to SNCC in order to solidify and refine its basic theoretical prose. Rhoda Blumberg (1984) draws on political process theory to argue that 'environmental factors' like urbanization, economic and political changes shape whites 'moods' and black strategy. Specifically for blacks, she argues "It is no wonder then that black strategists have disagreed among themselves, as they continually reassessed the limits of what was possible" (Blumberg 1984: 3). To illustrate, she rejected the idea that the black church was as influential as Morris claimed. She argued that the same conditions that made segregation possible also necessitated the placing of black ministers into the dominant leadership position. King is the beneficiary of non-church based Montgomery activists like Rosa Parks and E.D. Nixon and CORE'S early protests. The main contribution of King's nonviolence was to "awaken a sense of moral shame in the opponent so that in the end there would be redemption and reconciliation" (Blumberg 1984: 46).

After Montgomery, SCLC and King increasingly relied on the other actors to 'recharge' or reshape the struggle. She described SNCC as a counter-

20

movement that "develops its own ideology and rationale, reconceptualizing the impending change as negative and destructive of long-cherished values" (1984: 56). The ideological shift in more militant tactics created political opportunities for the movement. Specifically, it showed that the federal government was more willing to support voter education drives and act on behalf of blacks when faced with violent local municipalities.

In addition to the changing political structures that McAdam notes, Blumberg argued that King's declining popularity hurt the movement and the potential for further political opportunities. She isolated America's involvement in Vietnam and King's anti-war stances, the rise of black power and the urban riots as reducing King's political influence and popularity among whites. These factors represented "the interaction of internal factors with the movement's external environment was crucial in determining its demise" (Blumberg 1984: 164). Along with the disintegration of the civil rights organizations, the internal-external relationship changes black strategy. King's anti-war stance angered Lyndon Johnson, and alienated the movement from the Democratic Party's base. The rise of black power groups distanced the movement from its reform strategy to more nationalistic ones. Urban riots allowed whites to focus on 'law and order' issues in place of anti-poverty ones. Instead of social movements and direct action, 'mainstream' blacks chose to work through electoral politics, thus depriving the movement of its best leaders and strategists.

Herbert Haines (1984, 1988) also argued that other social process were responsible for the form the movement takes under King's leadership. For

21

Haines, the success of the civil rights movement was due, in part, to the rise of black power and black militancy - the 'radical flanks'. His contribution to the literature is to consider how the movement was shaped with struggles and interactions between different factions of the movement. Theoretically, he attempted to move the analysis away from the functions of black organizations, resources and political structures to a conceptual focus of personal motivations, psychological states of activists, and interorganizational processes that created black heterogeneity in the civil rights movement. This involved studying groups other than SCLC and SNCC and focus on 'radical movement ideology' of black power. Haines argued that black militants created 'turmoil', which "was indispensable to black progress because it enhanced the mainstream bargaining position" (1988: 2). SCLC was successful, in part, because they appeared less threatening to whites. Haines showed that the influence of black power in SNCC led to a disproportionate amount of governmental grants and money from private organizations to SCLC and NAACP. In contrast, unions, black churches and individuals generally gave money to all. In addition to changing what groups received money, Haines argued that black militants change the movement's tactics and goals. He claimed the rise of violence and declining relationship between the movement, the federal government and white coalitions were the result of a 'crisis of faith': "The crisis was related to both the effectiveness of nonviolent protest as the primary means for bringing about change and the nature of the changes required" (Haines 1988: 46). Therefore, CORE and SNCC's

22

adoption of black power indicate psychological changes in the mood of blacks, ultimately leading to the movement's split and decline.

Subsequent political process research on black organizations sought to show how black organizations 'professionalized' black political claims. Jenkins and Eckert (1986) assess the impact of professionalizing black organizations on the movement outcomes. They find support in political process claims in that SMOs provided a secondary role to both social structure and the grassroots organizations like the black church. Therefore, there was little or no elite white control over the black movement. In contrast to Piven and Cloward, they viewed black SMOs like SCLC and NAACP as channeling black demands, goals and tactics into more specified targets. The long term impact of professionalizing the movement is seen in post-Selma efforts at lobbying and forming voting blocs with other leftist social groups.

Kenneth Andrews (1997, 2001, and 2004) refined the organizational focus of political process theory by considering how black organizations impact movement outcomes, and whether or not the degree of professionalizing an SMO impacted movement outcomes. In contrast to political process theorists like McAdam, he emphasizes the stability of the black organization and downplays the idea of interorganizational cooperation. Rather than focus on organizational structure, he suggested analyzing the 'movement infrastructure' (defined as organizations, resources and leadership) impact on political process. He claimed SNCC's strong local movement infrastructure in Mississippi during the civil rights movement helped shape future federal antipoverty programs and

23

policy in Mississippi after the 1965 voting rights act. Mississippi was considered SNCC's 'territory' because of their extensive efforts culminating in the Mississippi Freedom Democratic Party (MFDP). Even though Mississippi was associated with the more radical factions of the movement, the infrastructure put in place by SNCC allowed blacks to continue to lobby and get access to resources made available by the "War on Poverty" programs. By showing that the organizational antithesis to SCLC had the same impact on securing federal funds and influencing state policy, Andrews illustrated that similar movement infrastructures makes SNCC an important SMO actor and not just a grassroots organization limited by divergent ideology.

CULTURAL TURN IN SOCIAL MOVEMENT THEORY AND THE BLACK CIVIL RIGHTS MOVEMENT

The cultural turn in social movement theory shifted the conceptual focus away from political opportunities to questions to how social movements struggle to change the dominant cultural meanings, or 'cultural codes', which form social hierarchies based on (Melucci 1996). The idea behind the cultural turn is 1) social movements attempt to change the cultural norms, values and beliefs assigned to practices that serve as exclusionary markers and 2) to account for how, and why, individuals struggle for the rights of members of groups they do not belong to (i.e. homeless advocacy) or organize around issues (environment, AIDS/HIV).

The cultural turn challenges two key assumptions of political process theory. The first assumption is whether we can judge and analyze social

24

movements solely in terms of instrumental rationality and securing, or failing to secure, new rights. Based on the concept of collective identity, which explains how movements organize, why people join and why they choose certain tactics over others, the cultural tradition attempts to get away from emphasizing instrumental successes (e.g. question like who wins?) to consider other ways that social movements are meaningful. The second challenge is to the explanatory power of frame alignment and organizations. Rather, cultural approaches argue that organizations and strategies result from the movements' political culture, indicated by their collective identity, which is irreducible to organizational form or movement infrastructure. In contrast to the idea that movements frame their grievances, the cultural turn analyzes the narratives -how the movement tells stories involved in establishing a collective identity - to explain the movement's identity and form.

Ron Eyerman and Andrew Jamison's (1991, 1998) work on the civil rights movement illustrates the collective identity approach. Eyerman and Jamison considered how social movements are involved in knowledge producing activities, which makes movements part of the collective learning process. Social movements contribute new types of social knowledge, what they define as 'cognitive praxis' - knowledge formation through social action. Concerning identity, they argue for an approach that, "focuses upon the process of articulating a movement identity (cognitive praxis), on the actors taking part in this process (movement intellectuals), and on the contexts of articulation (political cultures and institutions)" (1991: 4). They argued that the civil rights movement's

25

cognitive praxis is found in the cosmological, technical, and organizational levels, as well as the rediscovery of black history. The cosmological level is the use of Christian beliefs of 'redemption' and 'reconciliation', as well as the use of democracy to affirm "American ideals of equality and democracy, claiming their rights to be included in the mainstream of American life" (Eyerman and Jamison 1991: 122). The technical level is the learned protest techniques of nonviolence. The technical dimension created the nonviolent aspects of the movement's identity: "the specific objects of opposition and, even more importantly, the tactics, the techniques of protest, by which those objects were opposed" (Eyerman and Jamison 1991: 123). The organizational dimension was the development of mass action. They argued that blacks began to adopt their identity and see themselves as a real and imagined 'we' through boycotts, mass church meetings, sit-ins and music.1 Together, these dimensions constituted the civil rights movement's unified collective identity.

Civil rights "movement intellectuals" created and held together the movements' cognitive praxis by articulating the movements' demands to the broader American public. According to Eyerman and Jamison, movement intellectuals "create their individual role at the same time as they create the movement, as new individual identities and a new collective identity take the form in the same interactive process" (Eyerman and Jamison 1991: 98). Social movements allow for the articulating existing identities and for making new identities. Therefore, the importance of movement intellectuals is in how they

1 Also see Eyerman and Jamison 1998 for detailed analysis of the role of music and song in the movement

26

defined new collective identities to mobilize around. Rather than just King,

Eyerman and Jamison noted there were many movement intellectuals involved in

SCLC, NAACP, SNCC and CORE. What unified all four groups was the single

cognitive praxis that established the movements' collective identity. Furthermore,

movement intellectuals defined the movements' collective identity in relation to

an 'other'. The other is a real social actor like the government or state.

Ultimately, Eyerman and Jamison argued, it is the cognitive dimension that

makes the movement unique and successful: "the civil rights movement reflected

the shifting focus of consciousness from the material to the cultural as the driving

force in the cognitive praxis of social movements" (1991: 145). Hence, a social

movement's collective identity is as conscious acknowledgement and articulation

of a mindset that created new social knowledge in the form of new identities.

In contrast to isolating problems in organizations, ideology and strategy,

the cultural turn in social movements has rethought why the civil rights movement

declined. Similar to McAdam, Eyerman and Jamison explained the decline of the

movement in terms of what made the movement successful. Rather than credit

the alignment or misalignment of political opportunities, Eyerman and Jamison

pointed to the fracturing of the movement's unitary identity by rival movement

intellectuals,

The later 1960s witnessed the specialization of the dimensions by professional 'leaders', the emergence of extremist positions in the name of black power and black separatism, and the gradual dissolution of the movement's cognitive praxis into fragmented, partial practices of separate organizations (Eyerman and Jamison 1991: 124-125).

27

In addition to rival movement intellectuals, the polarization of American political beliefs expedited the dissolution of the civil rights movement. The polarization, they argued, made it impossible for the civil rights movement to occupy a middle ground. King was assassinated. Stokely Carmichael's affiliation with SNCC became troublesome because he championed 'black armed defense'. Whites and the FBI deemed black power organizations as extremists and a threat to public safety. Hence, the fragmenting the movement's collective identity causes the movement to split then end.

Eyerman (2001) supplemented the cognitive function of the civil rights movements' knowledge producing activities with an analysis of how the movement differed on how they should remember slavery. This part of identity formation is the cognitive process of rediscovering black culture and history. Eyerman argued that the memory of slavery is always important for black collective identity. For blacks, slavery serves as a common origin in a common past that every black generation struggles with in their political struggles. How the civil rights movement remembered slavery was important because "socially constructed, historically rooted collective memory functions to create social solidarity in the present" (Eyerman 2001: 6). Eyerman argued that 'Africa' served as the material object that created memories of slavery for civil rights activist. Consistent with his cognitive approach, he focused on the stories, or narratives told by movement intellectuals, which created a collective identity from past historical accounts: "Within the narrative provided by this collective memory individual identities are shaped as experiential frameworks formed out of, as they

28

are embedded within, narratives of past, present and future" (Eyerman 2001: 6). For Eyerman, the radical wings of the movement 'reframed' tragic and redemptive narratives in relation to post-colonial Africa to create the black power identity. For instance, Stokely Carmichael used the African struggles to speak of the civil rights movement in terms 'white nationalism' and 'black liberation'. In contrast, King and the mainstream movement used progressive narratives to explain Africa as new symbol for freedom, which symbolized how America could also change.

Francesca Polletta (1998) also argued for the merits of narrative, in place of framing, to understand how the civil rights movement formed collective identities. Framing was developed to account for how movement's actions depend on and influence political structures. She rejected frame analysis for lacking a conceptualization of ideology, for having no interpretive role, no explanation on how frames are created or their staying power, and for conflating material and discursive resources (Polletta 1998, also see Steinberg 1998). Concerning the civil rights movement, Polletta argued that the framing argument does not offer an account of the "discursive processes that precede movement formation of movement organizations... [and] the interpretive processes occurring in oppositional subcultures and indigenous institutions, and occurring during initial episodes of collective action" (1998: 138). Therefore, stating that the civil rights movement took form because of how it framed the struggle tells us very little on how blacks became receptive to the ideas of nonviolence and reconciliation with whites.

29

Polletta switched the conceptual analysis from the mainstream movement

actors and framing to the students of SNCC and narratives in order to

understand SNCC's contribution to the civil rights movements' collective identity.

If framing theories were correct, then why would the students of SNCC 'frame'

their actions in terms of spontaneity when it would make them appear

unorganized and irrational? Rather, she argued that we have to understand

SNCC as using a narrative of spontaneity because,

Spontaneity denoted independence from adult leadership, urgency, local initiative, and action by moral imperative rather than bureaucratic planning. Narratives of the sit-ins, told by many tellers, in more and less public settings, and in which spontaneity was a central theme, described student activists and potential activists to themselves and , in the process, helped to create the collective identity on behalf of which students took high risk action (Polletta 1998: 138).

The sit-ins created a new identity that distinguished the students from SCLC and

King. By 1960, King and SCLC were still basking in the glory of the success at

Montgomery, but were having difficulty mobilizing other southern black

communities. For this reason, the sit-in narrative allowed the students to become

part of, reenergize, and make a unique contribution to the movement.

Polletta extended the cultural turn to the question of organizations rethink

the questions of organizations. Focusing again on SNCC, she rejected the idea

that SNCC declined because of a lack of bureaucratic structure. Polletta (2002,

2005) argued that organizational structure and debates on when and how the

organization formed is a mute point. She argued how SNCCs organizational

form was the outcome of the 'symbolic resonance' with identity rather than

efficiency (or lack of) in a style of organization (Polletta 2002: 88-119). She

30

argued that friendships and tutelage were not enough to sustain the commitment to participatory styles of organizing in light the rise in black militancy, and the lack of ideas concerning effective programs and strategies. Thus, it would be wrong to say Black Power arouse in SNCC because of specific leaders or organizational form. Participatory democracy became an identity, and once that identity was associated with being 'white', blacks began to argue for a more strict bureaucratic structure. Polletta rightly critiqued organizational scholars for eliminating culture and identity from there explanatory models. Once we consider the movement's political culture, the importance and centrality of organizations weakens. In a sense, the debate over the importance of organizations initiated by Piven and Cloward has come full circle. We have gone from models that question the relationship between organizations and movement outcomes, to models that overemphasized the importance of organizations structure, leaders and resources, to how political cultures informs organizing strategies.

Polletta questioned the idea that the movement declined because of the fragmentations of organizations, ideology or collective identity. She argued that the 'real' problem was "generating the sense of radical purpose that would reenergize organizers and appeal to residents" (2002: 102). This frustration became racially coded, for instance, in debates over the amount of whites involved and their roles as leaders. SNCC's frustration extended to rejecting participatory styles of democracy as white, and consequently, their adoption of a black power identity, "Participatory democracy came to be seen as white, and, in

31

contrast, a centralized and top-down organizational structure came to symbolize not only programmatic certainty but also black orientation" (Polletta 2002: 90). However, the development of a black nationalist identity does not solve the problems of what to do, nor did it energize subsequent SNCC strategies. SYMBOLIC CITIZENSHIP, THE BODY AND THE CIVIL RIGHTS MOVEMENT

Following the cultural sociology critiques of the existing civil rights literature, I will argue for the importance of "symbolic citizenship" for social movement research. By symbolic citizenship, I refer to the analysis of how social movements make discursive claims that they are good citizens worthy of citizenship rights. Past research on citizenship and social movements considered how citizenship rights resulted from transformations in state structure (Tilly 1995), the importance of active participation (Licterman 1996) and how new social movements primarily struggle for the rights of others (Jasper 1997, Waters 1998). In research on the black movement, citizenship has been read solely as a instrumental gain fixated on the civil rights act of 1964 and the voting rights act of 1965 (Garrow 1978, 1986). Symbolic citizenship contributes to the existing citizenship and social movement literature because it highlights the discursive aspect of citizenship, and how movements produce a set of ethical practices to represents the movement with ideas of good citizenship.

Social groups struggling for civic inclusion "appeal" to an image of idealized national citizenship when making claims for citizenship rights. Idealized citizenship refers to how a nation prefers to see itself in relation to idealized cultural values and beliefs. For instance, American social movements appeal to

32

ideals of democratic citizenship and to beliefs of individual equality and nonviolence. Ideally, this means emphasizing a citizen's character and civic practice over their race, ethnicity, gender, ableness or sexuality. More importantly, symbolic citizenship refers to how social movements create the images and ideas of citizenship they claim only to represent. They appeal to idealized national citizenship in order to produce personal, social, and civic ethical practices. For the black civil rights movement, personal ethics defined the relationship blacks had with the self. It included managing bodily postures of how one spoke, walked, and presented the body in public. Social ethics defined the relationship blacks had with others, specifically, how to engage in relations with whites and other blacks. Civic ethics defined a manner and style of conduct for blacks while engaging in political practice and making claims for rights. Thus, for blacks in the civil rights movement, mastering ethical bodily practices was a strategy to project a racially non-threatening presentation of self and discredit black stereotypes.

Social movements guide their constituents to limit ethical practices indicating bad citizenship. Movements attempt to supply guidance through various methods. They use stories and narratives promising something better when speaking to members at meetings/rallies. They create representations of idealized citizens in the media to provide visual images of good civic practices in public protest. Lastly, they design pedagogical practices to train the body how to be a good citizen. This manipulating and shaping of the body teaches participants to manage their emotions in hostile situations and under difficult

33

circumstances. Social movements shape bodily postures and gestures, so that the body appears as their representation of good citizenship. Movements instruct activists to master techniques of self. The civil rights movement used the rights political project and discourses of good black citizenship to instruct blacks on deracialized techniques of self by teaching ethical practices designed to constantly monitor and inspect of the black self to ensure that they are, for instance, non-violent, even-tempered, modest and racially non-threatening when interaction with whites.

Appeals to idealized citizenship involve minimizing associations not reflecting idealized citizenship. For example, the civil rights movement made symbolic citizenship claims by associating non-violent civic practice with black citizenship. Non-violence defines, but also limits, the choice of civic practices to boycotts, marches and various forms of sit-ins. The black movement avoided violent demeanors and dispositions, in the form of initiating violence or retaliation (i.e. rioting). Movement actors were encouraged to appear non-threatening when engaging in civic practice. Thus, the rights based project used deracializing techniques of self to produce black interpretations and understandings of the black situation as being unjust, and which strategies were reasonable to stop those injustices. However, symbolic citizenship claims are exclusive to movements seeking social integration. In contrast to civic movements, nationalist and liberation movements attempt to associate meanings that reject or are the opposite of the "dominant culture". Nationalist movements often seek symbolic and sometimes real separation from the broader civic community. The

34

difference for nationalistic movements is the severity and conviction liberationists groups expect of their followers and the different cultural associations they try to attach to conduct and mannerism of their followers.

The civil rights movement used discourses of good citizenship makes normative claims about the type of citizen deserving rights. Movements appeal to idealized citizenship to minimize associations not reflecting idealized citizenship. Symbolic citizenship claims distinguish "good citizens" from "bad citizens". Good citizens reflect the idealized standards of national citizenship. Bad citizens are associated with the negative meanings of idealized citizenship. Good citizens and bad citizens are defined by the degree that they reflect idealized citizenship. Indeed, Steven Seidman (2002) argued that the idea of the "good gay" arose in the contemporary gay and lesbian struggles for civic inclusion. Good gays reflect gender conventional conduct and mannerisms that is sexually non-threatening to straight men. Since the idea of the good gay represents such a narrow slice of gay life, most gays are forced to conform and live up to an ideal they can and/or may not want to. For our purposes here, the civil rights movement distinguished an idea of the good black citizen by emphasizing the good black/bad white binary to illustrate how race should not serve as a marker for good citizenship.

Symbolic citizenship differs from other cultural sociological examinations of citizenship. For example, Alexander (1992, 1997, 1998) offers a structural approach to understanding citizenship as a way to measure civic solidarity and integration. He argued the discourse of citizenship (or civil society) reproduces

35

itself through cultural codes. The cultural code is a binary dividing 'meaning' into sacred/profane, pure/impure, good/bad etc. Thus, he theorized that we find civic meaning in cultural codes rather than in elites or institutions, which stabilized the system of civil society, allowing for civil society's distinction and autonomy from the state. Citizens rely on the code to interpret and make sense of others actions, behaviors and motives in order to legitimate 'friends' and delegitimate 'enemies'. Although analytically and conceptually distinct, symbolic citizenship is not an antithesis to this argument. Symbolic citizenship highlights the discursive aspects of citizenship - how social movements struggle to associate their "style" of conduct and mannerisms, to produce and idea of good citizenship they claim to represent. The difference between the two approaches is at the epistemological level, in that a structural approach argues that civic codes inform how we assign meaning (sacred/profane) to social groups, while symbolic citizenship argues that movements draw from, or appeal, to civic codes as they resist how civic meaning is assigned, in order to produce new ideas of good citizenship. Symbolic Citizenship and the Body

Movements shape ethical bodily practices to represent ideas of good citizenship. Sociological and cultural studies research theorizes the body as a cultural variable within a given cultural and historical context, to overcome binaries such as mind/body. Past debates on the body distinguished the internal body from an external body (Turner 1992, 1996). The internal body considers how actors engage practices of "asceticism" - restrain and self-control around

36

the idea of purifying the self in relation to the control of pleasures, e.g. sexual, consuming alcohol or mass culture (see Sheppard 2002). The external body, which is primarily based Foucault's (1976, 1978, 1985, 1986) later works on sexuality and punishment, considers issues of representation and regulation of the body. For instance, Butler (1993) argued that bodies are not only formed through regulatory bodily practices, but we are compelled to reproduce bodily practices through rituals and performativity. Ritualized repetition (or performativity) of sexual norms produces and stabilizes a sexual subject. 'Sex', then, is an idealized construct which "functions as a norm, but is also part of a regulatory practice that produces the bodies it governs" (Butler 1993: 1). More recent sociological work on the body is centered on the idea of embodiment. Primarily based on Bourdieu's (1990) argument, embodiment considers how discourse works through the body in order to shape both cognitive and phenomenological processes of perception, evaluation and judgment. Wacquant's (2004) study on how boxing gyms regulate both the external and internal process of the body can be read, in part, as an attempt to synthesize the external/internal body. Wacquant illustrated how the boxing gym regulated the boxer's body around an idea of the good boxer. The good boxer trains, learns to throw a proper punch, shadow boxes, exercises with the 'rhythm' of the gym, but is also taught proper dietary practices of restraining from unhealthy foods and sex.

This dissertation conceptualizes the body as a political object to be disciplined. It examines how the civil rights movement used competing

37

discourses to organize deracialized techniques of self and ethical bodily practices. I highlight Foucault's use of the body in what he describes as the technique of self (1986). Technique of self refers to how individuals go about transforming, correcting, and regulating their civic practices in order to highlight and develop good black citizenship. For example, I analyze how the rights political project used discourses of good black citizenship to design pedagogical practices for their "citizenship schools", which instructed activists how to master affective responses, so that blacks could refrain from lashing out violently or hysterically when confronting violent whites. The citizenship schools taught personal, social and civic practices by combining adult literacy with instructions on how to evaluate and judge what counted as good citizenship. SNCC designed "community centers" for freedom summer, which instructed dietary practices, how to fashion/dress the body, and how to sew and maintain the appearance of ones home. Thus, the rights political project used discourses of good black citizenship to discipline movement activists the movement by teaching them to regulate their self around idea of good black citizen as a resistance to racializing good citizenship.

Situating the body in social movement research allows for an analysis of how movements shape bodily practices to indicate ideas of good citizenship. By introducing the body to social movement scholarship, I am critiquing two aspects of the cultural turn - the emphasis on cognition and the 'role' of emotions. The cognitive claim cuts through both framing and collective identity. Since framing has been aptly criticized, and in part discredited in favor of narrative and

38

discourse, I narrow my critique or the cognitive aspect of collective identity. Eyerman and Jamison (1991) 'cognitive praxis' skirts some of the problems with framing by considering the knowledge producing activities of the movement, but reproduces others. That is, movement intellectuals are responsible for much of a movement's ideas and strategies, and work to convince others through organizational, technical and collective memory/rediscovery of black history strategies. Yet, Eyerman and Jamison fail to say how knowledge transmitted or produced, other than to say cognition exists in all human actions. Integral to shaping collective identities and civic practices is the manipulation and training of the body. As I show in chapter 3, the rights political project instructed blacks on practices of good handwriting to teach the meanings and pronunciations of a civic vocabulary. They also used role-playing practices, where civil rights activists' simulated 'real' protest, to learn how to hold ones temper and cover up the body to minimize pain, when confronted by violent whites and southern police. The cognitive focus has no account of embodiment, or the disciplining of the body. The separation mind/body misses ho the body helps to explain how the discourse of good black citizenship is materialized, fixing the movement's collective identity to blacks by regulating good civic practices. Hence, my critique is on the sole emphasis on cognitive and collective consciousness of the movement that overlooks how the body is regulated and controlled through power.

My second critique is the relationship between body and emotions. The increased study of emotions in social movement research also critiques

39

emphasis on cognition, in favor of a cognitive and emotional focus that illustrates how emotions are tied into culturally defined moral values (Jasper 1998, Goodwin, Jasper, Polletta 2000). Emotions are important for social movements because they are communicative and contain both a subject and object (afraid of something) (Jasper 1998, Blee 1998). For existing social movement research, emotions round out cultural theories on collective identities and social networks, as well as offer unique analysis of "moral shocks" and differences between negative and positive affective bonds. Besides shared cognition, emotions help to build a sense of community and 'reinforce commitment' between members. Emotions like shame or guilt are sometimes the object of change (Taylor 1989). Women's groups have also used emotional standards of victimization to create political empathy frames that cast victims as positively viewed agents (Dunn 2004). Debunking stereotypes of the 'angry feminist', research on 'anger' and feminist protest illustrated that woman join social movements and engage in collective action because it offers emotional support to transform negative emotions into positive emotions of injustice (Hemes 1999, Reger 2004). Movements themselves rely on 'moral shocks' - those unexpected and exceptional events that create a sense of outrage, causing individuals to become politically active and aware (Jasper 1997, Reed 2004). Emotions can also cause a movement to disintegrate. Klatch's study on SDS argues that negative affective bonds produced "competition, pressure and intolerance, which causes the deterioration of group solidarity" (2004: 489).

40

Despite the move away from cognitively orientated movement research, the study of emotions continues to reproduce the mind/body binary. The body is overlooked even in studies where it appears to be at the center of analysis. For instance, the landmark book in the study of emotion, Hochschild's Managed Heart, considers how the 'love of the job' and positive emotions have become products for sale: "The emotional style of offering the service is part of the service itself" (2003: 5). She shows how flight attendants are instructed to 'smile' and manage their emotions to ensure that, among other things, customers are not upset. Rather than analyze the body, Hochschild draws from Goffmann's symbolic interactionism to say these emotions are part of the presentation of self at work - the front stage - where real emotions are forced to the back stage. Jasper's argument on emotions and social movements echo's her sentiment: "Emotions are learned and controlled through social interactions, although never with complete effectiveness" (Jasper 1998: 388). Thus, emotions are learned through social interactions, which may or may not be regulated, but are independent and autonomous from the body. While both Hotchschild and Jasper correctly argue that emotions have to be learned, they do not answer how we learn to manage our emotions for political reasons.

In addition, theories of emotions fail to explain the discursive aspect of emotions. Goodwin, Jasper and Polletta argued, "like other aspects of culture, such as cognitive meanings or moral principles, emotions are shaped by social expectations as much as they are emanations form individuals personalities" (2000:78). They failed to explain how movements manage the social

41

expectations and personalities of their supporters and adversaries. Movements attempt to regulate where, when and how emotion is used or not used. The rights political project drew distinctions between their supporters and bad citizens based on the bad citizens' inability to manage their emotions. In contrast, the black nationalist project used discourses of black authenticity to produce an idea of violent and revolutionary black political agent that intimated and scarred whites into giving blacks power. Thus, there is a discursive element to 'emotional work' that instructs the body how to react to and control bodily desires and pleasures that can be provoked from either positive or negative emotions. The black movement invested in techniques to control and contain anger and resentment. The rights political project used discourse of good black citizenship to minimize anger and resentment for political reasons. Politically, blacks wanted to avoid associations with irrationality - public emotions of anger and yelling - but also wanted to regulate emotions - like crying or hysteria - to not appear 'feminine'. They also regulated which bodies, (child's body, student's body, women's body) were presented and placed in public space and in organizational pamphlets asking for money to volunteers, to cultivate empathetic emotional bonds within heterogeneous local geopolitical factions of the black community. Thus, my point of departure of the study of emotions in social movements is to consider the discursive aspects of social movement through the political relations between body and emotions. CONCLUSION

42

The civil rights literature focuses on questions of organizations, the movements form, and its decline. Blacks mobilized through their church based organizational structure that allows them to take advantage of political opportunities in the state. King situated the movement's message in democracy and Christianity, which brought white support and defined the movement's identity. The movement declined because the federal government ended their support, and activists felt a sense of completion and frustration. Subsequent black political struggles have failed to energize the black community around common strategies, ideas or issues. Scholars have used these developments of the civil rights movement to argue for the importance of social movement organizations, strategic framing, collective identity and political opportunity structures. Yet, they do not consider issues of social movement and citizenship representation, the movements' pedagogical practices, how the black body was the object of these practices, which cannot be reduced social structures.

The limitations in the civil rights literature provide the opportunity to rethink the civil rights movement in terms other than organizations, frames and social structure and identity. A starting point is on how the movement approached citizenship. The civil rights movement was aware of what constituted good citizenship and importance of good civic practices. The rights political project used discourses of good black citizenship to define a set of ethical practices for blacks to master that represented blacks with an idea of good American citizenship. The rights project used discourses of good black citizenship as a deracializing strategy to challenge how America privileged race to determine

43

which citizens were included in the national civic culture.
