The production and reproduction of good black civic practices in public spaces changed white support on the state's and local geopolitical authority's use of violence to reproduce white privilege. Additionally, the rights projects normative claims associated with deracializing black citizenship created boundaries between 'good black' and 'bad black' citizenship. The black nationalist project produced an idea of an authentic black political agent in relation to deracializing strategies and whiteness. As blacks, especially blacks affiliated with SNCC, began to question the possibilities of black-white reconciliation and the value of nonviolent civic practice, they began to use discourses of black authenticity to produce new practices and strategies to obtain power rather than civic inclusion. The competing claims over black citizenship continue to be important today. The rights project, which dominated public discourse on black citizenship and racial equality, marginalized the black nationalist political project as a violent and irrational normative ideal, and thus, anchoring its ideas of authentic blackness to the margins of American civic an black political cultures.

The next chapter analyzes how the rights political project used discourses of good black citizenship to produce a set of ethical practices to represent blacks with an idea of good citizenship. The focus is on how the movement, especially through King, created an idea of mastering deracialized personal, social, and civic ethical practices. I show how the movement emphasized the good black -bad white binary opposition to displace bad whites from power and illustrate how race should not serve as a marker for good citizenship.

44

Chapter three analyzes how SCLC and SNCC used four "movement programs" - citizenship schools, role-playing workshops, grassroots leadership training, and freedom schools and community centers - to train the black body how to master personal, social and civic ethical bodily practices. The first part of the chapter traces the sociological and historical development of how and why SCLC combined ideas of voter registration and adult education into citizenship schools to instruct techniques of deracialized black self. The analysis includes how instructing and mastering ethical practices came in steps. First, blacks had to master personal ethical practices - how to master ones affective responses, how to practice good manners - before proceeding to social ethical practices. After mastering social ethical practices of interacting with blacks and whites, they moved on to mastering civic ethical practices of how to canvass a neighborhood for voter registration, how to hold a mass meeting, and how to prepare and protect the body during public protest to remain nonviolent. I also compare the differences in how SCLC and the rights project versus how SNCC used a grassroots project. Both projects used discourses of good black citizenship. However, SNCC worked mainly with poor blacks, the occasionally poor white, and rural black communities, whereas SCLC was more involved in urban areas. In contrast to SCLC's affiliate program, where leaders came from the black church, SNCC's grassroots project involved training activists on mastering good ethical practices to take in the field and instruct other blacks on good ethical practices. SNCC also instructed good health and dietary practices, to bring immediate improvements to the rural black communities, and concentrated

45

around organizing blacks and whites based on the shared a local geopolitical culture, rather than by using an idea of a shared nation-state.

Chapter four analyzes how the black nationalist project used discourses of black authenticity to challenge the idea that deracializing black citizenship would lead to racial equality and improvements for the black community. The first part of the chapter concentrates on how Malcolm X and the Nation of Islam produced a normative ideal of the authentic black citizen by abstaining from associations of whiteness and in relation to deracializing strategies. The black nationalist project, in particular, defined racialized techniques of self to attach the black self to the racial group rather than the nation-state, and emphasized the use of emotional bodily practices as a representation of the real black response to racial discrimination. The second half of the chapter analyzes how SNCC grassroots projects, based on local geopolitical identifications, provided openings for members to use discourses of black authenticity to organize around an idealized black only political identity and reject the use of nonviolent civic practice. The conclusion compares the rights political project and black nationalist project, and uses SNCC to consider the question of how groups become more revolutionary.

The final chapter is a case study on the Selma to Movement and Meredith March. Whereas the chapter four analyzes the how SNCC adopts the black nationalist project, this chapter highlights how the movement splits into two competing political projects. I provide an alternative explanation to prevailing theories on why the black movement declines at the point of its greatest 'success'. First, I provide an overview of Selma's local geopolitical culture, and

46

the divergent strategies found in both the black movement and local police practice. Then, I show the post-Voting rights political culture, along with the challenged posed by the black nationalist project, split the movement into two competing fractions based on the question of what to do next by changing the object and subject of civil rights protest. More specifically, the projects differed on questions of 1) organizing on a national or local level in the continued struggle for black equality 2) pedagogical practices of movement programs 3) the form of civic practices, and 4) the their approach to urban revitalization. I conclude the chapter with an analysis of how the black nationalist challenge to the rights project forced the rights project to abandon the good black/bad white binary and focus on the good black/bad black normative claims. Despite the decline of the movement, I show how the ideas of deracialized and racialized black political agents produced by the competing political projects continues to serve as normative ideals for blacks to model subsequent political struggle.

47

CHAPTER 2: THE RIGHTS POLITICAL PROJECT AND DISCOURSES OF GOOD BLACK CITIZENSHIP

The rights political project, which made up the dominant position of civil

rights movement, used discourses of good black citizenship to produce the idea

of the good black citizen. What the rights project meant by the good black

citizens racially non-threatening, even tempered, physically nonviolent black

citizens, who reflected heteronormative American masculinity and femininity, so

that could they could integrate into the national polity as equal citizens, while at

the same time, displacing bad whites from positions of power. They used

discourses of good black citizenship as a deracializing strategy that

disassociated racial stereotypes from black citizenship. Drawing from the cultural

ideals of good American citizenship, the rights project defined a set of normative

ethical practices that defined and placed limits on how blacks should approach

civic inclusion. The symbiotic relationship between good citizenship and

idealized American civic culture suggests that idea of the "good American citizen"

is not autonomous concept. For instance, the Nation of Islam disciplined and

cultivated an image of blacks as exhibiting good manners and good character,

but they intertwined good black practices with a conflicting American civic

tradition of revolution, separation, and non-western religion (Muslim) and a

competing set of goals of producing black political autonomy (see chapter 4).

Thus, the larger implications of the rights project was producing an idealized

black citizen to illustrate why democracy worked better when racial, and to an

extent class, identities were suppressed in favor of universal and idealized

citizenship practices.

48

The rights political project used discourses of good citizenship makes normative claims about the type of citizen deserving of rights. That is, they produced an idea of what should represent black citizenship and distinguished an idealized black citizenship from what they defined as bad black citizenship. Discourses of good black citizenship included four normative categories - good blacks, bad blacks, good whites and bad whites. Idealized American citizenship defined each of the four categories in relation to the degree that they reflected idealized citizenship. The rights project emphasized the good black -bad white binary opposition to displace bad southern whites from power. They used discourses of good black citizenship contrasted good blacks with bad whites to illustrate how race should not serve as a marker for good citizenship. In contrast, the black nationalist project used discourses of black authenticity, which contrasted the good black and bad black binary, to define and distinguish an normative idea of the authentic black citizen. Thus, the rights political project produced a set of ethical practices that defined the 'right way' to be a good citizen for blacks and whites.

We see how the rights project used discourses of good black citizenship begins to shape deracialized technique of self that represented the idea of good black citizenship in texts produced primarily by Martin Luther King, pamphlets and public materials produced by Southern Christian Leadership Conference (SCLC) and the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (SNCC).2 These texts defined a normative rhetoric of talking, discussing and defining blacks'

2 This chapter focuses on SNCC as part of the rights project, before they began to draw from the grassroots project and before their transformation to into a black nationalist group.

49

practices, as well as aligning black citizenship with the idea of good citizenship, and a set of bodily ethical practices to master, which produced the idea of good black citizenship. Taken as a whole, these texts represent how the rights project sought to define the immediate goals of the movement, as well as fix an interpretation and collective memory of movement events. This chapter draws from the above text between 1954 and 1965. I selected this time-period because it spans the beginning of the Montgomery Bus Boycott to the start of the Selma Movement. Chapter 5 will specifically deal with the Selma movement and how post-Voting Rights Act affected black political practice. I analyzed the texts to isolate important patterns and clusters of thought that illustrate how the rights project portrayed blacks as good citizens deserving of rights. The organizational pamphlets, memorandums, minutes to meetings etc. illustrate how the movement designed guidelines and instruction on, for instance, how to exhibit good manners and refraining from violence, as well as the narratives and stories used to portray blacks as good citizens. I organized the chapter by analytical category, or themes, rather than teleological sequence. It is not a history of all aspects of the civil rights movement.

Historical Overview of the Rights Project and Deracialized Ideas of American Citizenship

The rights political project drew from American ideals of democratic citizenship while constructing the idea of good black citizenship. Although the movement resisted racialized citizenship, the cultural features of American citizenship still shaped the form and articulation of a deracialized American

50

citizenry. The civil rights movement articulated their idea of good black citizenship through existing meanings of citizenship - including a discourse of rights, responsibilities and what counts as good citizenship. Two important ideas of good American citizenship was the idea of adulthood signifying the independent and rational good citizen, and 19th century liberal protestant cultures that nurtured ideals of self-mastery in relation to nonviolence and refraining from social vice (drinking, gambling etc.).

The formation of the American state in 1776 included a variety of exclusionary restrictions on whom and what counted as good citizenship. The right to vote and participate in governing affairs was, in part, predicated on property ownership. Catholics, Jews, Quakers and blacks were also excluded. The move to incorporate additional white men into the polity began in 1792 when New Hampshire became the first state to eliminate property ownership as a condition for enfranchisement. Property ownership gave way to an achieved status of 'adulthood' as a new the basis for American citizenship. Citizenship became a status adults acquired with age. It established a hierarchy based on age (man/boy) which drew from the idea that men acquired wisdom over time. In addition, the system of slavery racialized adulthood by linking good citizenship with economic self-mastery, which distinguished "man from slave" and distinguishing and established a "minimum of social dignity" for whites in relation to blacks (see Shklar 1991: 1-3). No matter how destitute poor whites were, skin color alone provided minimal social advantages relative to blacks. For blacks, denied them associations with the capacity to control ones life and make rational

51

decisions that remained after slavery ended. The idea of dignity 'achieved'

through economic self-mastery linked idealized images of the white laborer with a

working class male identity. As culture of 'individuation' and 'self-directed work'

became the dominant position in early 19th America, it solidified the idea of

independence with ideas of rationality, and voting became the political

representation of a deliberate, conscious and independent act (Wiebe 1997: 30-

31).

Southern whites continued to harden racial boundaries after the American

Civil War, and through subsequent Southern Reconstruction. Whites used

violent practices to produce and maintain a sovereign white political polity. They

erected obstacles to prevent blacks from voting, thus restricting blacks from

associations with 19th century ideals of American citizenship. Whites justified

excluding blacks from political power on the basis that blacks were not morally

capable of handling the responsibility. For instance, the White Citizens Councils'

often cited former Mississippi Governor (1904-1908) James K Vardaman on his

views on blacks and democracy:

The Negro should never have been trusted with the ballot. He is different from the white man. He is congenitally unqualified to exercise the most responsible duty of citizenship. He is physically, mentally, morally, racially and eternally the white mans inferior. There is nothing in his race, nothing in his individual character, nothing in his achievements of the past nor his promise of the future which entitles him to stand side by side with the white man at the ballot box (RS 1-10).

The Vardaman text represented a racializing strategy to produce a democratic

culture that excluded blacks on the basis that they are not fit for democratic

citizenship. White Mississippians excluded blacks to ensure whites maintained

52

exclusive access to state resources, and by the 1930s, New Deal federal money. Because there were more blacks in Mississippi then whites in 1892 Mississippi started issuing literacy tests. The law stated that "a person had to be able to read any section of the Mississippi constitution, or understood any section when read to him, to give a reasonable interpretation of any section" (quoted from SNCC pamphlet, located in RS 1-10). Blacks were required to interpret any one of the 244 sections of the Mississippi constitution. However, it mattered less who did the interpreting than who judged and decided the legitimacy of the interpretation. As long as whites occupied all positions of political authority in the Mississippi state government, they excluded blacks from political power. The practice of using literacy tests to exclude blacks became the primary focus of SCLC's political programs and the subject of the 1965 Voting Rights Act.

Besides the age and racial classifications, the idea of mastering the bodily pleasures of what one ate, drank and the social space it frequented slowly emerged as representations of good citizenship. While southern whites drew from old south political cultures, specifically ideas that blacks were morally inferior to whites, and thus, not worthy of American citizenship rights, the rights project's drew from liberal protestant culture that linked ideas of nonviolence and good character with good citizenship. Liberal protestant culture included the Garrisonians, the nonviolent anti-slavery advocates, as well as mid-19th century temperance and self-help movements, and progressive thinkers. Rather than produce new rights, however, the 'self-help' movements of the 1840s attempted to improve American civic mannerisms and character. What the self-help groups

53

thought needed improving were the bad mannerisms associated with American politics, including eating habits, tobacco chewing, and public violence between political opponents (see Wiebe 1995: 49-50). In relation to masculine ideals of toughness with independence, self-help groups proposed avoiding practices like gambling, fighting, and drinking in favor of sobriety, frugality, buying homes and joining churches (see Wiebe 1995: 61-85). The idea of good manners emerged as a way to regulate a civic populace and establish the basis for intra-white hierarchies between political and economic elites and the 'mass culture' populace.

The self-help and temperance movement gave way to the American progressive movement that cemented associations of the good Christian with American nationalism, as well as new political strategy focused on shaping and manipulating public opinion. Eisenach argues that from 1880-1918, a progressive "regime of thought" emerged that combined a "language of social science, social control, community character, piety and memory, created systems of knowledge and institutional structures" (1994:46) to reconstitute personal identities and American citizenship. The idea behind the progressive project was to define a religious identity of 'liberal Protestantism', which would serve as the cultural structural basis for a good democratic public culture. For the progressive project, good citizens were Christians, and preferably Protestant. This also implied Americans were not Jewish, Muslim or Hindi, e.g. non-Christians. Indeed, King drew from liberal protestant intellectuals and pacifists such as

54

Niebuhr, Thoreau, in addition to Gandhi and black intellectual culture3 as the source for his approach to nonviolence.

In addition to associating the good Christian with an American national citizenship, progressive reformers reconstituted the idea of public opinion. The progressive idea of public opinion differed from James Madison, who associated public opinion with community values, and mid-19th century ideas of public opinion as a governmental form of social control (See Wiebe 1995: 38). The progressive approach to shaping public opinion also differed from the anti-slavery and women suffrage movements approach to social change. Although the women's movement changed public sentiment on child labor, the age of sexual consent, and food safety and public sanitation prior to winning suffrage, they joined the Republican Party in order to get their reforms into the public sphere (see Eisenach 1994: 81, Spain 2001). The progressive strategy sought political reform by concentrating their efforts in the most politically influential geographic territory, from New York to Chicago, rather than attempting to form political coalitions or independent parties. The progressives utilized their positions as college professors and periodical editors to have immediate access to the public sphere. They mastered the art shaping public opinion as a technique of resistance. Good citizens used their intellect, expertise and skill to initiate political change. They did not have to march or demonstrate to directly appeal to local representatives. The civil rights movement, especially SCLC, drew from this strategy of shaping public opinion be concentrating their political efforts in the

3 Information on how King drew from liberalism, black intellectual culture and Gandhi's satayaghara can be found in Ansbro [1982] 2000, Garrow 1986: 42-48, Lischer 1995: 51-64)

55

south, in relation to bad whites, in order to sway national sentiment and support for citizenship rights.

The decline of the progressive movement coincided with the rise of pacifism and peace cultures in the interwar period. Peace cultures nurtured the ideas of using nonviolent direct action as technique to end racial repression and global conflict, including world wars and colonialism. The peace culture that developed around WW 1 drew from socialist, feminist and Christian ideas to critique war-time economies, the defense of civil liberties and ideas of nonviolence (see Early 1997: 189-200). The peace culture challenged American ideas of the good soldier representing good citizenship. Individuals who influenced King's views on nonviolence spent time in pacifist cultures, including Glen Smiley and James Lawson of the liberal protestant group Fellowship of Reconciliation (FOR) (WF 29-1). Rustin, a World War 2 conscientious objector, spent time in prison for his pacifist beliefs (see Garrow 1986: 66). The civil rights movement drew from the peace culture on using the body as a non-violent weapon against violent and aggressive white police.

The above developments of American citizenship illustrated the cultural features of good American citizenship. The rights project drew from idealized good American citizenship to produce a deracialized technique of self that represented blacks as idealized citizens. Despite using a deracializing discursive strategy, they nevertheless retained social categories of good citizens as independent, self-directed, rational and a property of adult masculinity. Next, I will explain how King defined a set of ethical practices, which organized the

56

deracialized techniques of self, and represented good black citizens capable of

integrating into the civic polity.

Good Black Citizenship and Deracialized Techniques of Self

King, who publicly represented the black rights project, used discourses of good black citizenship to outline a set of practices for blacks to master. King used discourses of good black citizenship as a deracializing strategy to disassociate black citizenship from unfair and harmful stereotypes by shaping ethical practices that reflected idealized citizenship. In particular, mastering deracialized techniques of self required mastering affective response to limit black associations with black stereotypes of being savage, angry, and lacking the self-control that makes one prone to violent and emotional outbursts. In addition, the rights project did not want blacks participating in violent civic practices such a rioting or fighting police. In order to accomplish this, the movement outlined a series of techniques on how to observe, monitor, correct, and improve a set of ethical practices in relation to conduct in relation to idealized American citizenship.

The idea of black self-improvement was a contested issue in the late 1950s. King's book editors and advisors edited out the subject of black self-improvement in his first book Stride Toward Freedom and the subsequent collection of sermons in Strength to Love (see Lewis 1970, Garrow 1986). Nevertheless, the idea of "black self-improvement" was a dominant theme throughout his sermons. King's most important and definitive sermon, titled 'Loving Your Enemies', was first given in 1957. He posed the question on how to

57

overcome the fear and hatred of the other in relation to improving bad civic

practices. The sermons, in their original unedited, form featured the common

themes of outlining how to limit bad practices and how to identify good practices

in others.

In order to understand how the rights project used discourses of good

black citizenship to produce the idea of good black citizenship and fashion it onto

the black populace, we can analyze King's arguments for "why" and his

suggestions for "how" blacks can/should be good black citizens. First, King

wanted to convince black Americans that deracialized techniques of self were the

best and most effective resistance practices. Mastering good ethical practices

was a resistance practice that displaced race as the marker of good citizenship.

Idealized American citizenship based membership and rights on objective

standards of achievement. Therefore, King distinguished why denying equal

citizenship differed from interpersonal reasons attributed to ascribed

characteristics:

Now, I'm aware of the fact that some people will not like you, not because of something you have done to them, but they won't like you... Some people aren't going to like the way you walk... like the way to talk... Some people aren't going to like you because your skin is a little brighter than theirs; and others aren't going to like you because your skin is a little darker than theirs... They're going to dislike you not because of something that you've done to them, but because of various jealous reactions and other reactions that are so prevalent in human nature (King [1957] 1998:43).

For King, equal citizenship for blacks was not a question of whites liking blacks,

which meant outlining a standard of acceptance, but rather, a question of what

counts as good citizenship for blacks and whites. Whites could accept blacks

58

and still deny them equal citizenship rights. In order to integrate into the American polity, King had to change the associations of good American citizenship and make blacks reflect that ideal. Therefore, mastering deracialized techniques of self provided a method of displacing bad whites from power and race from good citizenship, and producing a normative ideal of black citizenship.

For blacks, mastering deracialized techniques of self was necessary to convince the general American public, especially whites, that blacks were good citizens who deserved rights. King argued that mastering deracialized techniques of self as the most effective way to debunk black stereotypes and prove they were unwarranted and unfair. He argued that, "the Negro must make a vigorous effort to improve his personal standards. The only answer that we can give to those who through blindness and fear would question our readiness and capability is that our lagging standards exist because of the legacy of slavery and segregation, inferior schools, slums, and second class-citizenship" (King [1960] 1986: 149). King isolated bodily practices as the site of power and resistance. He argued that failing to master deracialized techniques of self represented blacks as irrational black political agents. Because bad posture, bad manners, sloppy, unkempt, and unclean appearance were attributes of bad citizenship, King argued blacks should minimize and eliminate them. Unlike bodily conduct, race is an ascribed attribute that blacks cannot change. King wanted blacks to concentrate on modifying their bodily practices because it was something that blacks could control. Blacks could not control how state actors -police, social workers - or bad whites acted towards them. They could master

59

techniques of self that whites used to justify the subject of their ire. Deracializing personal and ethical practices meant exposing bad white anti-democratic and racialized practices. Thus, King isolated bad bodily conduct as the site of self-improvement that could disassociate or sever the significations of race from bad citizenship.

Secondly, King identified a series of techniques for blacks to use in everyday life that could guide them in how to identify and correct bad civic practices. First, King noted that, "In order to love your enemies, you must begin by analyzing self" (King [1957] 1998: 42). Blacks should contrast the self with idealized citizenship practices. Contrasting the good black self in relation to idealized citizenship practices overcame the problem of mimicking bad white civic practices as an expression of good citizenship. On the one hand, 'copying' whites would have confirmed that 'whiteness' equated into good citizenship. On the other hand, blacks copying bad whites' reinforced ideas that race marked good citizenship. In addition to his sermons, King publicly reiterated how blacks can transform themselves into good black citizens. One technique required blacks to ask themselves "how may I transform this liability into an asset?'" (King [1963] 1964: 209). He wanted blacks to isolate bad practices that whites used to deny them rights and transform them into good practices that resisted the rationale that blacks did not deserve rights because of character deficiencies. In other publications, King suggested that blacks diligently seek to improve on their present skills and practices, "For whatever demands the Negro justly makes on his fellow citizens are not an effort to lift responsibility from himself.... he will

60

have to learn new skills, new duties, and creatively and constructively to embrace a new way of life" (King 1964: 167). Blacks had to improve an entire set of ethical practices if they were to represent good black citizens. Black demands for rights would only be accepted once blacks convinced the American public that they were worthy not only worthy of rights, but also worthy of full civic inclusion into public life. Therefore, we should view the civil rights movement as preparing blacks for more that the political right to vote. The idea behind good black citizenship was a way to master good civic practice, so that blacks could enjoy the full range of citizenship, e.g. running for office, holding office, engaging in public debate, and assuming positions of public authority.

Good black citizens refrained from violence to exhibit respect to others and respect for the self. Nonviolence meant refraining from physical attacks, as well as refraining from exhibiting violent demeanors and conduct that provoked 'fear' or 'hatred' in others. King used discourses of good black citizenship to link nonviolence with self-improvement, "Our most fruitful course is to stand firm with courageous determination, move forward nonviolently amid obstacles and setbacks, accept disappointments, and cling to hope. Our determined refusal not to be stopped will eventually open the door of fulfillment" (King [1963] 1964: 209). Nonviolence served as an ideal that regulated a very general method of self-improvement. Mastering nonviolent practices reinforced idealized democratic standards and debunked black stereotypes.

In sum, the rights project produced an idea of good black citizenship to attach the deracialized black self to the nation-state. It represented the idea that

61

all citizens had to abandon, or at least downplay, the use of racial identities to define citizenship, as full membership and inclusion into the polity, if democracy was to work and fulfill its vast promises and potential. King associated deracialized techniques of self with the expansion of the black movement, "gradually the Negro masses in the south began to reevaluate themselves - a process that was to change the nature of the Negro community and doom the social patterns of the South ... We Negroes have replaced self-pity with self-respect and self-determination with dignity" (King [1956] 1986: 76). King credited the capacity of the black movement to expand and maintain a presence over time and geographical space, in part, to the idea of good black citizenship and deracialized techniques of self to the "success" and capacity of the movement to integrate into the American polity. GOOD BLACK CITIZENSHIP ETHICS

The rights project used discourses of good black citizenship to define three ethical practices - personal ethics, social ethics and civic ethics. Personal ethics defined the relationship blacks had with their self. It included managing bodily postures of how one talked and walked that organized a deracialized self and produced a unitary political agent and image of good black citizenship. Social ethics defined the relationship blacks had with others. Social ethics included mastering good manners to ensure cordial and rational relations with whites and other blacks, how to manage interracial sexual relations, in order to discredit black stereotypes. Civic ethics defined how blacks should use their mastery of personal and social ethics in their political practice. Mastering civic

62

ethics required limiting emotional outbursts (anger, hysteria) when debating matters of public concern, conducting media interviews, and demonstrating for rights. Thus, mastering the set of ethical practices was how blacks used the deracializing strategy that represented them as good citizens. Although each set of ethical practices had a symbiotic relationship with the others, I nevertheless analyzed each one separately for the sake of clarity. Personal Ethics and Good Black Citizenship

The rights project guided blacks on how to manage and master a set of personal practices that projected idealized good black citizenship. We find two dominant themes pertaining to personal ethical practices. The first is "good manners", which included ideas of cleanliness, connotations of higher education, and attractiveness. The second is "good character", which included ideas of what counts as dignity and how to master pleasures and emotions association with bad citizenship. A central idea pertaining to both good manners and good character was blacks being attentive of their bodily postures. The rights project used discourses of good black citizenship to define good manners in relation to the manner in which blacks walked and dressed. The idea behind a proper way of walking is associated with self-confidence and self-respect. The rights project wanted blacks to master bodily practices of walking with their heads up, shoulders back and looking at others in the eye to convey signified meanings of being trustworthy and respectable citizens. King noted the change in blacks' bodily postures as the civil rights movement began to take its shape "The increased self-respect of even the least sophisticated Negroes in Montgomery is

63

evident in the way they dress and walk, in new standards of cleanliness and of general deportment" (King [1958] 1964: 118). Blacks involved in the movement began exhibiting ethical bodily practices signifying meanings of cleanliness. They disassociated themselves from black stereotypes and meanings of bad citizenship - dirty, unintelligent, and not trustworthy - associated with race, poverty and newly arrived immigrants. Repetitive bodily practices of walking upright, wearing 'nicer' and less racialized clothing reproduced good black citizenship.

In contrast to good black citizens mastering good manners exhibited through their bodily postures, King distinguished how bad white personal practices did not reflect idealized citizenship. King observed how the whites in the Montgomery courthouse watching the trial of seven whites arrested for bombing his house were not 'clean': "One could tell from the dress and manner of the whites that most of them were poor and uneducated, the kind that would find security in the Ku Klux Klan. As we entered they looked at us with undisguised hate" (King [1958] 1964: 113). King noted that bad whites' sloppy and unkempt personal ethical practices associated them with bad citizenship. King made this distinction of differing personal practices to illustrate that bad conduct is not racially determined. King also wanted bad whites to improve their personal ethical practices. Bad whites did not practice any personal ethical standards of cleanliness or civility. Rather, they sought to distinguish themselves by using violence to police racial boundaries, and reproduce the idea that white skin equated to good citizenship.

64

In addition to the idea of cleanliness, the rights project used discourses of good black citizenship to argue that blacks should master the personal ethical practices associated with higher education and intelligence. King drew from the ideas that higher education cultivated more culturally refined citizens. King emphasized good manners and higher education to distance blacks from images as dirty sharecroppers or street thugs. He noted that the new civil rights protesters, especially the students of SNCC, differ from past black citizens: "But neither is the Negro today an elderly women whose grammar is uncertain; rather, he is college-bred, Ivy League-clad, youthful, articulate and resolute. He has the imagination and drive of the young, tamed by discipline and commitment" (King [1961] 1986e: 160). King associated good black manners with Ivy League colleges. In the late 1950s and early 1960s, this would have produced an image of an elite group of men, dressed in Brooks Brother's attire, epitomizing the mannerisms of a respected and knowledgeable citizen. King used representations of black college protesters as well spoken, clear in intention, and conveying their displeasure with unfair racialized hierarchies rationally, to indicate that good blacks reflected idealized American citizenship.

Indeed, SNCC's importance and 'success' was about more than just a commitment to "the philosophical or religious ideal of nonviolence as the foundation of our purpose, the presupposition of our faith, and the manner of our action" (EB 5-2). SNCC used discourses of good citizenship to argue that black stereotypes denied opportunities to blacks with achieved educational attainment: "Thus, many college trained Negroes are offered the mop and broom when

65

seeking employment in private industry" (EB 5-2). The students went to school,

worked hard, and embodied good citizenship. Yet, whites still denied students

equal employment. Subsequent talk and discussion of the students' personal

ethical practices during the sit-ins distinguished the students as good citizens.

King emphasized how the students mastered affective and bodily response by

refraining from violence: "few students are attracted to extreme nationalist sects

advocating black supremacy. The students have anger under controlling bonds

of discipline" (King [1961] 1986e: 164). Noting that SNCC was a disciplined

movement shielded them from critiques of irrationality so SNCC could articulate

the excitement of spontaneity sweeping through black college. Additionally,

James Farmer distinguished the students from bad whites based on their

presentation of self:

Newspaper and television accounts of the sit-ins suggested a picture which reversed the common stereotypes. Inside, at the lunch counters, sat well-dressed, well-mannered Negro college students with their calculus and philosophy books, quietly asking for a cup of coffee; outside, crowds of white boys with duck tailed haircuts and leather jackets grinned and shuffled their feet to start trouble (Farmer 1965: 67-68)

Farmer distinguished the students from white youths based on each of

their fashion and mannerisms. Good black students were engaged in techniques

of self-improvement - reading philosophy and mathematics. They were neatly

dressed and well mannered. Asking for a cup of coffee quietly made them polite.

In contrast to the good black students, bad whites exhibited bad bodily posture.

They shuffled their feet rather than walking upright and looking others in the eye.

Grinning associated them with being obnoxious and mischievous. This

66

associated bad whites with a general lack of respect for the self and others. Bad whites reject techniques of self-improvement in favor of using violence to hold back good blacks.

Good black citizens were clean, educated, as they exhibited a personal appearance that represented blacks as charming and attractive. An attractive citizen is the type of person that exhibits conventional American beauty norms, as has a pleasant personality. Describing the personal ethical practices of the students, King said, "I am no longer surprised to meet attractive, stylishly dressed young girls whose charm and personality would grace a junior prom and to hear them declare in unmistakably sincere terms, 'Dr. King, I am ready to die if I must" (King [1961] 1986e: 161). Deracializing the black self meant mastering practices of charm and physical beauty, which are embodied representations of cleanliness. This differed from the personal ethical practices of bad whites. Bad whites who screamed obscenities in public did not represent idealized American citizenship. Regarding bad whites personal ethics involved in defying desegregation laws, King contrasted good blacks with bad whites: "One who breaks an unjust law must do so openly, lovingly (not hatefully as the white mothers did in New Orleans when they were seen on television screaming, 'nigger, nigger, nigger') and with a willingness to accept the penalty" (King [1963] 1986a: 294). Whereas good black women represented polite, charming and attractive citizens, bad white women represented unpleasant, vile and repulsive citizens. Good citizens do not scream obscenities at children attempting to go to

67

school. Good women do not reflect the manners of bad white men relying on

skin color to distinguish themselves from blacks.

The second set of ethical practices we find in the rights project's text are

the ideas of mastering personal ethical practices to shape good black character.

The rights project sought to deracialize the associations of good character in

order to define good character as an achieved status that citizens must practice

and master in place of using race to define good character. Deracializing

citizenship is necessary not only to define blacks as good citizens, but also limits

participation and legitimacy of bad white citizens4. Good character is associated

with 1) dignity, 2) worthiness 3) restraint and 4) modesty. First, the rights project

used discourses of good black citizenship to define dignity in relation to public

recognition blacks can be trusted and counted one. Good black citizens

represented the American ideal, not bad whites. By mastering personal ethical

practices, the black male:

He came to feel that he was somebody. He came to feel that the important thing about a man is not the color of his skin of the texture of his hair, but the texture and quality of his soul. With this new sense of dignity and self respect a new Negro emerged. So there has been a revolutionary change in the Negro's evaluation of his nature and destiny (King [1958] 1986: 85-86).

For blacks in the movement, mastering personal ethical practices organized a

new way of perceiving and interpreting political life. Good black citizens rejected

attributing race to abilities and capacity for success. King noted that, "In the new

age we will be forced to compete with people of all races and nationalities.

4 In order to secure political power, bad whites associated blacks with bad character to justify their exclusion from public life. In 1960, the Mississippi legislative passed a joint resolution to amend the 1890 Article XII of the Mississippi constitution to include a new qualification, good moral character, to the list of qualifications to vote (RS 1-10).

68

Therefore, we cannot aim merely to be good Negro teachers, good Negro

doctors, good Negro ministers, good Negro skilled laborers. We must set out to

do a good job, irrespective of race, and do it so well that nobody could do it

better" (King [1957] 1986: 139). Good black citizens strove to be the best in

order to overcome boundaries and limits placed on them because of race.

Simply being a good black doctor implied that black doctors were inferior to white

doctors. It kept racial stereotypes attached to capabilities, skills and character.

In addition to speeches and writings, the rights project defined a set of

personal ethics in their published movement literature and pamphlets. The

movement printed and distributed pamphlets to gain recruits, and network with

smaller autonomous movements at small black colleges and churches. We can

see one example of how the rights project used personal ethical practices in an

SCLC pamphlet simply entitled "Why" to understand how they fashioned ideas of

dignity and worthiness to black citizenship. The pamphlet situated the life of a

fictional, yet typical, black family into a crisis narrative. Crisis narrative

"emphasizes not only the tragic distance between is and ought but also the

possibility of heroic overcoming" (Jacobs 2000: 9). Situated in a discourses of

good black citizenship, the pamphlet used the crisis narrative to produce the

normative idea of good black citizens trying to better themselves but cannot

because society denied blacks rights and opportunities. The story starts as:

Tommy is a bright intelligent little boy who lives in Alabama. There is no limit to the things Tommy could become and do in his lifetime. He could be a great scientist and build spaceships; he could be a businessman or a doctor; he could make enough money when he is older to give his own family a decent life. But the odds are against Tommy because he is a Negro (CC 3-2)

69

The story presented the "Tommy" character as good black child full of potential

and promise. The story noted that occupations associated with high-status and

high income could be his future. Tommy has the abilities, and we presume that

he would be and is capable of working hard, to fulfill the 'American Dream' of

moving up the social hierarchy. The tragedy is that Tommy's ascribed

characteristics, black skin, will prevent him from ever reaching his potential. A

fair desegregated democratic culture would not deny Tommy opportunities. The

narrative then incorporated Tommy's parents,

Tommy's parents love him, but they cannot see to it that he gets the education he will need...Tommy's mother and daddy are not lazy people; they want to work, but they cannot find jobs. Tommy's parents did not get the kind of education they needed to qualify for many jobs. Besides that, white people are hired first in Alabama, and Negroes only get the jobs that are left (CC 3-2)

Tommy's parents defy stereotypes that black poverty is the result of bad personal

ethical practices. Tommy's parents want to work, but they never received a

quality public education that would give them decent jobs. They wanted to

overcome their lack of education, but white employers would not even hire them,

even for menial jobs, because they are black. The "Mommy" and "Daddy"

characters appealed to both parents and students of the movement. It

challenged the students to think - do you want to end up like your parents? It

challenged the parents to think - do you not want something better for your

children? The narrative then defined Tommy as further victim of white violence:

Tommy's parents pay taxes, but the Alabama police are not used to protecting Tommy and his family. They are used to keeping them down. The police may beat and intimidate Tommy when he is older, and Tommy's parents will not be able to do anything about it (CC 3-2).

70

The narrative represented Tommy's parents as worthy and dignified good

citizens. They want to work hard and fulfill their basic citizenship participation

like paying taxes, joining voluntary associations and voting indicate ideals of

republican good citizenship. For blacks, however, the fulfillment of citizenship

duties did not produce and form of civic integration. It is the idea that active

citizenship did, and would, not produce civic inclusion that the idea of mastering

deracialized techniques of self emerged as the new strategy to produce civic

integration. This part of the narrative is targeting students and young people to

give them a glimpse of a possible future. Finally, the narrative presented the

solution to the problem and ended the tragedy in the form of good citizenship and

voting:

Voting is the answer! We cannot freely vote. Many of the Negroes' problems in Alabama are direct result of not having the right to freely vote. We have been told that he reason Negroes are poor, uneducated and in bad shape is because we are no good and lazy. Let's see what the real reason is. Join the Freedom Army" to solve these problem and vote (CC 3-2).

By concluding the crisis narrative with voting, it refuted black stereotypes as

helpless victims, and portrayed good blacks as political agents capable of

producing social change. Thus, the fictitious story of Tommy and his parents

represented how the civil rights movement sought to disassociate race from good

citizenship. The characters in the narrative represented blacks as good people,

worthy of civic inclusion and rights, but denied opportunities to succeed.

Third, the rights project used discourses of good black citizenship to

separate material products blacks used as a strategy to project social statues, in

71

sought to replace it with associations of good character. Specifically, the rights product wanted blacks to practice self-mastery when consuming material projects. This had two implications. On the one hand, it emphasized the quality of ones character. On the other hand, self mastery of consumer products was a deracializing strategy that sought to limit flashy styles of dress in favor of more conservative fashion practices. We see the emphasis of good black personal ethics in the program for the "Mass Meeting Sponsored by Southern Christian Leadership Conference Program for Student Conference and Raleigh Citizens Association". SCLC designed this program, closer to a small pamphlet, for the conference that led to the formation of SNCC. Despite narratives of spontaneity to distinguish and collective identity from the adult, part of SNCC's commitment to nonviolence required mastering personal ethical practices that represented them as good black citizens. For instance, the program contained a picture of King on the front. Under the picture, the text says "International Proponent of first-class Christian Citizenship Through Intelligent Non-Violent Protest" (EB 5-9). The text in a box under the picture and headline indicated: "Sacrifice for Dignity. First class citizenship is more important that first class clothes. Give up something for Easter in order to support the students sit down protest and the drive for total freedom (EB 5-9). Mastering good black personal ethical practices meant refraining from pleasures of shopping for consumer or material items. However, it also meant refraining from the desire to by new clothes because it reflected bad black stereotypes. Dressing the body in respectable clothing distinguished blacks as good citizens. It contrasted to the flashy and extravagant

72

styles of dress that represented black stereotypes that blacks only cared about their appearance.

The rights project viewed personal ethics of self-restraint and modesty as important to being a good black citizen. Self-restraint meant carefully managing and controlling one's emotions in relation to abusive white police and white citizens, when handling the bombing or attack on ones home, family or friends, and the right way to integrate buses or schools. An important part of SNCC's sit-ins included mastering self-restraint in relation to verbal and physically abusive whites. Mastering affective response required careful attention and detail to one's conduct. The public display of anger represented blacks as irrational. The public display of arrogance represented blacks as bad citizens. The ritualized repetition of good black civic practice provided the clearest distinctions of blacks as good citizens.

In his book Stride Toward Freedom King tells the story of how his Montgomery home was bombed to illustrate how he mastered self restraint, and how mastering ones emotions was beneficial to the black movement. The Montgomery Bus boycott began to make both statewide and national headlines because of the prolonged black commitment to the boycott and the nonviolent style in which they protested. Eventually, members of or sympathetic to the Klan bombed King's house while King was giving a speech at a local mass meeting. His wife, two-year-old daughter and friends' wife were home at the time. King arrived home, only to find that the tensions between local blacks and whites were escalating. The risk of not controlling this situation meant at minimum a riot and

73

potentially the end of the movement. King depicted the scene in front of his

house:

One Negro was saying to a policeman, who was attempting to push him aside: "I ain't gonna move nowhere. That's the trouble now; you white folks is always pushing us around. Now you got you '38 and I got mine; so let's battle it out.' As I realized that many people were armed. Nonviolent resistance was on the verge of being transformed into violence (King [1958] 1964: 90).

At this point in the Montgomery Movement, King indicated it risked disintegrating

into violent racial factions. The failure of the police to prevent the bombing is

important because the Montgomery Police Chief Clyde Sellers recently joined the

White Citizens Council. The bombing represented how bad whites used violent

practices to control and intimidate blacks. Black residents had been exhibiting

nonviolent civic practices in the bus boycott, but they were not pacifists.5 King

argued his mastery over his emotions help prevent further violence:

In this atmosphere I walked out to the porch and asked the crowd to come to order. In less than a moment there was complete silence. Quietly I told them that I was all right and that my wife and baby were all right. 'Now let's not become panicky,' I continued. 'If you have weapons, take them home; if you do not have them, please do not seek to get them. We cannot solve this problem through retaliatory violence. We must meet violence with nonviolence.... Then I urged them to leave peacefully. "We must love out white brothers,' I said, 'no matter what they do to us. We must make them know that we love them (King [1958] 1964:90-91).

Despite the tension and anger, King's ability to regain order and 'quietly' address

the crowd is significant. In a situation where whites almost killed his family,

coupled with gathering crowd, King addressed the onlookers in a calm and

rational manner. King did not shout, he did not curse, he did not yell, and by all

5 Many blacks owned guns for protection against bad whites. Indeed, the pacifist Glen Smiley persuaded King to give up his gun as a commitment to nonviolence and not appear hypocritical.

74

accounts, he did not cry. King's mastery over his emotions allowed him to exhibit

self-restraint.

The rights project trained Montgomery blacks in the art of self-mastery and

self-restraint to ensure good personal ethical practices when preparing to

integrate the buses. Additionally, they encouraged blacks to exhibit modestly by

regulating the style of conduct and manners blacks exhibited when ritually

boarding and choosing a seat on the bus. First, the Montgomery movement

emphasized modesty:

...we must not go back on the buses and push people around unnecessarily boasting of our rights. We must simply sit where there is a vacant seat... This places upon us all a tremendous responsibility of maintaining, in face of what could be some unpleasantness, a calm and loving dignity befitting good citizens and members of our race. If there is violence in word or deed it must not be our people who commit it (King [1958] 1964: 106).

Blacks were encouraged to board and sit on the bus as if nothing had changed.

They were to follow the ritual without interacting with white riders who may

violently respond. Managing one's conduct required consistency. Good black

citizens were modest in the bad and good times. When it came time to boarding

the buses, no one in the movement was sure how whites would respond. Would

they respond violently, would they boycott the buses? The movement decided to

place black ministers on the buses because they felt their presence would give

blacks courage and make them less likely to retaliate if insulted by whites (King

[1958] 1964: 109). In this sense, the presence of ministers provided a system to

ensure and support blacks exhibiting good practices. By practicing good

75

personal ethics, blacks ensured the American public that they were not provoking whites, but rather, were riding the buses as good citizens.

Prior to boarding the first integrated buses in Montgomery, the rights project designed a series of "general suggestions" and "specific suggestions" that instructed blacks on how to board the buses as good citizens. Movement organizers instructed blacks on how to board, sit and ride the buses through a series of workshops held at mass meetings.6 Here, I want to focus in how the rights project designed the suggestions around the idea of mastering personal ethical practice. Some of the suggestions read:

4. Demonstrate the calm dignity of our Montgomery people in your actions.

5. In all things observe ordinary rules of courtesy and good behavior. Remember that this is not a victory for Negroes alone, but for all Montgomery and the South. Do not boast! Do not Brag!

7. Be quiet but friendly; proud, but not arrogant; joyous, but not boisterous (King [1958] 1964: 106).

Good blacks practiced good manners and good character when riding the buses.

They were to be calm and courteous when entering, sitting and riding. There

was a consistent idea that blacks should refrain from public celebratory acts.

Bad citizens were ungrateful. Good conduct also meant mastering affective

responses. Blacks did not want to appear arrogant, but they also did not want to

appear apathetic. By practicing good manners and good conduct when

integrating buses, blacks demonstrated that racial segregation was unfair while

reflecting idealized citizenship.

6 The next chapter analyzes in depth how the rights and grassroots project trained the body to master a set of ethical practices that represented them as good black citizens

76

While the general suggestions served as guidelines, which outlined vague and abstract values of good conduct on how to board the buses as good citizens, the "specific suggestions" outlined the exact practices of how to choose a seat and how to handle an adverse situation with whites:

3. In sitting down by a person, white or colored, say 'May I' or 'Pardon me' as you sit. This is a common courtesy

4. If cursed, do not curse back. If pushed, do not push back. If struck, do not strike back, but evidence love and goodwill at all times

5. In case of an incident, talk as little as possible, and always in a quiet tone

6. For the first few days try to get on the bus with a friend in whose nonviolence you have confidence. You can uphold one another by a glance or by a prayer (King [1958] 1964: 107).

The specific suggestions illustrate the importance of mastering good manners

and good character. Good manners meant saying 'may I' and 'pardon' when

walking past another citizen. The public display of specific well-recognized

manners ensured blacks would not be associated with black stereotypes of bad

behavior e.g. rude, uncivilized. Additionally, the workshops instructed blacks to

be "quiet" and not respond to bad whites. Being quiet referred to not escalating

or making the worst out of a bad situation. If whites were verbally rude or hostile,

a lack of response ensured no further problems. Conversations amongst friends

were to be of a quiet or modest level. Voices were never to be raised to a noise

level others would deem unpleasant. Suggestion number six instructed blacks

ride the bus with a friend. Ministers rode the buses to provide guidance on good

conduct. However, friends provided an immediate and intimate form of

surveillance. Friendship provided a reciprocal relationship to inspect and ensure

good civic practices, as well as provide a witness to good conduct. As a witness,

77

they could publicly testify that their friend was a good citizen in relation to bad

whites. The surveillance practices of the friend reproduced good citizenship by

fixating ritualized good personal ethical practices while riding the buses.

In addition to the suggestions on how to enter and sit on the bus as good

citizens, the movement printed flyers and distributed them to black riders who

could not or did not attend the training sessions at the mass meetings. The

Montgomery Movement produced the flyers with the dual reading public of black

bus riders and whites who may object to integrating buses. The flyers read:

Negroes can now sit anywhere on Buses!

Be first class citizens! It's now time to move up front! Ride first class for

first class fare - - Sit in any empty seat on buses!

Remember: Be good Americans - be calm, be quiet, be friendly, be

prayerful but be free" (EB 5-9).

The flyer explicitly associated the importance of personal ethical practices with

idealized good American citizens. With instructions already established on the

proper way to board, sit and ride the bus, this flyer cements the association of

good civic conduct with idealized American citizenship. This flyer communicated

to Montgomery whites that blacks would not be involved in creating a public

spectacle of bus integration. Rather, blacks would simply exercise their right to

enter and sit on a bus like other good citizens who ride public transportation.

King reported that blacks integrated the buses without incidence and that

most whites were respectful during this process. One exception was a white

man who slapped a black woman in the face. Unlike white man, King noted the

black woman practiced self-mastery over her affective response. "True, one

Negro woman was slapped by a white man as she alighted, but she refused to

78

retaliate. Later she said: 'I could have broken that little fellow's neck all by myself, but I left the mass meeting last night determined to do what Reverend King asked'" (King [1958] 1964: 110). Despite wanting to retaliate, she practiced self-restraint and deferred to the pedagogical practices that represented good black citizenship.

In sum, the rights project used discourses of good black citizenship to deracialize black personal ethical practices by shaping idealized bodily postures and affective response to produce a normative idea of good black citizenship. The ritualized repetition of good conduct deracialized associations of good character to ascribed racial status. King used the good black / bad white binary to demonstrate the race had no impact or determinant cause on what counted as good citizenship. Indeed, bad whites who continued to exhibit rude conduct towards blacks contributed to the idea that good citizenship could no longer be associated with white skin color. By mastering deracialized techniques of self, blacks in the movement forced whites to engage the question of what counts as good citizenship. Is it white mothers screaming obscenities? Is it dirty whites shuffling their feet, uttering obscenities and using large groups of other bad whites to intimidate blacks? Or is it the college educated, articulate, well dressed and disciplined blacks that represent good citizenship? Social Ethics and Good Black Citizenship

In addition to outlining which personal ethical practices for blacks to master, the rights project constructed a set of social ethical practices for blacks to master when engaging others. The importance of social ethical practices was to

79

regulate how racial and gendered bodies could interact as equals in public by minimizing the use of racial stereotypes that interfered with equitable public relations. They used discourses of good black citizenship to define how blacks should minimize affective responses of fear or hatred in others. In the text, we see three relations 1) black-black, 2) black-white, 3) gender, emerge as the most important relations needed regulating. Regarding black-black relations, it was important to maintain a middle ground that distinguished the good black citizen from the Uncle Tom and Black Nationalist. Regarding the black-white relations, it was important for black to practice deracialized techniques of self that rejected black stereotypes, which facilitated racial and civic integration. For gendered relations, it was important to establish a male hierarchy between black men and black women that mirrored the broader gender hierarchy. However, it was also important to limit sexual relations between black men and white women because the rights project did not want to alarm or drive away sympathetic whites. Overall, the importance of regulating the gendered relations was an attempt to produce heteronormative black families that mirrored heteronormative white families in order to help the process of desegregation.

Once blacks' mastered personal ethical practices, they were to use them in all social relations. Overcoming black stereotypes was the biggest obstacle to mastering social ethical practices. Stereotypes are abstract generalizations that can potentially apply to any social group. Power works to attach harmful stereotypes to group identities. The civil rights movement targeted black stereotypes associated with bodily practices - blacks as lazy, dirty and prone to

80

violence - as the point of resistance. Racializing strategies, more systematic in the south than other parts of America, put the onus on blacks to prove that black stereotypes were unfair and unwarranted. Economic and legal strategies did not creating changes in the south. Local white political elites did not enforce legal ruling like Brown v Board of Education that desegregated schools. White unions, who were not influential in southern politics to begin with, felt they were in competition with black workers and blamed blacks for low wages. Therefore, blacks alone shouldered the burdened and responsibility of refuting unfair stereotypes. King argued that the southern black man, "He has to win and to vindicate his dignity in order to merit and enjoy his self-esteem. He had to let white men know that the picture of him as a clown - irresponsible, resigned and believing in his own inferiority - was a stereotype with no validity" (King 1964: 31). Social ethical practices were important to master so as not to confirm black stereotypes in the eyes of whites.

First, the rights project emphasized practicing deracialized techniques of self when interacting publicly with other blacks. They wanted blacks in the movement to distinguish themselves as good black citizens in relation to Uncle Toms and black nationalists. The idea of an Uncle Tom referred to blacks who gained increased social standing at the expense of other blacks. The movement identified Uncle Toms in local black communities as blacks who interfered with civil rights work. They avoided Uncle Toms because they harden black intra-group boundaries. Yet, the idea of black nationalism, especially ideas of racial separation and the use of violence as means for achieving equality, projected an

81

image of being 'too black' and anti-American. Being too black would harden racial boundaries between whites and blacks. The Uncle Tom was more problematic to blacks, while the black nationalist was more problematic to whites. The idea of the black nationalism was perceived as more harmful for the movement than the Uncle Tom because it had the potential to decrease white support for desegregation. By distinguishing themselves as good black citizens, the rights project represented a political position that stood in opposition to both white and black supremacy, and racial shame.

For the rights project, the black nationalist project represented the opposite of idealized American citizenship, and thus, should be avoided. King argued the Nation of Islam, "is made up of people, who have lost faith in America, who have absolutely repudiated Christianity, and who have concluded that the white man is an incurable 'devil'" (King [1963] 1986a: 296-97). Although America has no official state relation, historically Christianity has implicitly functioned as the normal religion to religion. Not being Christian equated to not being a good citizen. Indeed, James Farmer argued that blacks should avoid and reject the bad civic practices of black nationalists because they are dangerous and unpractical, "With no real work to do in America, their advice to love blacks turns into a program to hate whites. Eager to act manfully, they can only imagine petty schemes of violence and revenge" (Farmer 1965: 106). Rather than improving race relations in America, black nationalists are more concerned with immediate pleasures of revenge. The pleasure associated with revenge is using violence as means of fulfilling immediate goals of getting even

82

rather than long-term goals of cultivating a better system of racial and democratic

equality. Furthermore, the rights project viewed the black nationalists'

separation, isolationist and violent practices as rejecting democratic public life.

Public life depends on some commonalities and associational life. Hardening

racial boundaries inhibits public life and anchors blacks to the political margins.

In contrast to hardening racial boundaries, mastering deracialized

techniques of self limited affective responses in whites. Whites made reactive

and irrational decisions because they feared blacks. White political elites used

the fear of blacks to initiate racialized legislation that shaped a southern idea of

whiteness that unified a white population differentiated by geography, religion,

and class. For example, a 1959 letter by former governor of Georgia Marvin

Griffin (1955-1959) urged Georgia's whites that, "We must wipe the registration

slate clean every two years to keep from adding thousands of ineligible Negroes

each year... I know that you would much prefer this slight inconvenience to

turning our state over to Negro domination. This is the only way to protect

ourselves" (EB 5-1). Bad whites practiced a racially threatening technique of self

that encouraged bad black strategies that made black nationalism appealing to

blacks. King encouraged blacks to limit associations with black nationalism, but

he also notes how whites also needed to accept good black citizens as equals,

And I am further convinced that if our white brothers dismiss as 'rabble rousers' and 'outside agitators' those of us who employ nonviolent direct action, and if they refuse to support our nonviolent efforts, millions of Negroes will, out of frustration and despair, seek solace and security in black nationalist ideologies - a development that would inevitable lead to a frightening nightmare (King 1964: 91).

83

If whites resisted the rights project's deracializing strategy into the American

polity, then blacks would seek out black nationalist alternatives. Just as black

racialized techniques of self produced affective responses in whites, racialized

whites practices discouraged blacks from practicing nonviolent and democratic

reform. Bad white practices had the implications of igniting a race war. Their

resistance to the rights project would only convince blacks that America would

never change. In contrast to bad whites, good whites preferred the alternative of

minimizing racial conflict and supporting idealized American citizenship. They

rejected all forms of racialized strategies in favor of civic inclusion based on what

counts as good citizenship.

Mastery of bodily postures and affective response created opportunities

for interracial cultural exchange. Interracial cultural exchange meant whites and

black agreeing on a public consensus of good not tied to or associated with

either race. King notes that:

Not long ago the Negro collegian imitated the white collegian. In attire, in athletics, in social life, imitation was the rule... Today the imitation has ceased. The Negro collegian now initiates grouping for unique forms of protests... Overnight, his white fellow students began to imitate him (King [1961] 1986e: 161).

The indication of whites imitating blacks does not refer to whites acting black. It

refers to an idea of how some whites began acting like good citizens by

establishing external values of good citizenship not associated with racial

hierarchies7. Most important were white students adopting and supporting good

civic practices like sit-ins and nonviolent direct action. All over American college

7 King also presented the civil rights moved as political inspiration for American and European whites in relation to African independence movements and decolonialism

84

campuses, whites formed 'Friends of SNCC chapters to raise money and

organize support for civil rights within the white community. Rather than copying

blacks, we should understand the movement as stimulating the white

communities to support a deracialized American citizenry.

Finally, the rights project used discourses of good black citizenship to

organize a normative claim of what counted as the good black man. The idea of

good black man had two interrelated dimension. First, the rights project defined

good black men as political agents who mastered masculine practices that

allowed them to care for their family, as a the black patriarch, which created a

hierarchy between black men and black women. Before black males can master

civic practices associated with the public sphere, they must first master head-of-

household practices associated with the private sphere. The good black man

should be the head of the house, the breadwinner, and family decision maker.

The reasons behind shaping an idea of good black men with the familial patriarch

was that it associated black men with masculine ideals of adulthood, such as

strength and independence, that were intertwined with good citizenship.

Matriarchy violated the black man's ability to practice self-mastery. The

subordination of black men to black women not only undermines his masculinity,

but by extension also undermines his capacity to be a good black citizen. King,

especially, associated matriarchy with cultural conditions that artificially elevated

black women above black males:

When a Negro man is inadequately paid, his wife must work to provide the simple necessities for the children. When a mother has to work she does violence to motherhood by depriving her children of her loving guidance and protection; often they are poorly cared for by others or by

85

none - left to roam the streets unsupervised... The Negro mother leaves home to care for - and be a substitute mother for - white children, while the white mother works (King [1958] 1964: 126-27).

King argued that matriarchy interfered with the proper or 'normal' gender roles

intertwined with family roles. The decline of black masculinity, in turn,

strengthened white masculinity and the white family. For King, black women in

the labor force mixed up gendered family roles, and led to the dissolution of black

families. For instance, black women frequently worked as 'domestics' fulfilling

the roles of childcare and maid for white families in order for white men to enjoy

public life. Black women neglected the care of black children at the expense of

white children. Thus, the rights project used discourses of good black citizenship

to project an idealized black masculinity as part of their symbolic citizenship

claims. Good black men exhibited the same masculine practices as good white

men. The rights project used idealized masculinity to situated good black men

and good white men with idealized meanings of citizenship, at the expense of

bad black men and bad white men.

The second dimension of good black men was producing an idea of

masculinity not centered on violence. Besides convincing blacks that nonviolent

practices increased their chances of success, the rights project had to convince

blacks that nonviolence did not make them less of a man. The idea of accepting

beatings from white men, being spit upon, and berated with hostile language, all

violated masculine notions of strength and control. King notes that, "...

nonviolent resistance means that you do resist in a very strong and determined

manner and I think some of the criticisms of nonviolence or some of the critics fail

86

to realize that we are talking about something very strong" (King [1963] 1986b: 336). King associated nonviolence with attributes of 'strength' and 'sophistication'. Good black men were 'man enough' to accept the tough and unpleasant challenges of changing the world the 'right way'. The right way was through nonviolence, which distanced blacks from America's violent past. In addition, affective self-mastery distanced black men from feminine associations. Good black men did not show emotions, such as wincing or crying, when hit. They did not act out 'hysterically' when whites cursed at or spit on them. Thus, affective mastery organized black masculinity by emphasizing masculine virtues of strength and limiting feminine practices of weakness.

In contrast to good black men, bad black men failed to master their emotions and desires, which associated black men with black stereotypes of violence and broken down black families. Black men who failed to care for their families, and instead choose to hang on street corners, drink excessive amounts of alcohol, gambled etc. represented blacks as bad citizens. For the rights project, the implications for black men that did not master deracialized techniques of self were the continued subordination to whites and civic integration. In part, the distinction between the private and public sphere, where women have cared for children and fulfilled domestic labor duties, has produced the idea of the autonomous and rational political agent. However, culturally, the idea of intact black heteronormative families represent the symbiotic aspects of the public and private sphere, in that mastering the domestic sphere adds an additional aspect of status and associations of being "normal" to black

87

citizenship. Therefore, the rights project's symbolic citizenship claims relied

heavily on black men being good black men because black men were the

dominant representation of good black citizenship, and therefore, the degree that

they exhibited norms of American masculinity helped align them with idealized

citizenship.

An important part of the rights projects normative claims of the good black

men was how it contrasted black masculinity to black femininity, and created

boundaries between black men/black women, straight black men/gay black men.

The rights project understood black masculinity in relation to black femininity. The

rights project fashioned the idea black masculinity and black femininity around

the black polity by instructing gendered family roles into the pedagogical

techniques of both their "citizenship schools" and "community centers". The

community centers in particular sought to teach women how to be good mothers

and good wives, in order to attach them to the domestic sphere and the

household. Community centers offered instructional classes on nutrition (self
