and child), daycare services, as well as "Public healthcare such as prenatal and

infant care, basic nutrition" (CC 1-1). For men they offered classes on how to fix

up ones home. A CORE pamphlet asking for donations for their community

centers relied on ideas of idealized gender roles.

Recently, fabric for 110 dresses was sent by the IGWU's Local 23-25 to Mississippi. Many of the women who learned to sew by making a dress at the community center had not had a new dress for 4 or 5 years. Their involvement in the sewing class encouraged most of them to start voter registration classes (CC 1-1).

88

Good women learned how to be good wife and mother, through mastering

techniques like sewing, which represented them as good black women. The

rights project used discourses of good black citizenship to attach them to a set of

practices that had black women play 'second-fiddle' to black men. Regulating

black citizenship around a patriarch ideal of gender and American citizenship, in

part, organized the mainstream civil rights movements symbolic citizenship

claims.

However, black women in the movement resisted ideas that they

should function as good women and know their proper place as subordinates

(see Morris 1984: 114-115, Crawford et al 1993, Gyant and Atwater 1996).

Under Ella Bakers guidance, an unnamed young woman circulated a letter to

other members of SNCC protesting the gendered practices of work

assignments,

A fall 1964 personnel and resources report on Mississippi projects lists the number of people in each project. The section on Laurell, however, lists not the number of persons, but 'three girls... Average white person finds it difficult to understand why the negroes resents being called boy or being thought of as 'musical' or 'athletic' because the average white person doesn't realize that he assumes he is superior... So too the average SNCC worker finds it difficult to discuss the woman problem because of the assumption of male superiority (EB 5-9).

Similar to the utterance of 'boy' that whites used to marginalize black men, black

women rejected black men' use of the utterance 'girl' to reproduce a gender

hierarchy. Black men protested, accepted blows and went to jail. 'Black girls'

answered phones and went on coffee runs. Black women resisted because they

equated gendering citizenship with racializing citizenship. While the rights

project was using discourses of good black citizenship to open space for equal

89

citizenship between men, they were doing it at the expense of black women. Black and white women's displeasure over how black and white men treated them inspired many women to later abandon struggles for racial equality and organize the women's movement of the early 1970's (Ferree and Hess 2000: 53-75).

While little evidence exists of direct articulations of black masculinity in relation to hetero/homo binary, the silence on the subject speaks volumes. Queer theory challenged the idea that gender and sexuality are autonomous concepts (see Bulter 1990, Seidman 1999). That is, cultural images of the 'man' imply a heterosexual man. Good black citizens were not gay. The presence of a gay black man created a point of contestation within the movement. The movement felt that public knowledge of Bayard Rustin's sexual practices would be harmful to the movement (Morris 1984: 115, Garrow 1986: 69). Black political rival Adam Clayton Powell threatened to expose Rustin to the public to discredit SCLC unless King gave Powell input on intra-political matters (see Garrow 1986: 138-140). Roy Wilkins, president of the NAACP, also used Rustin's sexuality to undermine Rustin's work and decision-making over the March on Washington (Garrow 1986: 276). Despite personal contempt for Powell, King obliged and kept Rustin as a background advisor. Rustin worked primarily behind the scenes with white advisors Stanley Levison and Jack O'Dell, who were former members of the American communist party. Rustin obtained no leadership position in any black organization until he directed the A. Phillip Randolph Institute in 1965.

90

Besides defining the relations black men should have with black women, the rights project also defined the proper relations black men should have with black women. The most difficult social ethical practice to manage was interracial sexual and marital practices. Interracial marriage and sex represented asymmetrical power relations between races that overlapped the public and private sphere. Black men were to avoid all social and sexual contact with white women. The question of white males who engaged in sexual relations with black women differed. White male sexual overtures represented the lack of respect and the hypocrisy of whites not wanting to live or work with blacks but still willing to engage in sexual practices with them. Southern whites felt it was their right as white men to have sex with black women. This right was exclusive to white men. White women did not count in this equation. Each interracial sexual practice centered on the problem of the men. Women were victims or potential victims who needed protection from racialized sexual predators. The social position of black men in relation to white men also informed how each should manage interracial practices. Blacks had to contend with the threat and realities of murder. This meant blacks had to pay particular attention to their public practices around white women.

The use of interracial sexual practices was a topic the movement carefully managed. The movement could not reject interracial sex practices to appease whites because it would undercut their deracializing strategy. However, they also could not publicly condone interracial sexual practices because it would repel whites who supported equal rights but did not want their sons or daughters

91

sexually involved with blacks. The movement attempted to bracket the question of interracial sex from the discussion of good citizenship. There is no discussion of blacks and whites of good character and moral standing starting families and or even dating. The movement was neither for nor against interracial sex. They would only say that interracial sex and marriage was not part of the movements' goals. For example, in text produced by King and Farmer we find no definitive stance on the debate. On interracial marriage, King notes, "... the Negro's primary aim is to be the white man's brother, not brother-in-law" (King [1958] 1964: 128). Good blacks want to be neighbors, friends and fellow citizens, but they do not want to share a mixed race gene pool. Although James Farmer was critical of anti-miscegenation laws that prohibited interracial marriage (in 1965, nineteen states had such laws on the books) he sidestepped talk on interracial sexual practices by claiming that marriage and sexual practices were property of the private sphere: "And we are not advocating interracial marriage. I believe that such advocacy is as dirty-minded as the prohibition. One simply must not dictate to the human heart this way" (Farmer 1965: 127). Situated in the private sphere, states cannot regulate interracial sexual desires. Good citizens' sexual practices are personal matters not subject to regulation. Ideally, the private sphere provided the limit of limits of state intervention. Farmer assured critics that the movement did not advocate or encourage interracial marriages, nor would its practices encourage such endeavors.

The difficulty in managing interracial sex also reflected the asymmetrical racial-structural positioning between black men and white men. The question of

92

white men and black women differed from the question of black men and white women. For black men, it was a question of making white women publicly available. First, white men did not face the same threat of violence as black men. Second, the question of white men and black women was a sexual practice that represented practices of racial exploitation. For white men, it was a question of the hypocrisy of privately engaging in sexual relation while rejecting public forms of racial integration. Farmer noted that "Black women are for white men to have; white women are for no one to have. In a typical Southern town, every Negro knows of the whites who are kin to him" (Farmer 1965: 126). Here, the question of white men and black women is not a normative condemnation of interracial sexual practices, but of white men not being accountable for his actions. Fathering interracial children without acknowledging the children or the mother represented irresponsible and bad practices. Bad whites do not take care of their families like good citizens. They are secretive, dishonest and inconsistent. These same associations also represent bad white organizations like the Klan and white citizens' council. A special July 1964 issue of Jet magazine on the civil rights movement represented white male sentiments toward black women. A small article titled "Sex dominates white thought in Mississippi" writes "A white man (in Mississippi) admitted that he had kept a Negro mistress for thirty years but the indignity denied he favored 'social' equality'. As proof of this, he argued that he had 'never', he said hotly, 'sat down to breakfast with her" (RS 1-11). Here, the question is not that whites had interracial sex with black women. It was how they did it. Bad whites

93

differentiated sex from intimacy with black women the same way they would a prostitute. Black women were objects for bad whites to use to satisfy a need, urge or desire. Sex was a practice that enforced racial hierarchies. Civic Ethics and Good Black Citizenship

In addition to defining personal and social ethical practices, the rights project also used discourses of good black citizenship to define civic ethical practices for blacks to master while protesting and making claims for rights. For the rights project, blacks had to master deracialized techniques of self when engaging the public for political reason. They used their deracializing strategy to produce a black political agent who could demonstrate, run for office and function as a government administrator. Therefore, rather than view strategy as a product of elite decision-making, this dissertation holds that the civil rights movement embedded strategy in discourses of good black citizenship. The rights project constructed civic practices that pitted the black body in social space dominated by bad whites. They emphasized the good black / white binary that distinguished blacks as idealized citizens. In order to do this, the rights project limited civil rights protest to four analytically distinct protest civic ethical practices -citizenship programs, boycotts, sit-ins, and marches - that prevented movement supporters from engaging in revolutionary and separation practices.

Despite the glamour of mass protests and direct action, the rights project spent the majority of their resources registering blacks to vote. They used public demonstrations only when federal and local governments refused to desegregate facilities and prevent blacks from registering to vote. The rights project used

94

voter registration practices to attach blacks with idealized good citizenship. Good black citizens were active in their communities. Active citizenship is an ideal associated with practices to improve and make communities better by keeping democratic leaders honest and accountable8. Through their citizenship schools and leadership training sessions, the rights project trained movement activists on how to exhibit personal and social ethical practices, e.g. good bodily postures, when active in the community. Good bodily postures included how to listen to local black complaints for what they said, and more importantly, what they did not say. It meant learning how to speak clearly, so others could understand, as well as the subject of conversations. Mastering personal and social ethics practices ensured blacks exhibited good black citizenship when engaging in political action.

When voting could not create social change, the civil rights movement used direct action. Rustin was the main architect for nonviolent direct action. He urged SCLC to utilize direct action techniques because blacks could demonstrate locally to impact national citizenship (Garrow 1986: 85-86). This strategy differed to both the legal strategies of the NAACP and the revolutionary strategies of groups like the Nation of Islam. Roy Wilkins distanced the NAACP from direct action because he felt that it associated blacks too much with the labor movement of the 1930s, and early NAACP attempts at marching did not change much (see Fairclough 1987: 65). The NAACP represented black political practice that placed the responsibility for social change solely on black elites. Although some scholars consider SNCC's grassroots project more radical than 8 On active citizenship as a public ideal see Lister 1997

95

SCLC because of their commitment to participatory democracy and independence from black church leadership, SNCC too emphasized public protest practices. Because the rights project and grassroots projects goals were civic inclusion, they could enter into working relations with one another, but not the Nation of Islam or black power groups.9

Direct action was an intimate strategy to improve the immediate conditions of racial violence because it placed the body at the point of power/resistance. Blacks used the body to deracialize citizenship by changing how the body experienced pain. Blacks felt and experienced white domination through the body. Death by lynching was a physically brutal and symbolic form of social control. The body of the lynched experienced the pain of torture as whites sought to inscribe racial power through violence. Whites hung black bodies from trees for other blacks to view. Emotionally, blacks feared sudden and unjustified attacks. Black bodies experienced pain and violence through auditory sensations, especially bad whites cursing and berating of blacks during protests and marches. The body is also how blacks experienced and interpreted poverty. Black southern poverty meant cold winter homes that were not equipped with heat and windows. Malnourished bodies, stemming from poor carbohydrate rich diets and the demands of physical agricultural labor, marked black embodiment. All of the movement's direct action protest techniques required the immediate use and transformation of bodily practices.

To elaborate, in the 1950s Robert Williams organized an NAACP chapter based on armed self-defense, and was subsequently excluded from the national NAACP office, as well as the Montgomery Improvement Association.

96

The bodily techniques of nonviolent direct action were limited to three practices. First was the use of boycott. Tarrow (1998) described boycotts as modern repertoires because they are nonviolent. Boycotts could be selectively unleashed against specific adversaries. They were flexible in that they could protest local bus segregation or regionally based chain stores that did not buy from black businesses. Good citizens used boycotts because they indicated inclusion into the existing moral order. Rather than destroy present social institutions, boycotts applied pressure on institutions to change their exclusionary practices. Boycotts were a technique to improve how social institutions valued and treated blacks. The Montgomery Bus Boycott improved the spatial ordering of black bodies in pubic space. The placement of black bodies in the rear of the bus in relation to white bodies in the front, or forcing blacks to stand while whites sat, devalued black bodies and reproduced a racial social ordering. The deteriorated physical conditions of buildings that served as all black schools, or the decrepit public facilities all served to fixate bodily interpretation, through visual and auditory senses, that blacks were inferior and deserved civic exclusion.

The second civic practice was the march. The march represented a tradition of protest where activists express dissent through the public exhibition of bodies in public. It mattered less how much the movement marched or how many people marched. The effectiveness of a march was the style of marching and the conduct of the marchers. For instance, SCLC outlined how protesters should march to the courthouse or registrars office, "persons visiting the

97

registrars office should do so in groups from 5-10. This will enable us to have witnesses in the event there are incidents relating to voter registration... We should send over our best persons first. Meaning persons we feel are reasonably qualified" (SCLC Part 4 Reel 1). For the rights project, the march, if properly executed, were effective at establishing the good black / bad white binary. A march comprised of good black citizens not reacting to the white mob's jeers projected the idea of good black citizenship throughout the dominant public sphere, and helped the overall civil rights movement gain supporters and allies.

The third protest practice was the sit-in. Similar to boycotts, sit-ins were flexible. Besides the lunch counter sit-ins, movement activists used swim-ins in hotel pools to protest segregated hotels, and stand-ins to protest segregated movie theaters. For instance, a SNCC produced test that instructed embryonic grassroots political cells how to apply the sit in model to a theatre protest, "A line of students forms at the ticket window, and, one by one, each person asks to purchase a ticket. Upon refusal, the person goes to the end of the line, which will continue to revolve in this manner."10 The advantage of using a sit-in over a boycott was that citizens could get their point across with just a few bodies. The Nashville students only needed 91 students to create an image of unjust and unfair treatment by whites. Effective boycotts demand the commitment of large groups of people mastering consumption practices over time. Unlike citizenship schools and community centers, sit-ins did not require large-scale networking, organization or resources. King noted the vast potential of social change through sit-ins, "Thousands of courageous students, sitting peacefully at lunch counters, 10 SAV 48-8 "SNCC - February First Freedom Day Action"

98

can do more to arouse the administration to positive action than all of the verbal

and written commentaries on governmental laxity put together" (King [1961]

1986a: 159). Sit-ins produced images of the unjust ways whites handled and

treated blacks. It also demanded a different kind of commitment than boycotts

because bodies were the site of violence. The rights project and SNCC's

grassroots project trained bodies how to absorb a blow, how to 'deaden' ones

weight, while maintaining a good black presentation of self.

The rights project used discourses of good black citizenship to regulate

how direct action civic practices were fashioned in relation to local geopolitical

adversaries. The strategy to deracialize American citizenship worked best when

they could use the good black / bad white binary on the local level to induced

federal response. Despite the variation of protest techniques, they all required

the mastery of bodily postures and affective response in relation to bad whites.

For example, CORE instructed the students involved in the sit-ins how to protect

their bodies. For males, they were to "kneel down and arch over, with skull and

face protected" while females were "to prevent internal injury from kicks, lie on

the side and bring the knees upward to the chin" (quoted in Zinn [1965] 2002:

24). Protecting the body to minimize pain limited the possibility for an emotional

or violent outburst. The students brought instructions on how to exhibit a good

bodily presentation of self, which included the following instructions:

Don't strike back or curse if abused, Don't laugh out, Don't hold conversations with floor workers. Don't leave your seats until your leader has given you instruction to do so. Don't block entrances to the stores and the aisles. Show yourself courteous and friendly at all times. Sit straight and always face the counter" (quoted in Oppenheimer and Lackey 1965: 81).

99

In addition to a style of dress, mastering good bodily postures and affective responses also distinguished the students as good citizens. The students used public recitations of good citizenship practices to remind them to exhibit good civic practices. By publicly articulating that they would not reciprocate the violence and bad behavior of whites, the students made sure that larger publics could read the distinction between good black and bad white civic practices.

Besides pitting groups of protests versus bad white business practices, we have to understand how protest techniques also took place in geopolitically defined spaces. Part of situating the good black / bad white binary was selecting local geopolitical cultures and public figures that best represented bad white citizenship. They choose regions associated with 'predictable' bad white adversaries, like Birmingham and Selma, but also in relation to social space and dates in American History that associated the movement with idealized citizenship. The students staged sit-in at restaurants connected to city, county or federal government buildings (Zinn [1965] 2002: 27). This included a sit in at the lunch counter of the Montgomery City Courthouse (EB 5-1). It also meant protesting in spaces that were associated with the states national beliefs and values. In the recorded minutes of an SCLC meeting held in Atlanta July 2 & 3, SCLC directed protest strategy in an "Attempt to make use of the symbolism inherent in such historical days as: December 15th (bill of rights day) September 17th (Constitution Day), and July 4th (Independence Day)" (EB 5-2). By choosing historical dates, good citizen practices fixated American ideals of democratic

100

rights and equality to the movements' goals. It also had the dual purpose of

displacing bad white groups from doing the same thing:

It would be good to have a number of mass meetings held in the south on July 4th. As it stands we usually celebrate this date with picnics and other entertainment, and the only group memoralizing the date, is the 'daughters of the American Revolution" who by no means can be called progressive. The movement for freedom in the South should make use of these symbolic dates in American history, as a means of dramatizing the unfinished business of democracy. (EB 5-2)

Bad whites used an identical strategy of staging group performances to link them

with idealized American civic virtue. By fashioning strategy in relation to both

bad whites and special dates in American history, the movement forced on

looking publics to ask the question, 'which group exhibits idealized citizenship'?

CONCLUSION

This chapter has argued that the rights project used discourses of good

black citizenship to produce a normative ideal of the black citizen that

represented idealized American citizenship. They defined a technique of

deracialized self that represented the normative idea of the good black citizen.

Deracializing strategies required disassociating ascribed attributes of race (skin

color) as both a determinate and casual factor in favor of achieved statuses

linked to idealized American citizenship. We can isolate two important

implications the rights projects outlined for why blacks should adopt deracialized

techniques. First, they challenged and undermined bad whites' basis of power

and authority. The rights project understood that integrating into the American

polity without fundamentally altering what counted as good citizenship because it

would have resulted in token forms of integration without providing blacks with

101

any real power or means of improvement. The second implication was that deracializing good citizenship and replacing it with universalistic claims of good American citizenship excluded citizens based on bad citizen practices, such as violence and discriminatory practices. In part, this was a radical critique on American democracy, which argued for the self-suppression of racial and class identities for the benefit of the larger civic polity.

Displacing race as a marker of good citizenship placed more responsibility on blacks to master an interrelated set of normative ethical practices - personal, social and civic. The rights project used discourses of good black citizenship to define a set of personal ethical practices, which included a way of walking, talking, dressing and dialect that represented blacks as good citizens. They also defined a set of social ethical practices to govern how blacks should have relations with whites, with other blacks, and the gendered relations between black men and women, as well as black men and white women. It was important for black to master personal ethical practices in order to have good relations with others. For blacks, practicing good manners and dignity minimized emotions while discussing and debating political matters with whites and other blacks. Regarding black social ethical relations with whites, good manners helped debunk black stereotypes that blacks were not ready or capable of engaging in civilized democratic discourse. Regarding black relations with other blacks, good manners and dignity distinguished the idea of good black citizenship from either black political extremes of the black nationalist and Uncle Tom. Since black men were the dominant representations of blacks in public, the onus was on them to

102

gain mastering over the domestic sphere, by caring for the family as the patriarch, because it helped align good black men with norms of American masculinity.

The third set of ethical practices, civic ethics, referred to how blacks were to master their personal and social ethical practices while represented blacks politically, which included demonstrating, making media appearances, voting, or running for/holding political office. While the black nationalist project defined a similar set of personal and social ethical practices, albeit to produce an idea of authentic black citizenship in hopes of creating black sovereignty and keeping whites away rather than racial and civic integration, they challenged the rights project most directly over what counted a civic ethical practices. For the rights project, good civic practices allowed blacks to establish the good black / bad white binary that induced federal legislation. The black nationalist project was more concerned about gaining control, governing, and caring for segregated black communities who found themselves in destitute situations. Therefore, demonstrating to invite federal legislation or protection, for the black nationalists, was not going to help the black community as much as building up independent black economic and political power. As I show in chapter 4, the differences in civic ethics represent the differences in political ideas, citizenship models, and strategies for producing racial equality.

Overall, how the rights project produced the normative idea of good black citizenship illustrated the importance of how social movements make symbolic citizenship claims, and the importance of culture in how we understand the power

103

of the dominant ideas of good citizenship. Prior ideas of good citizenship and how social movements make claims for citizenship have assumed that good citizenship was based on fulfilling a host of duties, such as paying taxes, joining the military or being publicly active, that do not consider the difficulty of how movements deal with racialized citizenship discourses. For the entire civil rights movement, the importance of existing idealized categories of good American citizenship, in the form of a discourse of rights and responsibilities, is how they structure and shaped the form and articulation of an alternative to racialized citizenship. Good citizenship represented ideas of mastering good civic practices as a technique of resistance. Resistance did not mean blacks 'speaking truth to power' or overcoming white hegemony. These ideas of resistance accompany modern assumptions of progress through resistance. Abandoning assumptions of progress, resistance is complex concept that cannot assume that the negation of an adversary, or other, equates to something better or something different. In the case of the rights project, blacks found more opportunities for social change when appealing to idealized American civic culture. Resistance meant emphasizing (or conforming to) idealized American values as much as it meant displacing race as the definitive marker of citizenship.

In this respect, we cannot hope to understand how the movement made demands or claims for new rights without analyzing how the movement sought to shape an ideal of good citizenship into good bodily practices. We cannot assume that abstract transformations in economic, political or organizational structures produced new types of citizens or improved conditions that made the civil rights

104

movement possible. The body was the site of resistance because the body is something that blacks could control. The movement shaped the body to fix interpretations and judgments about how to respond and carry on as good citizens and limit the extent they exhibited bad civic practices. Next, I analyze how the movement situated pedagogical techniques of good civic practice in a discourse of good black citizenship. As we will see, the movement trained activists how to exhibit good black normative ethics in relation to mastering bodily posture and affective responses that represented blacks as good citizens.

105

CHAPTER 3: BODY, PRACTICE AND AFFECTIVE RESPONSE

The rights project used discourses of good black citizenship to define a set of ethical practices that represented blacks as good citizens. Civil rights volunteers were responsible for a detailed care of the self, an art of mastering their bodily postures and affective response that associated blacks with idealized American citizenship. This chapter explains how the rights project used discourses of good black citizenship to organize their pedagogical techniques that trained civil rights activists how to master deracialized techniques of self. The pedagogical techniques shaped the body, as a political object, in both 'bodily ascetics' and external bodily regulation11. The rights project instructed blacks how to master external bodily postures and demeanors. Regulating the external body also included a discursive element of 'emotional work' that instructed the body how to react to and manage bodily pleasures. The internal discursive element, or 'bodily ascetics', was mastering the art of self-restraint in relation to violent and abusive adversaries. Through "role-playing", activists simulated interactions with bad whites in order to practice holding their temper. This meant learning to accept physical contact and verbal abuse without response. Training the body also fixed cognitive interpretation by teaching lessons on what should count as good citizenship. For instance, community centers intertwined ideas of a proper diet and a gendered ethic of taking care of the home (children and physical structure) with good citizenship. The citizenship schools used good handwriting lessons to shape a civic vocabulary to fashion a liberal, deracialized, rights orientated interpretation of political events. 11 See Turner (1996) for an extended discussion between the internal body and external body

106

I analyzed four movement programs, the rights projects "citizenship schools" and "role-playing" exercises, and SNCC's grassroots projects "leadership training", "freedom schools" and "community centers". Scholars have conducted little research on the movement's citizenship schools, community centers, and workshops. Most researchers either indicated that these programs existed (Lewis 1970), debated the merits of how effective they were at registering blacks to vote (Garrow 1986), explained them as illustrations of the overall organization of the movement (Morris 1984), or their importance for constructing the movement identity (Carson 1994, Eyerman and Jamison 1998). However, there exists no cultural-historical analysis that situates the programs within the histories of the larger political projects, or how and why the body became the target of the training. I organized the chapter by movement program rather than temporal sequence to highlight how each program taught personal, social and civic ethical practices. The data and materials for this chapter came from archival sources. Of special importance are the training manuals that outlined specific guidelines on what counted as good black civic practice. Next, I will provide a history and overview of how and why SCLC developed citizenship schools to replace voter registration drives. FROM VOTER REGISTRATION TO CITIZENSHIP SCHOOLS

After desegregating the buses in Montgomery, SCLC's initial citizenship drives form 1958 to 1961 focused on voter registration. Throughout 1959, the movement mobilized blacks based on the idea of challenging the restrictions on black voter registration. For example, the United Christian Movement, a local

107

affiliate of SCLC in Shreveport Louisiana, sent mass letters to black residents on a "citywide voter drive" urging blacks to "Please contact at least one person and urge him to register Thursday March 19" and that "we will all go to the Caddo Parrish Courthouse together" (EB 5-1). Baker reported the outcome of "250 persons crowded the Caddo Parish Courthouse in an attempt to register. Only 46 persons were interviewed that day, and only 15 registered" (EB 5-2). What we see here is two obstacles that SCLC encountered. First, they underestimated southern whites' ability to maintain restrictions on black voter registration. Second, SCLC recruited from the professional, or elite, segment of the black population, which limited the number of blacks who attempted to register at one time, making it difficult to mobilize a large numbers of protesters at a given geopolitical location.

The "Crusade for Citizenship" was the first post-Montgomery program that introduced the idea of training blacks to master civic ethical practices. The initial 1958 memorandum stated the Crusade intended "to set up voting clinics and workshops in local communities. There is a concrete job for you to do - giving out leaflets, or going with a friend to register, or visiting your neighbors, or helping people in your block learn how to fill out registration forms" (EB 5-1). It was the idea of setting up workshops and clinics that made the Crusade significant. The workshops and clinics represented a community wide or 'collective effort' to train blacks on the techniques of voting. It involved producing text (leaflets) to pressure reluctant blacks to register, as well as formal and informal instruction on correctly performing the actual ritual of voting.

108

Setting up workshops and clinics involved logistical and practical difficulties. They included questions of where the workshops and clinics should be set up, who should run them, and the existing literacy skills of prospective volunteers and students. Baker gave the following observations at the SCLC meeting in Columbia, South Carolina: "Some people most interested in trying to vote are those unable to read and write. Churches should have committees each Sunday to help these people. Other organizations such as masons, sororities, etc. should render assistance. 'Citizenship schools' to help people learn to read and write is the need of the day" (EB 5-1). Her recommendation was to use the black church and other voluntary organizations and to assist in the training. In part, this emphasized the collective effort in shaping good citizenship techniques. Yet, the importance of Bakers proposed modifications was the recognition that even with the legal right to vote, blacks would still have to disassociate black stereotypes from ideas of good black citizenship.

While SCLC was hesitant to implement Baker's reforms, workshops on nonviolence, which the Montgomery Movement used to prepare blacks on how to enter and ride the buses, continued to spread throughout the black south. They included the first nonviolent workshop held at Spellman College in Atlanta in July 1958 attended by 65 people hailing from 16 states (EB 5-2). September 23-24 in Jackson, Mississippi, James Lawson led workshops and discussion on nonviolence with about 25 ministers and black community leaders (EB 5-2). Lawson was the key figure who trained the Nashville students on nonviolent sit-in protest techniques that spread throughout the south in 1961. What separated

109

the workshops from the voter registration drive was the pedagogy and idea of

mastering bodily practices. Lawson's workshops combined lecture, discussion

and role-playing (see below). He believed blacks could master civic ethical

practices through repetition. Repetition was 'simulating' or rehearsing scenarios

that placed blacks in social situations that necessitated the mastery of bodily and

affective responses.

Baker gathered information from key authoritative sources on why adult

education was important for good black citizenship. The idea of educating and

training citizens was not acquiring literacy skills. Rather, it was to negate

associations of bad character attached to illiteracy. Baker initiated

correspondences with the Federal Department of Education, Health and Welfare

in October 1959 to obtain suggestions on the best way to incorporate adult

education into the citizenship schools. Edward W Brice, Specialist in

Fundamental and Literacy Education responded first by linking the lack of

education with bad civic practices,

There is some evidence of correlation between the educational level of people in the community and their participation in civic and public affairs. We believe there is some relationship between the educational level of the people in our predominately-southern states and their registration for voting purpose (EB 5-1).

Without the literacy skills and implicit socialization of educational institutions,

Brice viewed blacks as lacking necessary skills associated with good citizenship.

More important than linking illiteracy to poor civic practice, Brice used poor civic

skills to make a normative argument, "These under educated Americans become

hostile, bitter, socially inhibited, cheated in life, with a strong guilt sense over in

110

abilities and limitations. They are prejudiced, superstitious, unwanted" (EB 5-1).

The article mentions both white and blacks, but blacks were the subject of this

utterance. Bad black citizens were hostile and bitter. Good citizen pedagogy

required improving the ethical shortcomings signified with illiteracy and limited

educational accumulation.

Brice indicated to Baker that proper training could correct bad ethical

practices that represented bad citizenship. Brice suggested an educational

program that "would have as its keystone 'development through enlightenment'"

(EB 5-1). Development through enlightenment meant pedagogical techniques

"... to secure for our masses basic literacy such as: occupational literacy, social

literacy, civic literacy, personal literacy, which are so necessary for a survival and

extension in the world social order" (EB 5-1). Good citizenship required

mastering a set of ethical practices that carried over to all aspects of public life.

Personal ethical practices, such as good conduct and good character were

equally useful at the ballot box, in the streets or at work. Before blacks could

enter public life, they had to rid themselves of the practices that represented

black stereotypes. Baker's handwritten note on the back of letter from Brice

illustrated the movement's developing ideas of good citizen pedagogy,

Compared with 1927, residential illiteracy = more than now - 1959. No longer sheer illiteracy - broad view giving them tools with which to achieve fuller living. How can a process of change to draw upon resources of people_____as they attempt to satisfy_____. (EB 5-1)

Baker ceased defining good citizenship in relation to quantified ends (number of

voters, number of illiterate) in favor of the qualitatively defined set of standards.

Good black citizenship required teaching blacks the art of mastering personal,

111

social and ethical practices exhibited through the body as symbols of idealized citizenship.

Baker moved to intertwine the voter registration efforts with a broader program organized around the pedagogical techniques of good black citizenship. In SCLC's Report of the Executive Director12, Baker writes, "the framework for a program of crusade proportion has been provided. The question is, are we ready to add substance to this frame" (EB 5-2). Then, in the following report of the Executive Director13, Baker argued, "The real value of SCLC would be that more people would be equipped with the basic tools (reading and writing) and would then be ready for effective social action" (EB 5-2). It was not enough to register blacks to vote. Baker argued the movement should set up a citizenship school to instruct deracialized techniques of self, and increase the number of nonviolent workshops.14 More importantly for Baker, "the literacy project could provide a 'respectable' channel for helping the cause without too close identification with more militant aspects of the struggle" (EB 5-2). The citizenship schools would link the movement to an idealized method of creating social change.

Despite Bakers urging, it was not until SCLC incorporated the Highlander citizenship school model did the civil rights movement implement systematic programs on the art of mastering good civic practices. Three reasons explain why SCLC switched to citizenship school model in 1961. First, the NAACP already fought legal exclusions, like poll taxes, literacy tests and segregation, so

12 SCLC Report of the Executive Director May 16 to September 29, 1959 located in EB 5-2

13 SCLC Report of the Executive Director September 30 to December 8 1959 located in EB 5-2

14 The first citizenship schools were also referred to by 1961 by SCLC executive Wyatt Walker as leadership training (WF 29-12)

112

SCLC wanted to distinguish their political project. Second, the movement began to ask questions of how blacks would vote. Was the black vote susceptible to being 'bought' by whites? Did blacks know how to practice the ritual of voting, including reading the ballots and finding the polling places? Voter registration did not prepare blacks on how to be good citizens. Third, and most important, SCLC viewed rural blacks as lacking the necessary skills to be individual and independent black political agents. Part of the strategy to deracialize good citizenship was the idea that black and white Americans were part of a broader idealized American nationhood. It was to break individual identification with racial groups and shape and identity around an idea of good citizenship. Therefore, the cultural change that distinguished SCLC's political project from other black political projects accompanied a different set of questions about racial equality and social change. To expand deracializing political project required a mechanism for instructing ethical practices that represented blacks as idealized American citizens for blacks and whites to emulate. The Highlander Model

SCLC formed their citizenship schools only after they incorporated the Highlander Folk School model. Highlander had a history of involvement with civil rights activities. Rosa Parks attended the school, and Highlander proprietor Myles Horton attended the first SNCC meetings (EB 5-1). Baker noted that Highlander enjoyed past success in training "functional illiterate" blacks on citizenship practices. Septima Clark, the first citizenship schoolteacher on St. John's Island in South Carolina, focused on practical techniques that local

113

residents found pleasurable, like learning to write their name and filling out mail order forms, in order to encourage voter registration. As Baker was leaving SCLC to become an advisor to SNCC, SCLC obtained Highlander's citizenship files and programs (see Garrow 1986: 150-151, Glen 1988, Horton 1989).

The Highlander model is significant for influencing how the movement selected teachers, spatially and temporally organized the classes, and presented pedagogical material. It provided the skeletal outline that organized subsequent movement programs. In contrast to voter-registration drives, the Highlander model systematically defined a pedagogical process of teaching the art of good citizenship. For instance, Highlander's 1960 summer program defined its uses for "civic leaders who need to learn how to interest people in voting; also for prospective voters who need to learn how to register, how to mark a ballot, how to use a voting machine, how to vote wisely, and how to use new federal laws on civil rights" (SCLC 4-2). Located in the files of the SCLC are the files Highlander transferred to SCLC. Of special importance is the "Proposed Citizenship School Training Program" from December 1960. SCLC modeled their subsequent citizenship school proposals verbatim from this document. The only modifications were replacing the name "Highlander" with "SCLC" and differences in the set up of a "typical day".

The model specified how to develop authority figures (supervisors and teachers), the spatial organization, and the temporal workings of the school. Supervisors and teachers had different responsibilities. Supervisors were the main authority figures, responsible for managing each 'area' or aspect of the

114

school. The suggested ratio of supervisor to teacher was 1:10 (SCLC 4-2). They were responsible for knowing the intimate local cultural details, including its history of race relations, the form of the local municipal government, and willingness of the black population to get involved with the civil rights movement. Local cultural knowledge was information on the "best time of year, best time of day, best place for a meeting, what are local voting requirements, what makes registration difficult" (SCLC 4-2). The supervisor's knowledge guided each semi-autonomous citizenship school by defining: "(1) the different needs in different communities under their supervision, and (2) to judge the level of citizenship experience among the students, (3) to organize and administer schools and coordinate schools in the area and (4) to supervise teachers" (SCLC 4-2). Supervisors embodied local cultural knowledge, which provided the basis for judgment and evaluation of the teachers and students progress. While all citizenship schools worked with the same materials, supervisors had the authority to run the schools in relation to the distinctive needs of the local geopolitical community.

In contrast to supervisors, teachers were responsible for managing the classroom. Highlander recommended selecting teachers based on their knowledge of the local culture and positioning in social networks. "The teacher is a person living in the community. He may be a teacher by profession, a minister, a businessman or woman, a tradesman, a beautician, or any person qualified by demonstrated skill and responsibility and concern..." (SCLC 4-2). Teachers were selected in relation to their social standing in the local black community.

115

Selecting individuals who were already professionals ensured the presence of teachers who embodied a good black self. Since the teachers had more face-to-face contact with students, it was important that they exhibited idealized bodily mannerisms. Professional jobs accompany a style of dress and deracialized technique of self the rights project wanted blacks to emulate. The teachers' bodily presentation would have served as the 'hidden curriculum' that good citizenship was about more that literacy.

Highlander also provided a guide for "leadership training for a six week course one night a week" (SCLC 4-2) that supplied specific techniques on the training and development of leaders. For example, the first meeting made sure all teachers could answer the following questions: "Do you know the facts about your city, county or town? Organizations? Services for underprivileged and handicapped? "How can Negroes get these services?" Welfare - Health - Mental illness, orphan, blind, deaf, dumb". It was important to know the facts about each locale because not all southern locales had a municipal government. A mayor and common council headed some governments, while a mayor, commissioner, and common council ran others. Subsequent voter registration and protest strategy differed depending on government structure. The organizations of interest were primarily the NAACP, and their relation with (if any) local civil rights groups. SCLC judged the desirability of local knowledge in relation to care the body, especially medical and welfare services that could provide immediate improvements. The accumulation and mastery of local knowledge defined the quality of each local leader, supervisor and teacher.

116

Highlander suggested carefully managing the spatial configurations and daily temporal rhythms to limit tensions and hierarchies within the classroom. Ideally, classes should be between 25-35 students. The spatial configurations of the classroom organized bodies in a non-hierarchical way. Although teachers enjoyed some flexibility on how they tailored good citizenship pedagogy to the students' capabilities, they were restricted from lecturing. Adult students experienced the role of student, signifying child, as demeaning - especially if teachers were younger - and were prone to drop out. Classes should focus on 'hands on' and practical assignments - like name writing and filling out applications. Therefore, the emphasis of group participation, in particular, meant not ordering bodies in the classroom with teachers lecturing in front of a class separated into neat vertical rows. In contrast, group participation meant dividing students "into small groups... to discuss their special problems and to have individual and group instruction on how to deal with them in local citizenship classes" (SCLC 4-2). The organization of bodies into small groups encouraged students to identify local problems, while the schools worked on instructing on how interpret their perceptions and provide the 'right' solutions to their problems.

Highlander structured the temporal organization of each day to strengthen collective bonds and fashion a good black identity. Highlander suggested dividing the day between formal instruction in the morning and afternoon, and informal instruction at night. Students were expected to attend both formal classes and informal sessions. The first classes, or "general sessions" should take place between 9-10:30 am. The formal sections taught good handwriting,

117

good listening and speaking skills (see below). Late night sessions between 8-10 pm were for "group singing, informal talk and recreation" (SCLC 4-2). This is when students learned freedom songs, such as "We Shall Overcome". The body ties together the relationship between time and space. While the two sessions instructed techniques of deracialized self, it was important for students to develop a bodily rhythm that put all students 'on the same page'. For example, participation in mass protest required singing in unison and marching at a controlled pace. The movement used singing and marching to discipline the body when confronting violent whites. It ensured that the protests appeared orderly and nonviolent, which insulated the movement from the press dismissing the protests as amateurish (see below).

SCLC made three adjustments to the Highlander model. The first two changes were made in relation to administering the pedagogy - who should ideally teach the classes, and how to incorporate workshops. SCLC saw the selection of the right teachers (or leaders) that represented good black citizens as "prime importance to the overall effectiveness of the program" (SCLC 4-2). The right leaders referred to activists who practiced techniques of good black self that served as a model for students to emulate. SCLC trained teachers at their Dorchester training center in Mcintosh, Georgia. After completing the training, which took about a week, teachers returned to their communities and set up the schools. The schools help create new SCLC chapters, whose students "definitely knew they were part of SCLC" (quoted in Morris 1984: 238). Second was the emphasis on incorporating workshops. "Demonstrations of actual

118

teaching situations will enable the teacher - trainee to solve real problems. Available are refresher courses which the teacher may attend for advanced training" (SCLC 4-2). Since 'real life' situations provided the substance for the workshops, SCLC considered them more practical and desirable than theoretical discussions on the pros and cons of nonviolence and good manners.

SCLC made a third change in relation to rhythms of southern life. SCLC "Proposed Strategy for Citizenship School Program 1961" (SCLC 4-2) structured the temporal organization around a 12-month calendar. SCLC organized the citizenship training based on the school calendar when college students were attending class and when farmers planted and picked their crops. Recruitment was based July through September. Since recruitment required quantitatively the most labor, the movement could take advantage of college and high school students and teachers, who were on summer break. Supervisors and teaches prepped and trained October through December, when colleges and secondary schools were in session, and the farmers picked cotton. SCLC held the schools and refresher courses in the winter months, January through March, when rural blacks would not have worked the farms. Schools concentrated on political organization April through June to prepare for summer recruitment. Thus, SCLC attempted to organize their activities around a southern cultural rhythm of colleges (future teachers) and the rural agricultural economy.

We can observe SCLC's shift in emphasis from voter registration to incorporating the training of body/mind in relation to how SCLC presented the citizenship program to the public. In the 1961 SCLC Report to the director,

119

Walker described the citizenship schools as instructing "The whole areas of good

citizenship is explored to equip every person that he might move with confidence

and assurance in the coming integrated society we seek" (WF 29-12). The

SCLC pamphlet "Citizen Education Program" defined the purpose of the

citizenship schools as teaching ethical practices of good citizenship. The

citizenship schools:

They help students to pass literacy tests for voting. But they also give an all-around education in community development which included housing, recreation, health and improved home life. Specific subjects include filing income tax forms, understanding of tax-supported resources such as water testing for wells, aid to handicap children, public health facilities, how government is run, social security etc. (CC 3-2)

The idea of instructing to how to care for the home and the family was a rejection

that the family operated autonomously from the local southern culture. SCLC

emphasized improving a set of ethical bodily practices including the body and

physical environment (housing), body and recreation (leisure) body and health,

and body and improved home life (family). Water testing for wells improved the

quality of water ingested. Southern rural areas may have had no water or poor

water quality. Visually, poor water is of yellowish or brownish tint.

Improvements to these immediate body-society relations changed how the

general southern black populace interpreted their expectations of the self, the

civil rights movement, and the county/state/federal government. A 'clean' and

'healthy' environment produced good black citizens.

In sum, the adoption of the citizenship schools for shaping personal, social

and civic ethical practices was a process that developed unevenly from the end

of the Montgomery movement until 1961. The rights project was most active

120

where citizenship schools and workshops existed. 1958-1961 saw little action from the SCLC, which focused on mass voting drives but no citizenship pedagogy. However, student involvement thrived, in part, because of their participation in the nonviolent workshops and Highlander citizenship schools. SNCC organized the sit-ins, and CORE organized the "Freedom Rides". By 1961, SCLC formed citizenship schools after the highlander model to instruct techniques of good black self to a geographically and culturally diverse black populace. Next, I illustrate the relationship techniques of good black self and the body. THE CITIZENSHIP SCHOOLS

We cannot judge the citizenship schools success or merit based on how many or how few blacks SCLC registered to vote. For instance, SCLC's "Summary of Citizenship Schools" from October 25 1962 reported 2910 persons were trained in a 5- day workshop and 114 persons trained in a refresher course. There were 263 classes, 2330 number of attendees, and 2464 registered black voters through the classes. Citizenship school trainees registered 13,266 blacks through community drives and voter canvassing (SCLC 4-2). By 1964, SCLC reported 225 active voter registration groups, 560 inactive voter registration groups, 216 SCLC affiliates, 219 active adult citizenship school classes (average 15 students each), 1,060 inactive (temporarily) adult citizenship school classes (trained 12,271 students) (WF 27-18). Whether or not these numbers represent 'progress' because of the complexity of restrictions on black voter registration, or 'failure' because these numbers are small in relation to the number of blacks

121

living the south is a mute point. The movement programs existed for the purpose of training blacks on how to be good citizens. They represented a broader cultural change and deracializing strategy to break individual identification with racial groups, and attach an identity with idealized American nationhood.

I used SCLC's "citizenship workbook" and other pedagogy materials to analyze how they instructed they body on personal, social and civic ethical practices. The workbook repeated the same information found in all the pamphlets noting its work on "learning to read and write an all-around education in community development which includes housing, recreation, health and improved home life. Specific subjects are emphasized such as safe driving, social security, cooperatives, the income tax..." (CC 3-2, WF 29-13). The five-day organization represented how the schools taught 'simple' bodily postures first (good handwriting) and 'complex' bodily practices involving mastering emotions last (nonviolence). Once students were introduced to the art of good citizenship, they were given sample tasks like "Planning a Voter Registration Campaign" and worked together on how to plan a block party, or how to fill out a sample page of voter education spread sheet. Civic Vocabulary

The citizenship schools used bodily training to fix a normative style of interpretation and understanding of good citizenship and racial injustice. Specifically, good citizenship pedagogy shaped the body to master good handwriting, good manners, and nonviolent practices. Good handwriting meant learning how to hold a pen/pencil, writing in a straight line with a consistent

122

height. Samples in the book recommend practicing on paper with lines to master

this art. Good handwriting equated to good citizenship, "It is important to have a

handwriting that others can read. A strong, sure handwriting shows that you are

a strong person. All of our first class citizens should have a first class

handwriting" (CC 3-2, WF 29-13). Good handwriting signified the accumulation

of knowledge. Good black citizens exhibited good handwriting to project a strong

and confident image. In addition, exhibiting good handwriting skills embodied

cultural ideals of cleanliness and goodness. Bad handwriting embodied bad

cultural ideals of sloppy and unkempt. Good black citizens mastered the art of

handwriting as a good civic practice.

Practicing good handwriting allowed for broader civic participation. The

workbook stated:

As you improve your writing, new worlds of pleasure will open and old fears will pass away. You will be able to write to your newspaper and express your views on the events of your community. You can write your congressmen or senator to help him to vote for things that will help our people, and you will not be shy about filling out job application blanks, signing your name to your checks or registering to vote (CC3-2, WF 29-13)

On the one hand, good handwriting produced texts that were more than legible.

Legible handwriting was important when engaging with cultural and political

authority figures. On the other hand, mastering good handwriting fashioned a

'second reading' or implicit reading for the reader that represented blacks as

good citizens. It distinguished them from the letters written with bad handwriting.

The second reading of a letter in bad penmanship ranged from a letter of

123

complaint, with no rational argument, to a letter from a citizen who lacked self-mastery and did not fully comprehend the argument.

Blacks could practice good handwriting in a number of ways. One way was in relation to pleasures of consumption and public life, "How to Write my name and Address on a Mail order blank. Writing a friendly letter (w/practice lesson) - heading, greeting, body, closing, signature. How to fill out a Money order blank" - practice money order (CC 3-2, WF 29-13)." In order to make the sessions pleasurable, the workbook suggested mastering immediate practices in relation to everyday, like purchasing items through the mail. It gave blacks access to things like a Sears Roebuck catalog that skirted issues of segregated shopping areas. It also allowed for communication between friends and relatives. This was important because much of the rural black south did not have electricity or phones. If they did have phones, they could not afford the longdistance telephone charges. Thus, linking good handwriting with consumption and associational practices provided a pleasurable component that drew in adult students.

Practicing good handwriting by constructing words, sentences and

narratives around significations of good civic practices, idealized American civic

culture, and the civil rights movement, expanded civic vocabulary. For instance,

one task stated:

Make words out of the alphabet, then use them in sentences and stories

a attorney - amendments - abridged - alderman

c Chatham - congressional - county - circuit - citizen - constitution

e exercises - election - elect - executive - electorate

r representatives - rebellion - register - resident - regulation

w whites - workshop - world - white house (CC 3-2, WF 29-13)

124

Practicing good penmanship allowed for the construction of a good civic vocabulary. An increased civic vocabulary increased the understanding and interpretation of why and how to make claims for rights. Students did not learn vocabulary and sentence structure by learning words like 'mat', 'pat', 'sat', 'cat', like kindergarten reading exercises. Students mastered a civic vocabulary by linking "amendments", "congressional" "election" "register" and "whites" to understand how bad whites denied blacks the right to vote. Mastering an expanded civic vocabulary projected the image of strong and confident black citizens making rights claims with conviction and determination. A good civic vocabulary limited the amount of frustration, confusion, resentment and fear experienced when bad whites attempted to explain to them why they could not register to vote and the legality of their protest techniques.

Once blacks expanded their civic vocabulary, they could construct stories in relation to specific events in the civil rights movement. The workbooks provided the following list of word to organize the movement's collective memory, "Use some of the above words to make a story: state, train, on rain, register, sit in, it, Etta, station, strain, tag, rotten, get, ten, ton, treat, stranger" (CC 3-2, WF 29-13). Blacks practiced good handwriting when constructing narratives to recount and recollect past protest. The citizenship schools supplied the words to guide blacks to interpret the civil rights movement as a struggle for rights and civic inclusion. The narratives could emphasize or deemphasize key characters depending on each local culture. Some narrative could be heroic and emphasis the role of blacks in desegregating "trains" or buses. Other narratives could

125

emphasize the role of a repressive state. Thus, the movement defined the content and style of writing the narrative as a good personal ethical practice.

A supplemental SCLC pedagogy handout "Helpful Hints in Teaching Citizenship Classes" also suggested paying special attention to the pronunciation of words used in demonstrations: "Pronounce and define the following words. Make sentences from each. Larceny, Commissioner, Register, Congressman, Bonafide, Affidavit, Signature, Elector, Residence, Applicant" (CC 3-2). Fixing a style of pronunciation to black citizenship signified an articulate and well-mannered black citizenry. Ensuring the pronunciation of key words to use when attempting to register deracialized the association intelligence with race. Whites used the improper pronunciation of words as an indication that blacks did not deserve rights. How blacks spoke the words were just as important and knowing what the words meant. Good Manners

Learning good manners meant mastering social ethical practices in relations to others. Specifically, it meant mastering the role of good listener and good speaker, "When other people are talking, I listen. Harry likes me to listen when he talks. She likes me to listen when she talks. One has good manners if he listens when others talk. When I talk I want other people to hear me" (CC 3-2, WF 29-13). The good listener shaped their body to be attentive. A good listener looked the speaker in the eye when the speaker spoke. A bad listener shook his/her head or looked away while another spoke. Bad listeners interrupt the

126

others thought. Good manners required mastering bodily and verbal forms of

communication.

Mastering good manners also required learning a style of speaking based

on what counted as appropriate content for discussion and how not to sound

domineering. When speaking with another, the good citizen does not want to

appear trite or boring, but also does not want to appear overly confidant like a

braggart or 'know it all'. The workbook indicated how good citizens exhibit good

manners:

I talk about things my friends are interested in. I speak so that everyone can understand me. It is not polite to do all the talking. Everyone likes to talk some... My friends like to tell me about their jobs. They like me to discuss their community problems with me. I like to tell them about by [sic] job and my children. She discusses with her friends the ways they can share in the running of their city... When your friend is talking, do not interrupt. It is not polite to interrupt. Everyone likes people who listen when he talks (CC 3-2, WF 29-13).

Good manners meant mastering the proper pronunciation and pace (not too fast,

no too slow) when talking. Good citizens are articulate. The substance of good

mannered conversations meant discussing personal matters Gobs, family) that

produced the friendship bonds that allows for broader discussion of political

matters. A good mannered conversation was a strategy to talk about matters of

public concern in a respectful and civil way. It ensured that good citizens

mastered their emotions in times of disagreement. Mastering affective response

through techniques of good manners meant exhibiting a rational and convincing

demeanor when debating with others who were not of like mind.

The art of mastering good manners specifically meant mastering the art of

being polite. The workbook suggested practicing the follow lesson on politeness:

127

Introduce a new friend to your other friends. When you introduce a man to a woman, call the woman's first name. When you introduce a younger person to an older person, call the older person's name first... Tell something about the new friend you are introducing. Tell your old friends something about the new friend. Say the names of the person clearly. Be polite and introduce your friends (CC 3-2, WF 29-13).

Politeness was a way to establish a favorable impression when encountering

someone new, and introducing new people to one another for the first time.

Politeness did not just announce ones name but also defined the status of each

actor. As we can see from the example, politeness was gendered (man/women)

and generational (man/boy) in the order of introduction and acknowledgement.

Politeness insured that inter-group relations, specifically black-white interactions,

would be civil and cordial to limit racial tensions. Good manners also insured

cordial intra-group or black-black relations, which was important for networking,

organizing and mobilizing southern black communities. For black attendees,

practicing good manners meant mastering their emotional responses in times of

disagreement. By mastering their affective responses, blacks exhibited a rational

and convincing demeanor when debating with others who were not of like mind.

Nonviolence and Civic Ethical Practices

Nonviolence was a civic ethical practice all movement activists had to

master. SCLC forbade all forms of violence within the social space of the

citizenship schools. One explicit rule was "Shooting firearms and exploding

fireworks are not permitted on the centers grounds" (CC 3-2, WF 29-13).

Restrictions like these were to encourage blacks to live without guns. A common

practice for southern rural blacks was to carry guns for protection against

lynching. In contrast to role-playing, where blacks participated in practice runs to

128

test ones ability to master their emotions (see below), the citizenship schools focused on the whys of nonviolence. For instance, in a section titled the "Power of Nonviolence", the text indicated, "When we don't fight back, they are forced to think about why we don't. This is the beginning of understanding, understanding is the stepping stone to true brotherhood" (CC 3-2, WF 29-13). Practicing nonviolence was a deracializing strategy that forced bad whites to confront their own actions and behaviors. The workbook suggested practicing nonviolent tasks by learning and recounting how Gandhi and the Montgomery Movement used nonviolence through a series of discussion questions. Discussion questions were,

1. What would happen in your town if minority groups used violent racist means to solve their problems?

2. What happens when nothing is done to overcome community problems?

3. How can non-violence be used in your community? (CC 3-2, WF 29-13)

Discussion groups provided the space to identity both the benefits of nonviolence

as well as the consequences of violence. The idea was to bracket out alternative

strategies that suggested violence as the preferred technique of resistance. If

blacks used violence, whites would retaliate with violence and likely produce

genocide. Violence does not solve underlying racial problems in the community.

In sum, the citizenship schools illustrated how the movement shaped the

body to exhibit good civic practices by practicing good handwriting to develop a

civic vocabulary and mastering the art of good manners. Good black citizens

acquired the knowledge of what counted as good citizenship at the same time

they mastered bodily postures. However, the citizenship schools were only one

129

aspect of shaping good bodily practices. Before blacks could participate in public protest, they were required to go through further training that simulated situations that tested blacks mastering of their bodies and emotions. MOVEMENT WORKSHOPS: THE BODY AND ROLE-PLAYING

An important pedagogical technique that cut across the rights and grassroots projects' programs was the workshop. Activists completed workshops before desegregating buses, staging sit-ins, and marching in Albany, Birmingham and Selma15. Workshops differed from citizenship school participatory discussion because they deemphasized discussion in favor of "role-playing". Role-playing was the simulation of social situations involving blacks and bad whites to provide opportunities for blacks to practice mastery of bodily conduct and affective response. The rights and grassroots project used discourses of good black citizenship to organize role-playing instructed and regulated the style, conduct and responses in relation to bad citizenship. Repetitive simulation fixed civic ethical practices to and stabilized an idea of the good black citizen. While scholars have been aware of the workshops, very little historical evidence exists as to their exact form. To illustrate how the workshops functioned, I use a book titled Manual for Direct Action written by civil rights activists Martin Oppenheimer and George Lakey, and forward by Bayard Rustin. Published in 1965, it was a compilation and history of how to engage in direct action, including how to set up the role-playing techniques, how to manage the press, and how ensure bodily

15 King noted that when asking for volunteers during the Birmingham movement, "Mindful of the difficulties involved, we decided to undertake a process of self-purification. We began a series of workshops on nonviolence, and we repeatedly asked ourselves: 'Are you able to accept blows without retaliating?' 'Are you able to endure the ordeal of jail?'"(King 1964: 80).

130

safety when being arrested. The subject of the manual is the history civil rights movement. The authors focused on what the movement did before, and how they did it, in order to encourage more volunteers to join the movement. I describe the manual as a compilation because the authors were compiling data from their experiences with Mississippi Freedom Summer, that reprints, or represents, the nonviolent teachings and workshops of Lawson and SCLC, and other manuals the movement referenced when developing these pedagogical technique.

Role-playing prepared the body for public protest. Sample Scenarios for role-playing included: how good citizens dealt with landlords if they were evicted, how they approach their congressmen, what to do if a barbershop refused to cut black hair, how to practice good manners in court, how to protect the body during a sit-in, how to hold cordial committee meetings, how to ensure an orderly picket line, and how to avoid having a march transform into a riot (Oppenheimer and Lakey 1965: 67-72). Role-playing allowed activists "to practice skills. Participants, by taking on various roles, learn how to behave in different situations. They get an idea of what to expect and how to react in the best way... Mistakes are less likely later on" (Oppenheimer and Lakey 1965: 64). It was important to master affective response in different contexts because the body can adapt to repetitive training. Although techniques can condition the body to master emotional outbursts and exhibit good postures in a march to a courthouse, it does not mean activists can apply this to a situation of overt police violence. Some activists may exhibit self-restraint to shouts of 'nigger' but not to

131

police batons, or vice versa. It was important to make mistakes and identify ones limits in the simulations before engaging real demonstrations. Role-playing allowed civil rights volunteers to identify their weaknesses ahead of time.

Civil rights volunteers used role-playing simulations to overcome their 'weaknesses' and 'limitations'. One technique built into role-playing to practice affective mastery was taking on the role of other, "to understand your opponent. By playing opponents' roles, the worker gets to feel how the opponent thinks and feels. This will be of tremendous value in the real situation, because the worker will be better able to make judgments as to possible reactions to various tactics" (Oppenheimer and Lakey 1965: 64). Training the body in both the protagonist and antagonist roles linked the embodied good black self with the bad white other. For blacks, playing the role of 'activists' fixed good civic tactical and strategic judgments through exhibiting self-mastery in relation to typical bad white response. Playing the role of the bad white allowed civil rights volunteers to embody the perceptions and judgments of bad whites. It provided a better understanding of why bad whites perceive their actions to be just. One could begin preparing or bracing the self in advance knowing what was coming. Knowing how the other perceives and responds to a situation reinforces why it is necessary to counter with good civic practices, thereby restricting the number of possible responses the body can perceive as a desirable response.

Role-playing taught volunteers how to manage their emotions. The problem of emotions was the immediate management (e.g. during the protest) as

132

well as the emotional stability over time. Role-playing provided and outlet for the

right way to:

Get rid of tensions. It is important, when in action, to keep tensions under control... People 'crack' under strain and 'blow up.' After a while, some begin to suffer the equivalent of 'battle fatigue.' Obviously this presents a real danger if it takes place in an actual situation. In the workshop the opportunity is created to get rid of tensions before the action (Oppenheimer and Lakey 1965: 54).

Role-playing sought to guard against long-term emotional and bodily fatigue.

The tired body, or the physically beaten body, was susceptible to mistakes and

jeopardizing affective self-mastery. Emotional fatigue, or being 'burnt out', also

increased the possibility of mistakes, loss of interest, and wavering commitment

to the movement. Therefore, role-playing was advantageous for both the novice

and seasoned veteran civil rights workers. For the novice, it was a technique to

keep tensions resulting from anger, outrage and resentment from slipping to

bodily practices. For the civil rights veteran, it was a way to express tensions, by

either playing the role of the bad whites, expelling the emotional outbursts in

scripted yelling and/or hitting, or by reinforcing the commitment to good black

citizenship through the repetition of affective control practices.

Role-playing required actors performing the roles of bad whites and good

blacks, as well as an audience to judge and interpret the simulation. The

audiences' role was to judge and confirm if activists were ready to participate in a

demonstration, as indicated by the participants' mastery over their affective

responses. However, members of the audience also had to exhibit self-discipline

when making observations. Effective role-playing "requires an audience as well

as participants, but the audience must be cautioned not to laugh or react. They

133

are the observers and will be asked to evaluate and comment after the 'scenario' is concluded" (Oppenheimer and Lakey 1965: 65).
