Audience members were responsible for managing their conduct when observing so as make the simulation seem 'more real'. Audiences must control affective responses such as laughter, crying or outrage. They also must refrain from exhibiting demeanors that made them appear condescending or demeaning. That is, audiences must appear objective to confirm the seriousness of the simulation, as well as the objectivity of the interpretation of whether or not the activist is ready for real public demonstrations. Thus, role-playing provided an opportunity to practice self-mastery over affective response in three roles - the volunteer, the bad white, and the audience. Each role embodied a different perspective of the situation, yet required affective and bodily self-mastery for a successful performance. Good Bodily Practices in Public Demonstrations and the Media

Mastering affective response and exhibiting good bodily conduct was necessary for executing a proper demonstration. The manual suggested marching, parading, picketing, and vigils as basic techniques of civil disobedience. Volunteers were advised to exhibit deracialized techniques of self while demonstrating for rights. In order to prevent opponents from discrediting the march as "disorderly and violent", volunteers should "have silence, or singing in unison" (Oppenheimer and Lakey 1965: 74). This disciplining technique made the group act as one, thereby reducing the chances of any one individual acting out.

134

A variation of the march is the picket line. Unlike a march, picket lines are more localized, usually with a specific grievance in mind. The manual suggests that individuals participating in the picket line appear neat and orderly at all times. An orderly picket line meant assembling the volunteers "someplace other than the place where the picket line will be, then go to the place in a group" (Oppenheimer and Lakey 1965: 75). This prevented activists from loitering. Loitering signified lack of purpose and focus. Once assembled, it was important to "avoid unnecessary scurrying about" (Oppenheimer and Lakey 1965: 75). Bodies should remain in the designated geographical space to project an image of purposeful political action. It also meant exhibiting the proper postures when picketing. "Expect participants to walk erectly and not slouch, call out, laugh loudly, or use profanity; smoking may be ruled out in some situations" (Oppenheimer and Lakey 1965: 75). Picketers should exhibit good bodily postures that associated the demonstration with good citizenship. They should limit bad civic bodily practices of slouching, improper language and volume of speaking, that indicates bad citizenship.

Conducting a vigil provided its own set of challenges. Since they required standing still for a long duration, vigils could be enduring on the body. However, the manual noted that vigils resonated with American ideals of Christianity. "In a culture like ours where religion is held in high esteem, a vigil is sometimes more effective than picketing; however, it is slightly more wearying and requires more self- and group-discipline" (Oppenheimer and Lakey 1965: 74). Vigils, therefore, were effective when used at the proper time, with the proper people, and in the

135

right space. Experienced civil rights workers who previously illustrated the

capability of self-mastery and endurance were best suited to partake in vigils.

Since the vigil attempts symbolic resonance with idealized American virtues of

Christianity, its use should be restricted to areas that emphasized Christian

ethics.

Exhibiting good black civic practice meant mastering a style of conduct in

relation with the media. Before giving a press conference, the movement

advised to:

Make your charges believable... Watch your language. Use English that makes sense to the community in which you are working. Watch your appearance. Appearance is a communicating device. You cannot expect people to raise their own standards of cleanliness, or look up to you as a leader, if you act like a slob. The civil rights worker gives up some of his private rights when he joins the movement (Oppenheimer and Lakey 1965: 52-53).

Mastering deracialized techniques of self helped blacks while making media

appearances. Activists appearing on television or radio should speak clearly, in

'proper' English, and be clean and well dressed. Although some activists may

resist the regulation of self-presentation, the manual notes that civil rights

workers forfeit some of their rights of free choice when joining the movement.

The movement expected all civil rights volunteers to conform to good bodily

practices. Volunteers who did not, or could not master good black civic

practices, were not allowed to participate in civil rights activities and protest.

Bodies and Police Beatings

Placing the body in public opened it up to physical punishment. Blacks

had to train their bodies how to master their affective response in relation to

136

police brutality. Since the police embodied the state's legitimate use of violence, civil rights protesters had to be ready for the police use 'weapons'. Police used tear gas as a favored police technique for dispersing crowds. The manual offers a series of suggestions of how to protect the body to limit the chance of an emotional outburst. If the group is tear-gassed, "Retreat in an orderly fashion from the scene... Clothing permeated with fumes should be changed. Persons affected by gas attack should face into the wind (assuming there is no further gas) and/or wash eyes and face in water (stick your head in a bucketful, if possible)" (Oppenheimer and Lakey 1965: 91). Tear gas affected the visual capacity of the body. It burns the eyes, causing some disorientation as to what is going on. Since the body's first response when getting something in its eye is to attempt to rub it out, volunteers should practice not touching their eyes. Rubbing the eyes after being tear-gassed will make it worse. Knowing the correct way to respond to tear gas prevented panic and other affective outburst. Good black citizens' exhibited good civic practices at all times during a protest.

Besides tear gas, civil rights activists also faced physical violence. In contrast to the police shooting tear gas into a crowd, police violence such as direct blows from police nightsticks, bats or fist, happens in close spatial proximity. There is also the greater likelihood that activists will interpret intimate police violence personally, therefore, placing more responsibility on the volunteer to master affective response. The manual relays a lesson from James Lawson. Lawson said that when meeting physical attack, "There are two nonviolent reactions to a physical attack. One is to stand up to it and try to make eye

137

contact with the attackers; the other is to fall down and cover up" (Oppenheimer

and Lakey 1965: 93). Lawson suggested that civil rights activists should follow

the second technique of covering up and protecting the body when attacked.

Covering up:

It is intended to protect the most vital parts of the body, through adopting a crouching position with hands over the head and ears, while lying on the ground. If a buddy is undergoing severe attack, and is on the ground, it is often wise to place yourself between the attackers and the victim by means of falling over the victim, face down, approximating the position of a person doing a 'push-up' on the 'up' part, but keeping your face down and tucked into your chest (Oppenheimer and Lakey 1965: 93)

Covering up was a technique of absorbing physical blows to limit the amount of

physical punishment. Knowing how to take and absorb physical punishment

limits the damage and blunts the pain. Learning how to take physical

punishment, to lesson the pain, makes it easier to master self-restraint. Rather

than attack the police to make them stop, the manual suggested individuals

situate their body in between that of the victim and the attacker. Absorbing

physical punishment for a friend, sacrificing ones body, is a self-less act. The act

of sacrificing ones body for ideals of nonviolence strengthens bonds between

activists, distinguishing activists as heroic.

Limiting the amount of physical punishment the body absorbs also

required preparing for the best way to prepare for arrest and going to jail.

Specifically, it meant clothing the body in a way that provided padding and

protection from police physical assault:

Wear loose clothing in order not to be choked when dragged. Wear decent, tough clothing, but not your best. If you expect to be jailed, wear two sets of underclothes so that you can wear one set while washing the

138

other. This is also helpful padding if you are dragged about the police. An extra pair of socks also helps. Wear a sweater or trench coat - cells get cold, and the coat will help cover your leg or serve as a pillow. Take a bunch of kleenex or toilet paper in case that commodity is not available right away (Oppenheimer and Lakey 1965: 109).

Since the civil rights movement used mass arrest to fill the jails, and southern

police were eager to arrest, civil rights activists expected to go to jail. The

manual recommended layering clothes for protection, but not to the extent, that it

will affect an individual's personal appearance. Activists should not sacrifice how

they presented the body for the sake of physical protection.

Once in prison, the civil rights movement expected protesters to exhibit

good social ethical practices in relation to prison guards and other prisoners.

The manual reprinted suggested rules for prison from an SCLC pamphlet

"Handbook for Freedom Army Recruits" that instructed civil rights activists on

how to be a good prisoner. They included:

Always act and speak with honesty. Cooperate with prison officials and don't break prison rules unless are against dignity and self-respect or our principles. Do all jobs to the best of your ability. Have regard for fellow prisoners and do not be selfish. Do nothing to demoralize your fellow prisoners. Take responsibility for keeping everyone in good spirits. Do not take part in teasing or conversation that might hurt feelings or start a fight (Oppenheimer and Lakey 1965: 113).

Practicing techniques of good black self did not end when locked behind bars.

Good black citizens mastered their bodily postures and affective states in

differing, hostile and unpleasant situations. Being a good prisoner represented

unjust imprisonment. Therefore, imprisoned civil rights workers were not to

exhibit any behaviors that artificially distinguished them from other prisoners.

Exhibiting good prisoner behavior was also a matter of personal safety behind

139

bars. Bad behavior could initiate violence between civil rights workers and other

prisoners, or lead to increased police repression towards jailed civil rights

workers and/or other inmates.

SNCC's GRASSROOTS POLITICAL PROJECT AND LEADERSHIP TRAINING

SNCC used discourses of good black citizenship to develop training

guidelines to shape a black political agent capable of autonomous leadership.

The idea behind SNCC's grassroots project was to organize black communities

into independent cells capable of political autonomy. In their pamphlets, SNCC

described how they drew from a grassroots project to organize black

communities,

"SNCC's grassroots approach is designed to .... Build indigenous, trained leadership... on college and high school campuses, and in local communities... SNCC workers have organized and guided local protest movements which are never identified as SNCC projects. This is part of its program of developing, building and strengthening indigenous leadership"16

Ideally, each cell directed their political activities at the local geopolitical

community, but could be called on to support and assist national demonstrations,

like sit-ins or marches. Political authority was spread horizontally between cells,

rather than in a vertically or bureaucratically. SNCC's grassroots project differed

somewhat than SCLC's deracializing project because of 1) SNCC emphasis on

building political communities from the 'ground up', and 2) the different black

population SNCC worked with, rural blacks versus urban blacks, that

accompanied a different set of questions and concerns. In contrast to SCLC's

hierarchal organizing approached, modeled after the black church, SNCC

16 SAV Box 36 "SNCC" pamphlet from 1963

140

purposely did not place field organizers in positions of authority. SNCC leaders assisted rural blacks on how to organize, rather than leading the organization. Because of the difference in organizing strategies, SNCC's ability to mobilize southern blacks was based on how well they worked with existing black groups. Indeed, SNCC could not have organized mass protests in Albany, Georgia or throughout Mississippi without the help of local NAACP chapters. Because of the differences in working with urban versus rural black populations, SNCC focused more on organizing political meetings and voter registration than establishing formal citizenship schools. Rather than encourage rural blacks to enter citizenship schools, SNCC allowed them to decide if they were interested in citizenship schools. Rural blacks had a different set of concerns - like physical safety from Klan violence, and fair trade on crops - than urban blacks who were more likely to have worked industrial jobs and dealt with white citizens' councils.

Despite the differences in political projects, SNCC and SCLC used discourses of good black citizenship to instruct deracialized techniques of self. What was different was that SNCC asked a different set of questions, like the best way to enter an unfamiliar black community, and the best way to run a political meeting. Because organizing rural black communities meant a decrease in surveillance techniques to reinforce nonviolent practices, the responsibility to practice nonviolence was placed on individual field workers. Therefore, questions of how to master various levels of ascetic bodily practices in relation to nonviolence also circulated amongst SNCC workers. Thus, SNCC's training programs had the dual emphasis of shaping ethical civic practices as well as

141

reproducing their membership ranks. Nevertheless, they fashioned a style of conduct begetting of good citizens to enter a local community, as well as how to interact with the locals once in the community. How to Enter an Unfamiliar Black Community

The SNCC training booklet, prepared by Charles Sherrod, simply entitled "Non-Violence" (EB 6-14) first outlined how field workers should enter an unfamiliar local black community. Specifically, it focused on how to identify and interpret the population - who to approach and how to do it. The proper way, meaning safest and most effective, to enter a community required the collection of 'macro-information' that provided 'objective' knowledge of the population. That is, knowledge of a local community that indicated how easy or difficult it would be for SNCC to enter. When entering a new community, volunteers should first identify, if any, local civil rights organizations that "have similar purposes" as well as which ones are "antagonistic". In contrast to SCLC, SNCC had to work with groups who shared similar goals of voter registration. Once SNCC workers identified other civil rights groups to work with, the training guide recommended identifying any changes in the community. To identify the changes in the community, the manual suggested activists focus their interpretation on the bodies of local residents to know certain patterns in the community. Specifically, "Shifts in population in facts about people moving in and out of the community -their skills, ages, sex, etc.", the "Work habits of self employed people" and "Changes in thinking and loyalties of people toward various images" (EB 6-14). Demographic patterns indicated the number of young blacks and students, whom

142

SNCC appealed to more than the NAACP. Work habits, changes in thinking would indicate how active the local community was in the struggle for civil rights.

The best way to identify patterns in the local community was to interview local blacks who may be aware of the everyday rhythms of the black community. In addition to mapping objective knowledge onto the population, activist should focus on 'gossip' or subjective knowledge of the black community. This included interviewing grocers on the "spending on food, clothing and general household supplies; gossip", local repairmen on any "changes in spending for farm equipment", barbers and beauticians on important "local issues" and more "gossip" (EB 6-14). What the locals talked about indicated what the community valued, feared, respected and hated. Information on who is spending money on clothes may indicate blacks with leisure time and extra money.

It was also important to interview local blacks whose employment positions placed them in relations with whites. These included porters in railroads and bus stations. Interviewing blacks who worked in close proximity to whites was a strategy to identify "what white folks say, maids, cab drivers, known Toms. These persons, so close to whites in some ways, may be approached indirectly" (EB 6-14). Since whites were not likely to cooperate with SNCC volunteers, the best way to identify white sentiment towards civil rights was to interview blacks who shared social space with whites at work, and overheard whites' discussions. SNCC workers had to be careful on how they approached these blacks because they may be weary of jeopardizing their economic livelihood by cooperating with civil rights workers. It was important to distance

143

themselves from blacks, like 'known Toms', who may betray and interfere with

civil rights work.

How to Set Up Operations Once Inside an Unfamiliar Black Community

The training manual instructed SNCC leaders what to do once they have gained gain access to the unfamiliar black community. This included how to hold a meeting, how to interact with locals, and how to interact with black professionals in the local communities and the families that housed them. First, it was important to know how to hold a meeting. Besides the importance of holding meetings at regular times and at the same places, "and being in a centralized location", activists must learn how to manage the emotional feelings of the crowd. For instance, Sherrod wrote, "Plan development of emotional peak in meeting or some kind of development - may be intentional development but you many intend to be unintentional" (EB 6-14). Emotional peaks in meetings disciplined the body and shaped embodied judgments, specifically the audiences' evaluation of the problem and how to solve it by 1) using examples of courage to excite and motivate the audience and 2) use words that signified feelings of outrage, anger to motivate blacks to join the movement. One suggested way of creating an emotional peak in the audience was emphasizing how students situated their bodies in relation to bad whites, "Our best selling point is that we are students with nothing but our bodies and minds, fearlessly standing before the monster who killed our mothers and castrated our fathers - yet we stand with love" (EB 6-14). Armed with nothing but their own bodies and minds, SNCC activists created an emotional image of heroic citizens sacrificing for the good of the community.

144

Emotionally charge language, like the verb 'castrated' has the polysemic meaning in psychoanalysis of being forcibly separated, but also being denied manhood. Thus, the use of emotions in meetings was a technique to shape the black audiences' evaluations and interpretations of black-white relations and the best way to solve it. SNCC's use of emotions to 'arouse' the audience's interest differed from SCLC's approach that urged blacks to manage affective responses, so as not to exhibit black stereotypes of emotionalism.17

Second, when interacting with the locals it was important to create social bonds. To create bonds between SNCC workers and strangers in the community, they taught freedom songs, and emphasized developing "personal relationships with students and adults" (EB 6-14). The best way to go about developing personal relationships is to "observe the basic sexual attraction between sexes and utilize this" (EB 6-14). SNCC believed they could use attractive women to get men to join, or vice versa, to recruit blacks who may not be overtly political at first, but may support SNCC for other reasons. SNCC also drew from gendered assumptions that women were less threatening than males, noting, "Women make the best images (impressions)" (EB 6-14). Gendered assumptions of women as 'weak' and 'inferior' did not help perceptions of women as rational black political agents, but it did make them useful for recruiting more black males to the cause. As I noted in the last chapter, the civil rights movement approached civil rights as the responsibility of the black man to gain, in part, a sense of masculinity as he gained a new rights. Thus, the female body

17 On occasions when King gave a speech, SCLC did use warm up acts. However, they used speakers, like SCLC vice president Ralph Abernathy, to loosen up the audience with humor rather than getting the crowd riled up, outraged and angry

145

should be styled and portrayed as feminine in order to make the struggle for civil rights appealing for black men, and non-threatening to whites.

Third, since the vast majority of SNCC volunteers were college students working down south during summer breaks, coupled with the limited monetary resources for housing costs, local families adopted volunteers as part of their family. SNCC referred to the homes of local black families who housed them as 'freedom houses'. Aware of the intimate shared space between volunteers and families, SNCC regulated how each family was to be address and what constituted proper subject matters for public discussion: "We promote the adoption of each of us as their children - we call them moms, pop - that's home). We relate to our professional peers be preaching for ministers; playing chess, discussing medicine, politics, insurance, education, business, etc." (EB 6-14). SNCC regulated how volunteers would interact with adults, and families, in order to show respect for their elders. SNCC limited conversation subject matter to serious matters of public importance. They did not engage in juvenile small talk - sports, members of the opposite sex, gossip etc. Limiting conversations to matters of public importance disassociated SNCC students from both black stereotypes and childish associations. Sherrod wrote that in the act of communication with local black residents, "We build images of respect, courage, suffering, Tomism etc, using various personalities as points of reference" (EB 6-14). In the process of creating new images of good black citizens, Sherrod noted, "We also destroy images". The responsibility was placed on SNCC field workers to convince rural blacks that change was possible. They had to

146

overcome assumptions that students were not capable for an adult job, a 'man's job', of fighting for civil rights. The regulation of good black practice represented SNCC workers as rational and knowledgeable black political agents capable of initiating social change. Nonviolence and Ascetic Techniques of Self

In addition to questions of how best to train new leaders, nonviolent periodicals circulated throughout the students, indeed, through all of the civil rights movement. One such periodical, Theory and Practice of Civil Disobedience, was written and published by New Hampshire pacifist Arthur Harvey (RF 1-1). Harvey first published this periodical in July 1961 with a print run of 105 copies. By December 1961, it was in its seventh printing totaling 5070 copies. While the periodical discussed a general theory of nonviolence, it also outlined a set of ascetic practices of self in relation to civil disobedience and Christian virtue. This periodical represents a link between the peace movement and ideas of meditating and the use of sport as an alternative to violence18. It represented texts that circulated amongst liberal protestant pacifist culture the movement drew from. The relationship between nonviolence and religion was the association of virtue with an ascetic mastery of pleasure and temptation.

Harvey defined nonviolence as form of religious asceticism. Mastering nonviolence equated to mastering a set of pleasures that temp the body. Harvey described a list of temptations to master, including "Pleasure-seeking, luxury, ease, wealth and power should be avoided; self-restraint, simplicity, physical

18 See Henry Fitzgerald (1935) "The Significance of the New Pacifism" and Everett Jessup (1940) "War or Sport" located in box 3 of the Carnegie Peace Pamphlet and Microfilm Collection

147

labor and identification with the lowest classes through service - all these strengthen nonviolence". Practicing nonviolence required monastic devotion. Mastering nonviolence and self-restraint equated to virtuous practices of giving up perceived luxuries of the 'modern world', and working with ones hands. We see how Harvey associated self-restraint from bodily pleasures with how he hierarchically orders different forms of nonviolence. A section pondering the question "Should injustice be resisted" implicitly ranks four forms of nonviolence: non-involvement, non-resistance, non-cooperation, and fasting. Non-involvement is considered and extreme practice. It was reserved for the select few individuals to such a level that they do not "attempt to influence others" through political practice. Harvey notes non-involvement, "in social terms this attitude has effect. The practice of celibacy and vegetarianism, for example, strongly suggests that sex and meat-eating are inferior types of behavior - at least to many observers who look for values in the attitudes and conduct of others". The idealized nonviolent subject mastered all temptations that indicate inferior behavior - including the eliminating dietary practices of consuming animals and sexual practices. Mastery over these 'worldly' temptations distinguishes and transforms the pacifist into a symbol to emulate.

Since only a select few might master non-involvement, Harvey evaluated other techniques of civil disobedience. Nonresistance was "too elusive or misunderstood for brief treatment" but it was the nonviolent practice of choice for both Tolstoy and Jesus. Fasting, the art of denying the body food as a means of protest, was taken as a "borderline technique" only useful in specific situations,

148

like prison reform. Physical intervention was dangerous because it involved thwarting the will of the opponent" and may arouse one emotionally. Therefore, Harvey presented non-cooperation as the nonviolent practice for present political struggles like the anti-war/peace and civil rights movements. Non-cooperation, in part, meant mastering the physical body in the "refusal to use one's muscles to comply with commands", including "going limp when taken into custody". Suggested nonviolent techniques aligned with non-cooperation concentrated on using the body as a political weapon, situated at the point of violence. For instance, activists should use the body to obstruct war machines, "the disobedient places his body in a position where he would be killed if the machine continued to function". Thus, non-cooperation used the body to disrupt the rhythms of public space as a symbolic act.

An overarching theme of this periodical is going to jail. Harvey notes how James Lawson identified a mistake in the student sit-ins as not staying in jail and demanding that adults increase their support and involvement in the struggle for civil rights. For Harvey, commitment to nonviolence and civil disobedience meant that over ones lifetime, one could expect to divide his/her life between, "25% of imprisonment, 25% for picketing, leafleting, speaking, writing, etc., 50% for constructive program - developing an economy to eliminate injustice. In my view this must be agrarian, vegetarian, poor, decentralized and not dependent on technology." How one went to jail mattered. Nonviolent civil disobedience required a commitment for going to jail with a purposive meaning. When entering a plea, "a plea of guilty should be entered". Harvey does not go into the kind of

149

detail of the best ways to prepare for arrest and jail that the Manual for Direct Action does. However, he does note that 'going limp' was up to each individual, but just going along with the arrest was ok too. There was also a set of rules to observe when going to jail. When interacting with other prisoners, Harvey recommends, "Don't be talkative or discuss personal matters with prisoners you don't know pretty well. Many homosexuals are looking for partners". In contrast to SCLC ideal of the good prisoner, Harvey intertwines personal safety in jail with not giving into temptation and being penetrated, or feminized. In some respects, Harvey is attempting to compensate for the lack of masculine virtues (tough, rugged etc) associated with nonviolence with religious based homophobia. That is, nonviolent men were still good citizens and masculine because they did not signify "gay" - feminine, weak, and lacking self-restraint from temptation.

Thus, SNCC's grassroots political project used discourses of good black citizenship to organize ethical practices to organize autonomous political cells. The important ethical practices were what counted as proper subject matter of public discussions, how to use emotions at political rallies, and mastering nonviolence. The Harvey periodical illustrated how the care of the body, in relation to dietary and sexual austerity, intertwined with a virtuous nonviolent practice. Since the grassroots project placed the responsibility on individual field workers to remain nonviolent, ascetic practices of anti-consumerism and vegetarian disciplined the body to master emotional responses. While civil rights movement activists were definitely not refraining from having sex, many of the leaders, including King, did associate nonviolence with a religious asceticism of

150

refraining from consumer goods and representing the plight of the poor. These debates over the proper care of the body filtered into SNCC programs that instructed on practices of public health and what constitutes a proper diet. Next, I illustrate how SNCC articulated debates over the body - good listening and speaking, and the healthy body - and inscribed them into bodily practices in Mississippi Freedom Summer 1964.

THE FREEDOM SCHOOLS AND COMMUNITY CENTERS OF THE 1964 MISSISSIPPI FREEDOM SUMMER

Freedom summer was a response to the expansion and influence of SNCC's grassroots project. Similar to SCLC's citizenship schools, the idea behind freedom summer was to setup alternative schools to train blacks on ethical practices in order to get them to a point where they could organize and sustain autonomous black political communities. Freedom summer differed from other SNCC projects because 1) they sought to mobilize Mississippi blacks into an independent political party to challenge local and state authority rather than federal authority, 2) it emphasized community health standards instead of voter registration, and 3) it was centralized in northern Mississippi as opposed to decentralized independent cells scattered throughout the south. These three differences represented a shift from organizing blacks as 'individuals', associated with the idea of liberalism, to organizing southerners as a group, black and white, in relation to shared geopolitical territory. SNCC saw limitations of organizing rural blacks in relation to idealized American citizenship, which placed the responsibility individual blacks to master deracialized techniques of self, because

151

of the 'lack of progress' in the movement (SNCC wanted more improvements at the local level) in relation to the changing political culture (post-1963 civil rights act). This shift to organizing blacks as a collective group made it possible for SNCC post-1965 Voting Rights act to draw from discourses of black authenticity and suggest that blacks were better off organizing as separate racial group (see chapter 4). However, in 1964 they still used discourses of good black citizenship to organize Mississippi blacks and whites into an interracial challenge Mississippi's Democratic Party.

The "freedom schools" and "community centers" were the Mississippi Council of Federated Organizations (COFO) signature program. COFO was a conglomerate of all nation civil rights groups, local civil rights groups and fraternal organizations operating in Mississippi. Although COFO was a conglomerate of all civil rights groups, SNCC was the dominant member. COFO came about after SNCC workers began voter registration drives in 1961. White anti-civil rights sentiment forced SNCC to focus its political activities in the Northern Mississippi Delta region and Greenwood in 196219. SNCC moved its operations to the Mississippi Delta because they believed that the "vague antipathy of the hill folk for the rich planters" provided better opportunities for inter-racial political organizing, since blacks and poor whites 'shared' impoverished social and geographical space. That is, SNCC believed that blacks and whites could organize around the idea of sharing a common geopolitical territory and economic positioning. In Greenwood, SNCC began to network with local groups,

19 "What is COFO? Mississippi: Structure of the Movement and Present Operations. COFO publication #6 located in CC 1-1 and RS 1-3

152

the "Holmes County Voters League" and the "Ruleville Citizenship Group", as well as SCLC citizenship schools, which provided the pedagogical structure of the freedom schools20. SCLC provided the structure for organizing the schools and helped train teachers at their Dorchester site.

The summer of 1964, known in Mississippi as "Freedom Summer", COFO established a series of freedom schools and community centers that trained Mississippi blacks on the ethical practices associated with good citizenship, which resulted in the formation of the Mississippi Freedom Democratic Party. By July 1964, there were 41 functioning schools dispersed throughout 20 Mississippi counties, totaling 2135 students.21 COFO divided freedom summer programs into three working parts - voting registration, freedom schools, and community centers. Neither program was autonomous from the other. All shared the end goal mastering a set of ethical practices that prepared blacks for roles within the civil right movement. Similar to SCLC's citizenship schools, freedom schools organized the spatial and temporal rhythm around the everyday lives of the local geopolitical community of rural black Mississippian. Freedom schools differentiated local geopolitical cultures between three contexts "rural, urban with strong civil rights movement, urban with weak civil rights movement"22 Literacy, trust, and desire to participate varied depending on the context of preexisting political work, and urban/rural cultural differences.

COFO organized some freedom schools in basements and outdoor areas of local black churches, while they organized others in black storefronts and homes23. Because of the nontraditional learning space, COFO suggested teachers, "Spend your time making your schoolroom full of the physical conditions for learning - reference books and materials in inviting and handy places"24. Teachers decorated space to appear more 'scholastic' to cultivate a learning environment. When possible, teachers brought in chalkboards, bookshelves, or alphabet posters to associate the makeshift spaces with "school". Some schools were run on the back lawns of churches, were a space under a tree served as a classroom. Regardless of where the schools were set up, COFO emphasized consistency and regularity in time and space25. Curriculum varied by time of day. Morning classes were organized around the topics like "Negro history and citizenship" while late morning classes focused on cultural development of typing, learning French, drama or working on the school newspaper.

Freedom schools also implemented the same learning strategies as SCLC's citizenship schools. They included discussion groups rather than lecturing because of need to train "children of the non-verbal 'culturally deprived' community the ability to formulate questions and articulate perception"26. COFO also emphasized selecting the right teachers. They used psychiatrists to screen

and weed out volunteers considered "dangerous to the movement" (quoted in Carson 1994: 111). COFO defined dangerous individuals as too idealistic, anti-political, and had their own ideas of what to do that contrasted with the freedom school program. Individuals accepted to teach were required to familiarize themselves with a shared foundation of knowledge, organized around mastering certain texts that the movement as a whole was reading or have read. COFO sent a letter to all accepted teachers asking that "all summer participants to read several books so we can assume some knowledge in common" (RS 1-1). The standard set of text ensured a base of knowledge associated with a discourse of good black citizenship. The required book list, ranked in order of importance, was Cash's The Mind of the South, Dubois's Souls of Black Folk, Harrington's The Other America, and King's Stride Toward Freedom, and Smith's Killers of the Dream (RS 1-1). These texts ensured not only the familiarity of southern culture and the history of the movement, but they also told a specific history of how blacks have successfully struggled for equality. Since the goal was to train students in the art of civic ethical practice, freedom schools tailored their citizenship pedagogy around Mississippi's local geopolitical concerns. Students were "given practice activities to improve their skills with reading and writing. Writing press releases, leaflets etc. for the political campaigns is one example. Writing affidavits and reports for arrests, demonstrations, trials etc. which occur during the summer of their town will be another".27 Other skills included "using the telephone as a campaign tool" and learning about the "forces" against Fannie Lou Farmer in particular, and blacks in general, from "even attempting to run for 27 "Prospectus for the Mississippi Freedom Summer" located in CC 1-1

155

Congress in Mississippi". Thus, freedom schools took SCLC's pedagogical strategies and modified them according to the specific problems and challenges Mississippi volunteers and activists faced.

The community centers provided the most expansive attempt of what the movement perceived as possible. COFO hoped the community centers would be a "permanent institution rather than a summer 'crash' program".29 Community centers taught the kinds of practices usually associated with a welfare state -public education, job training, childcare etc. COFO sought the general improvement of the body, especially the care of the body and questions of who was responsible for the body's care. Community centers trained adults how to "provide instruction in pre-natal care, infant care, and general hygiene" (SCLC 4-2). They also included "job training, classes for people who cannot read or write, classes on childcare, health programs, adult education and negro history classes, music, drama, and arts and crafts workshops" (CC 1-1). Workshops focused on "family relations, federal service programs, home improvements".30 The idea was to organize a set of ethical practices to inspect the health of the bodies - self, family and friend. Community centers instructed individuals on what constituted a good and nutritious diet, in differences between carbohydrates and protein, as well as public services that ensured minimal levels of sustenance. Healthy bodies and clean bodies dissociated black stereotypes from idealized black citizenship.

Finally, voter registration provided the end goal of the schools and community centers. In contrast to the various teaching practices of the freedom schools and community centers, COFO's "Mississippi Handbook for Political Programs" defined the voter registration summer project as the "The stock work or ordinary voter registration is the simple day to day business of canvassing, informal teaching, and taking groups to the court house" (RS 1-3). Therefore, voter registration projects faced a different set of problems of garnering trust and "overcoming fear and apathy of Negro community" (RS 1-3). In order to gain trust, bodies must exhibit good demeanors to appear trustworthy. COFO emphasized mastering techniques of a good black self, "The worker must give the impression of being courageous but not foolhardy, competent but not all knowing. Be yourself, do your job, preach freedom, and the community will come" (RS 1-3). Specific training included how to listen, what to listen for, knowing when to talk and how to talk when canvassing for prospective voter registrants. Next, I will show COFO used the freedom summer programs to train and shape the black body capable of exhibiting good civic practice. Citizenship Tasks, Listening and Speaking

The freedom schools used the same techniques as SCLC's citizenship schools to improve reading and writing skills. In order to improve the mind (perception, interpretation) COFO emphasized learning through the active body. For example, the suggested tasks for improving reading and writing were, "report for, and edit, a newspaper to exchange with other freedom schools" and "report

157

or exchange information (e.g. their work on voter registration)". Similar to SCLC's citizenship schools, COFO used tasks that prepared blacks for the nuances of political organizing. COFO instructed blacks on the practice of editing newspapers, which allowed blacks to comment on the political state of black Mississippi in a way that distinguished them as serious and professional. Learning how to publish periodicals, report and exchange information trained black students for much of movements' groundwork - local voter organizing and canvassing black neighborhoods. While students engaged in the tasks and discussed 'new ideas', Teachers were encouraged to "praise people freely. Compliment them for any small thing".32 Teachers 'praised' to overcome student shyness, timidity to build up feelings of competence while learning how to complete political tasks.

Good listening and speaking skills prepared activists for political activity in Mississippi. COFO published an "Overview of the Political Program" for volunteers and teachers. It contained a subsection "Techniques for Field Work" that defined issues pertaining to safety, the right way to canvass and run a workshop (CC 1-3). COFO instructed, "You should try to present yourself in a way that will make them want to talk with you". Canvassers should avoid associations of being timid and obnoxious in order to project a strong and courteous self. For instance, COFO instructed that "If a person closes the door in your face or will not talk with you, try to find out [sic] selsewhere why he did it. Everybody can be approached, but it may take much time and patience to reach

some people" and "If a person talks but show obvious reluctance, don't force a long explanation on them. Come back another day... This builds confidence and builds a relationship". Thus, the freedom schools trained volunteers to master a style of listening and speaking to 'read' what local blacks said, and more importantly, what was not said, to organize black Mississippians politically.

COFO trained the body on how to be a good listener in a racially ordered political culture. For example, COFO suggested that teachers that they emphasize practicing good listening skills in informal settings. "Cultivate this attitude of respect and real listening and honest answering right down to the bone. It's very hard to listen - practice it over the lunch table. But listen actively, not passively".33 COFO emphasized good listening because it was vital to the quality of information collected by volunteers working in the black community and establishing trust between civil rights workers and local black residents. A good listener signified the sense that the listener understood and sympathized with the plight of rural blacks. Based on SNCC's leadership training, COFO instructed future field workers how to interpret was blacks were implicitly telling them. It may not be what a local black resident says, but how they said it, that a volunteer based their interpretation on. When interacting with local black residents, COFO emphasized to "keep listening, and remember that fear will often cause words to mask real responses and that you must learn to hear what is beneath the words."34 Many local black residents, especially in places like northern Mississippi, feared talking or cooperating with civil rights activists because of the

33 "Non-Material Teaching Suggestions for Freedom Schools" located in CC 1-2

34 "Non-Material Teaching Suggestions for Freedom Schools" located in CC 1-2

159

likelihood whites would respond violently. They especially told white volunteers what they wanted to hear to make the white volunteers leave. Being a good listener was the best technique to convince the local black residents that civil rights workers could be trusted.

In addition to being a good listener, COFO trained the body to be a good speaker. A good speaker articulated their thoughts and opinions in a clear and concise way. COFO instructed teachers to use caution when correcting speech. COFO teaching suggestions advised "I would suggest not correcting grammar or spelling for the first few days unless a student asks you to (and means it)".35 Because how one speaks and pronounced words is so tightly wound with perceptions of intelligence, correcting how one speaks seemed abrasive, and was counterproductive to getting blacks to attend. Nevertheless, mastering a clear, concise, and articulate style speech was necessary for success management of the press, managing other civil rights workers under ones supervision, and putting together a mass meeting or workshop to attract others to join the movement. Free Southern Theatre and Role Playing

In order to practice deracialized techniques of self, freedom schools combined role-playing with theatre. Theatrical performances, dubbed "Free Southern Theatre" were workshops that put on plays in relation to the history of southern black-white relations36. COFO noted, "The workshops will serve not

In contrast to stories of Thomas Jefferson as the father of American democracy, the play emphasized Jefferson as a racist slave owner. While the theaters aim was to tell a southern story from the black point of view, learning how to act was important for learning how to manipulate the body and manage emotions. Role-playing situations allowed blacks to apply their 'acting skills' to simulated interactions involving black civil rights workers and the press, the police use of violence, canvassing for registered voters, and dealing with bad whites. For instance, COFO trained and prepared students on how to manage the press. One student took on the role of 'activist' while another student took on the role of 'reporter'. Other questions dealt with how reporters fished for internal conflict or race baited, questions such as "Do you think the summer project was a good idea?", "Do you like working with Negroes", "Have you found that most Negroes are dirty?", "Are negroes staying with white boys and girls?"39 COFO expected activists to master a set of answers that would not provide 'ammunition' to white adversaries. It was important not to confirm black stereotypes of blacks as dirty, or that they may find it difficult or unpleasant to work with them. Of special concern was managing the interracial sex question. It was important for activists not to confirm (nor deny) that black men were sharing social space with white females. Bad whites may perceive white men interacting with blacks as race traitors. However, acknowledgement of black men and white women sharing social space could initiate a systematic lynching of black men. Since the Klan was indiscriminate on lynching, this jeopardized all black men in the community. Community Centers: The Racial-Biopolitics of Diet and Family Care

In some respects, freedom summer was a continuation of what the movement as a whole was doing with citizenship schools, socio-dramas and leadership training. The community centers differed because they focused on issues of the body and public health. COFO collected and analyzed data related to black bodies and population. For instance, COFO published and distributed booklets like "The General Condition of the Mississippi Negro" in October 1963, 39 "Possible Role Playing situations" located in RS 1-11

162

where they detailed birth rated, death rates and infant mortality rates of the southern black population (CC 1-1). COFO volunteers researched ideas such as school lunch programs in Greenwood, and public health programs in Jackson Mississippi".40 The community centers attempted to improve the body's health by teaching public health practices and care for the body. It is important to note that federal nutrition programs, such as Women, Infants and Children (WIC) did not start until 1972, and the first Head Start programs, public pre-school, not until 1965. Thus, the COFO community centers established a new idea of the relationship between the healthy black body and society.

The community centers trained blacks on medical care of the body. Medical care of the body focused on immediate practices of prenatal care and infant care, to governmental responsibilities of sanitation and which public health services".41 They focused on medical care because of the generally poor health conditions, a lack of medical service in the black community, and lack of knowledge on how to use medical services in the rural black community. COFO reported Southern blacks faced a nutritional crisis and food shortage. "An adequate diet for the Mississippi Negro is available for brief periods only when they are recipients of government commodities and when the tenant farmer sells his cotton", and, "Even when food is available it is in the form of most poverty diets, high in starch and low in protein".42 Improving the physical health of bodies deracialized the visual presentation of they body. Good black men should work outside the home, both in the labor market but also on the physical exteriority. Good black women should work in the home, both in care of the children and ensuring the cleanliness of the interior. The art of maintaining ones home had two implications. First, COFO publications reported that the 1960 census showed "that in Mississippi, 66% of all Negro housing was dilapidated or deteriorating" and "more that 90% of rural Negroes homes in Mississippi have neither flush toilets nor bathing, or shower facilities".49 Fixing up ones home in part meant bringing it into the modern world of sanitation. Of course, blacks could not erect their own sewer system or generate electricity. Through political organization, they could pressure the state to provide public services to good citizens. Secondly, the art of maintaining ones home was an important craft to master when integrating white neighborhoods. It debunked black stereotypes that they did not care about the appearances of their homes. The Biopolitics of 1964 Mississippi

Improving the care and health of the body influenced what kind of rights they demanded. We can see the how the focus on improving the body's health influenced the types of rights asked for in "1964 Platform of the Mississippi Freedom School Convention". Rather than just voting rights, black Mississippians demands ranged from public sanitation, the improvement of housing conditions, changing educational practices and curriculum, and health care services. The demand for the right to a healthy life illustrated how the care

What is COFO? Mississippi: Structure of the Movement and Present Operations. COFO publication #6 located in CC 1-1 and RS 1-3

166

of the body organized the movement perception of what they expected out of government, and what was government's idealized role in society.

The Mississippi Freedom School Convention called for improvements in the physical environment. The body experiences the physical environment through its auditory, visual and olfactory senses. Bad visual 'landscapes' and smells radiating from sewage and garbage impact both quality of life and how citizens perceive their social positioning in society. The Mississippi Freedom School Convention called for city financing of "paving and widening the streets and installing drainage systems in them" and a "Better system of garbage disposal, including more frequent pickups" (RS 1-4). In addition to cleaning the physical environment, they also asked for a "building code for home construction" that ensured all homes in the black community would have a complete bathroom kit, kitchen sink, central heating systems, insulated walls and ceiling, and at least three electrical outlets in the living room (RS 1-4). While housing upkeep was the responsibility of blacks, they suggested that there be "there be lower taxes on improvement in the house so that more people will fix up their homes" as well as "zoning regulations be enacted and enforced to keep undesirable and unsightly industries and commercial operations away from residential neighborhoods" (RS 1-4). Good citizens deserve to live in clean environments. Members of the Mississippi Freedom School Convention had an idea that improving health of the physical environment affected the embodied black self. The deplorable environmental conditions limited black Mississippians' perception of what was

167

possible and what opportunities existed. Thus, improving housing and the physical environment encouraged good citizenship.

Improving the physical environment also had an impact on the family. The Mississippi Freedom School Convention asked for equal opportunity buying and rent control policy. They demanded, "Slums be cleared, and a low cost federal housing project be established to help house these people" (RS 1-4). They indicated that, "The home, being the center of a child's life as well as the center of a family's must have certain facilities in order for it to be a home and not just a building in which one eats, sleeps, and prepares to leave for the rest of the day" (RS 1-4). Good citizens cannot raise good children in bad and dirty environments. Familial relationships existed within the cultural and physical environment. Families invest emotional attachment to physical space to make it a home. Demanding standards for housing construction meant blacks had the right to live in single unit houses rather than shacks.

The Mississippi Convention demanded changes in teaching practices and the content of educational curriculum. This meant, "That teacher brutality be eliminated" (RS 1-4). They viewed all practices of using violence to inscribe power onto the body as unjust. The state should change the educational content to prepare blacks and poor whites for a post-industrial global economy, "In an age where machines are rapidly replacing manual labor, job opportunities and economic security increasingly require higher levels of education". The Mississippi Conference observed the decline of the cotton-based economy. They recognized that blacks and poor whites would fall further behind wealthy

168

whites as an emerging global economy took shape that required intellectual and interpretive skills. Schools would have to prepare the body for an economy that devalued manual and physical labor.

Finally, the Mississippi Freedom School Convention demanded services that allowed for the improvement of the body's health and well-being. One the one hand, this meant providing authoritative medical services to inspect and provide surveillance over the body, such as "mobile units, chest x-rays, semiannually and check up at least once a year by licensed doctors, the local health department, or a clinic should be provided be the local or state government" (RS 1-4). It is the equal responsibility of government and citizens to ensure the body's health and well-being. Preventive medical treatment could improve the quality of life in parts of rural black Mississippi that did not have health care, and places were rural blacks may have never seen a doctor. One the other hand, it meant deracializing the deployment of medical services. This meant more black physicians and nurses, but also the elimination of medical-political bodily punishments, "We actually seek the abolition of any sterilization act which serves as punishment, voluntary or involuntary, for any offenses" (RS 1-4). The body should not be the site of any form of punishment. In 1964, bad white Mississippians were attempting to pass legislation that proposed "Prison or sterilization for more than one illegitimate child".50 Good citizens control their own body and make their own decisions about rearing children. In sum, in addition to the right to vote the Mississippi Freedom School Convention
