169

demanded improved health and well-being of the body. While they viewed the care of the body as the responsibility of citizens and government, they also sought to impose limits on the state's monopoly of violence over the body. Good citizens owned their body, and teacher brutality and medical-political punishments violated this right. CONCLUSION

The idea behind the rights projects citizenship schools and role-playing workshops, and SNCC grassroots leadership training and community centers, was to train the body on how to exhibit good bodily postures and master affective expressions to deracialize idealized good citizenship. We can isolate how the program emphasized five dimensions that represented good black citizenship. The first practice was mastering good listening and speaking skills associated with good manners. Good blacks carefully pronounced the words they were using, as well as used the correct meaning of the words. They did not use slang associated with urban or 'street corner' cultures. Good black citizens listening to what others said by looking the speaker in the eye, and waiting for the speaker to finish his or her sentence before speaking. Good manners projected a polite and cordial black self, which debunked emotional, excitable, and illiterate black stereotypes. The second practice was mastering affective responses that limited the public display of emotions. Limiting emotional response disassociated blacks from irrational stereotypes of being violent, brash, angry, and over sexualized. Good black citizens were even keeled, especially when facing tough situations, like losing a job or facing instances of racial discrimination. Third, and related to

170

affective self-mastery, was mastering nonviolent practice. Being nonviolent meant 1) limiting physical responses in relation to physical violence and 2) limiting emotional verbal responses, like yelling, increase in pitch and tone of voice, and profane language, in relation to 'intense' and hostile situations. The fourth dimension was bodily practices associated with healthy bodies. This included clean bodies, clean clothes, a neat/conservative appearance, and nutritional dietary practices that incorporated protein into the diet. The healthy body was clean, groomed and physically fit, not fat nor malnourished, dirty or flashy. The idea of what counted as a well groomed and neat appearance was a contested point within the movement. The black nationalist project fiercely contested what counted as a well-groomed black body, arguing that many of the beauty products, for hair and makeup, was to lighten and even-out the black skin tone to appear more 'white'. Nevertheless, the rights and grassroots project used discourses of good black citizenship to press for a conservative look or clean and conservative dress - suits, polo shirts, slacks for men, and housedresses for women - to help blacks integrate. The last dimension was mastering good housekeeping practices. Good housekeeping was maintaining the cleanliness of the interior and exterior of ones home. Mastering good housekeeping practices represented good blacks as good neighbors. Since racial integration was part of the mainstream civil rights movements' political project, blacks had to maintain the upkeep on ones home to convince whites that neighbors cared about their home and property values.

171

These five dimensions of good black citizenship produced the idea of a deracialized black political agent. This was important for 1) discussing matter of common concern 2) networking with other blacks and whites, 3) appealing to a broad constituency when running for political office, and making additional claims for rights. The rights project urged mastering deracialized techniques of self as part of obtaining access to the public sphere, and having their participation be meaningful and effective. Rational political dialog should be cordial, with the emphasis on strength of argument rather that class position or racial characteristics51. Good manners, a lack of emotional outbursts, and the proper pronunciation and use of words organized how good citizens maintain rational dialog. In addition to social positioning, an important part of social networking was the social ethical practices, how one interacted with others, which formed connections and bonds that to establish social cohesion within and between groups. Because power relations historically constructed and 'ranked' whites as superior to blacks, the responsibility was on blacks to master deracialized techniques of self when sharing social space and networking with whites. Politically, blacks who mastered techniques of good black self were more likely to form political coalitions with other blacks and whites. Since blacks are a numerically minority in the United States, they burdened the responsibility of appealing to white support to govern integrated and cosmopolitan communities.

There were two key limitations to the rights project's citizenship schools. The changes in American political culture, especially overt racial discrimination,

51 Here, I am drawing from how Habermas [1962] 1991 argued that an idealized public sphere operated, rather than how it may operate

172

related to the movement's success also opened space for new forms of white resistance and for the increasing influence of discourses of black authenticity. The first limitation of the citizenship school was instructing non-violent practice in relation to southern public demonstrations. When the movement switched their focus to northern urban ghettos and ideas of combating poverty, mastering nonviolence practices became less important with a lack of violent adversaries. The movement succeeded in changing southern political culture, in that it lessened the use of violence as a strategy to control blacks. The second limitation was that the citizenship schools focused on instructing deracialized techniques of self in relation to disassociating black stereotypes associated with illiteracy. The voting rights act eliminated the use literacy tests for voter registration, thus, downplaying the need for overcoming illiteracy for political reasons. Illiterates could vote, therefore, they could not use learning to read to shape a civic vocabulary to understand the struggle for civil rights. Because the citizenship schools lessons were ordered, mastering personal ethics preceded social and civic ethical practices, and the focus of mastering personal ethics was practiced in relation to illiteracy, the citizenship schools lost their starting point. In order to overcome these limitations, SCLC would have had to reframe their reasons why blacks needed to master techniques of good black self by emphasizing in terms of urban revitalization and inclusion into political parties. That is, they needed a concrete issue to wrap their program around, like voting rights or ending racial violence, rather than abstract issues, like 'world peace' or 'eliminating poverty', which seemed unattainable and Utopian. While SCLC did

173

attempt to integrate stores with products from black owned businesses and start a poor people's movement, they did not have a model to draw from on how to revitalize black communities or create jobs.

The changing political culture open possibilities for SNCC to ask questions of whether nonviolence, working with whites, and deracialized techniques of self was still a preferable and effective mobilization strategy for racial equality. By the Freedom Summer of 1964, we could already see how SNCC started to emphasize blacks identifying as a group, defined by local geopolitical boundaries and still interracial, as opposed to the idea good citizens attached to American nationhood, bounded by idealized American civic norms, values and beliefs. It is this shift to identifying as a group, which preceded SNCC adoption of the black nationalist project, that opened up space for SNCC to use discourses of black authenticity to begin considering blacks as first and foremost part of a racial group, then American citizens. While SCLC did not have an urban revitalization or economic growth models to draw from, SNCC did have the competing black nationalist project, specifically the Nation of Islam and movement intellectuals like Malcolm X, to draw from to attach blacks to an idea of racial authenticity. As I will show in chapter 5, SNCC forced the civil rights movement to answer questions of intra-group boundaries - how to handle blacks that did not conform to good black citizenship, who could not or did not want to practice nonviolent civic ethics or integrate with whites. Rather than focus their resources on developing revitalization models, the rights project had to take a step back and face a challenge that blacks needed to emphasize the idea of the racial group,

174

rather than the deracialized individual, to provide the best way to further racial equality.

CHAPTER 4: THE BLACK NATIONALIST POLITICAL PROJECT AND DISCOURSES OF BLACK AUTHENTICITY

Despite the rights project dominating 1960s public discourse on the race question, the black nationalist political project challenged the rights project's idea of what counted as good black citizenship. Unlike the rights project's use of discourses of good black citizenship that attempted to deracialize American citizenship, the black nationalist political project used discourses of black authenticity to argue that struggles for equality and citizenship rights in American have always been racially based. Rather than fashion a set of ethical practices around an idealized good citizen, the black nationalist project suggested that the blacks struggle for racial equality should be organized around the idea of an "authentic black self". The idea behind the authentic black self was that blacks had to rediscover a set of black practices uncorrupted by whiteness. As I show below, this included learning or rediscovering black history in American culture, abstaining from bodily mutilations, and rejecting religions, economic and political systems associated with whiteness.52 A consistent pattern in black nationalist thought is the practice of "recovering" a pre-discursive black body uncorrupted by white cultures that represented a glorious and powerful black self. The black nationalist project used the idea of an authentic black self to produce and distinguish a normative ideal of the revolutionary black political agent from ideas of whiteness and the deracialized black self. Thus, rather than rank blacks based on how much they reflected an idealized good citizen, discourses of black

52 For example, the Nation of Islam rejected American nationhood and Christianity because they considered them white cultural practices.

176

authenticity ranked black citizenship based on how much they abstain from associations of whiteness and represented an arbitrary idea of black authenticity.53

The black nationalist project differed significantly from the rights project in how they approached citizenship and made symbolic citizenship claims. As the previous three chapters argue, the rights project used discourses of good black citizenship to shape a rhetoric of describing and defining blacks as good citizens, as well as how to master bodily postures and affective self mastery, in order to attach the idea of good black citizenship with the dominant representation of what black citizenship should be. The rights project, which drew from liberal ideas of citizenship, emphasized the importance of the individual. In contrast, the black nationalist project challenged the rights project on the grounds that citizenship was the property of groups, and primarily racial groups.54 For the black nationalist project, American citizenship excluded all blacks, regardless if they mastered deracialized techniques of self or if they were wealthy, based on their ascribed status. Therefore, the black nationalist project made symbolic citizenship claims by attaching their idea of black authenticity to the racial group. Once blacks identified as black first, and American second, the black nationalist project assumed blacks would begin to build up financial resources and political power, then associate with whites on the political level as equals. That is, blacks

Indeed, the Nation of Islam viewed communism and socialism as 'white ideology' and Christianity as a white religion or slavery and death (see Lincoln 1961: 18, 28, 119). 54 For example, in 1967, Stokely Carmichael remarked to black students that, "You had better recognize that individualism is a luxury that black students can no longer afford. You had better understand that. You had better begin to see yourself as a people, and as a group, and therefore you need to help advance that group" (Carmichael [1967] 1969: 123).

177

would become a part of the American polity, but would not assimilate into it, after they had built up enough political and economic power. Thus, the differences in how each project approached citizenship reflect the differences in liberal understandings of citizenship that defines citizenship as the property of autonomous individuals, and multicultural understandings of citizenship that critiques universalizing ideals of citizenship in favor of defining citizenship as the property of social groups (see Young 1990, Kymlicka 1994).

The black nationalist project understood citizenship as the property of groups because of how they understood the history of American political life and racial and ethic groups. Black nationalists told the story of upward social mobility, 'the American dream', in racial terms rather than individuals working hard to achieve economic gains. For them, white ethnics groups improved their social standing by organizing by homogenous racial groups. They saw 'Irish' and 'Italians' living and policing their own neighborhoods, patronizing their own stores, and eventually electing 'Irish' and 'Italian' city councilmen and mayors. Despite never assimilating like white ethnic groups, they saw 'Jews' and 'Chinese' as successful because they ran their own family businesses, in their own neighborhoods. Thus, the black nationalist political project used their interpretation of a homogenous intra-racial group strategy of white ethnics and Jews as a model to emulate for their own path to gaining power, not assimilation, before proceeding with ideas of civic participation. The black nationalist project maintained that the best approach to racial equality and debunking harmful black stereotypes was by distinguishing blacks as a distinct racial group.

178

Although both political projects struggled to defy black stereotypes, their differences stem from an idea of mastering techniques of self in relation to attaching the individual to an idealized American nationhood versus mastering techniques of self that attached the individual to the racial group. On the one hand, each political project organized a set of practices for blacks to master. The rights political project attempted to deracialize American citizenship by establishing at set of ethical practices for both blacks and whites to exhibit. They concentrated their political efforts at excluding irrational political practices, like physical and verbal attacks, in place of rational dialog that provided 'common ground' for civic inclusion. Since the idea of rejecting whiteness was a given, the black nationalist political project concentrated on intra-group, or black-black relations. Before blacks could engage whites as equals, they must first purify and 'resolve' conflicts with the self and other blacks. That is, they must learn about a separate black cultural history that distinguished a proud history of resistance against white domination.55 Although some practices overlapped, especially with ideas of conservative dress and the maintenance of heteronormative black families, the practices represented something different depending on the political project. The rights project instructed a set of personal ethical practices, such as abstaining from flashy styles of dress, to help blacks integrate into American society. In contrast, the black nationalist project

A common theme in Malcolm's text was linking blacks to the violent and revolutionary aspects of anti-slavery movements: "When we send our children to school in this county they learn nothing about us other than that we used to be cotton pickers. Every little child going to school thinks his grandfather was a cotton picker. Why, your grandfather was Nat Turner; your grandfather was Toussaint L'Ouverture; your grandfather was Hannibal" (Malcolm [1964] 1992c: 65).

179

instructed, in some instances, a similar set of personal ethical practices to keep whites away, especially government administrators, in order to help black establish sovereignty and racial separation, which represented a revolutionary black political agent.

This chapter examines, first, how the black nationalist project used an idea of black authenticity as a discursive strategy to obtain power in place of civic inclusion. Based on primary source text (speeches, writings, editorials) and secondary historical source material, I focus on how the Nation of Islam and Malcolm X, the most popular post-war black nationalist project, represented how the black nationalist project arises in relation to deracialized and rights discourses. Since the Nation of Islam was a secret and exclusionary organization, they did not leave a textual archival legacy. Indeed, C. Eric Lincoln, who did a participatory study on the Nation of Islam in the early 1960s, noted that the Nation of Islam's passed along their core doctrine orally (see Lincoln 1961, also Beynon 1938). I will focus primarily on how Malcolm X used discourses of black authenticity to suggest the black nationalist political project as an alternative to the rights project. My purpose here differs from other research and scholarly work on Malcolm X. Scholarly writing on Malcolm and the civil rights movement have focused on his use of black nationalism as a political ideology (Sales 1994). Others have argued that Malcolm's ideas began to overlap with the mainstream civil rights project by his and King's assassination, and that common ground between the two political projects could have been sought (Lomax [1968] 1987, Cone 1991, DeCaro 1996). Nevertheless, my objective

180

here is not an extensive analysis of the organization, or the Nation of Islam as a 'millenarian' cult (see Lee 1996), nor do I spend time with detailed nuances of his thought, but rather focus on his normative arguments and the cultural ideas Malcolm and the Nation of Islam represented. Indeed, subsequent black nationalist groups, including SNCC, and the Black Panthers, drew almost exclusively from Malcolm's articulation of the black nationalist normative black political agent after the 1965 Voting rights act (see Chapter 5)56.

The second half of the chapter focuses on SNCC's transformation to a black nationalist project. Scholars have theorized SNCC's transformation in terms of the tightening of the organizational structure (McAdam 1999), shifts in black ideology (Blumberg 1984), motivations and psychological states (Haines 1988) rival black intellectuals (Eyerman and Jamison 1991) or changes in the 'symbolic resonance' of grassroots projects and participatory styles of democracy (Polletta 2000). These studies fail to note that 1) SNCC continued to use 'grassroots' organizing practices even after adopting the black nationalist project, 2) that the centralization of authority in SNCC did not change the autonomy of political cells in Alabama or Atlanta and 3) the presence of rival intellectuals like Adam Clayton Powell and Malcolm X since the late 1950s. Scholars that propose that SNCC changed because of shifts in black ideology or symbolism fail to say how those shifts arose, were constructed, what they produced, and the relationship of the differing ideology to the history of black political thought and

56 Franz Fanon's Wretched of the Earth was the other important text for the black nationalist groups of the 1960s. However, it appealed primarily to those attempting to organize around ideas of pan-Africanism, which competed with ideas of black capitalism for influence within the black nationalist project.

181

protest. In contrast to previous studies, I will explain how SNCC used discourses of black authenticity to reinterpret the difficulties associated with their grassroots political project, which along with their geographical style of organizing autonomous political cells, led to their adoption of the black nationalist project. I use comparative methods to show the differences in how SNCC used discourses of good black citizenship versus how they used discourses of black authenticity to understand how they answered questions of mastering techniques of authentic black self, which changed how they approached their relationship with whites, and how they shaped black civic practices. In sum, this chapter illustrates that the black civil rights ethical practices are not autonomous from the discursive political projects, and that American movements can draw from alternative understanding of citizenship, American cultural features, and global racial struggles. Next, I will outline how the black nationalist political project defined a set of techniques of authentic black self as an alternative political practice for achieving racial equality. THE NATION OF ISLAM AND TECHNIQUES OF AUTHENTIC BLACK SELF

The history of the black nationalist political project in black political struggles is one of emerging and responding to the dominant integration and rights projects. In the mid-1800s, Martin Delaney challenged Fredrick Douglas over the issue of integration and argued that blacks should create a separate black nation (see Cruse 1967). Black nationalism became an influential alternative in the 1930s depression era urban black culture. Detroit, Michigan, in particular, had several black nationalists groups competing for influence -

182

including a chapter of Marcus Garvey's United Negro Improvement Association (UNIA), the Moorish Science Temple Movement, The Nationalist Movement for the Establishment of a Forty-Ninth State, The National Union of People of African Descent, and The Nation of Islam, to name a few (see Beynon 1938, Lincoln 1961, Cruse 1967). The early Nation of Islam, of the 1930s, drew many of their recruits from southern blacks who migrated to the North (Beynon 1938). In contrast, Lincoln noted that in the 1950s and 1960s, 80% of the Nation of Islam's members were between 17-35, predominately male and lower class (1961: 23-27). Of the many black nationalist groups of the 1930s, only the Nation of Islam survived. Despite group competition for influence over the urban black community, each black nationalist group sought to obtain power by first creating an idea of an authentic black culture that rejected associations with whiteness. This meant emphasizing symbolic identifications with Africa, physical separation from whites, and rejecting Christian religious beliefs and practices. Although groups came and went, and membership never approached the levels of the NAACP, the black nationalist political project was important for representing a racializing strategy that sought power through cultural and political sovereignty.

One of the reasons the Nation of Islam outlasted their contemporary black nationalist organizations were its schools and internal police force that instructed blacks how to practice their idea of an authentic black self, and punished them when they violated its strict rules. The Nation of Islam organized the 'University of Islam' and 'Muslim Girl Training Class' to teach black history, how to speak Arabic, and in the Girls training school, the proper way to clean a house, sew,

183

cook a Muslim meal, and take care of children (see Lincoln 1961, Malcolm [1965] 1999). The police force, which went by the name 'Fruit of Islam', was responsible for administering judgment and punishment for any Nation of Islam member who violated the group's strict cultural codes. Lincoln noted that The Fruit of Islam read the charges then pronounced the verdict; defendants were not allowed to present their case (1961: 199-203). Violations that led to punishments, which ranged from performing manual labor at a local Muslim temple to expulsion from the group, included misusing temple funds, using narcotics, sleeping during meetings, eating/selling pork, being overweight and disrespecting Muslim women (Lincoln 1961: 201). In addition to their schools and police force, the Nation of Islam used theatrical performances to celebrate the superiority of an authentic black culture. One play title Orgena, written by Louis Farrakhan, portrayed a black lawyer convicting 'the white man' for being, among other things, the greatest liar, drunkard, gambler, peace-breaker and troublemaker on earth (see Lincoln (1961: 3). Thus, the Nation of Islam used formal and informal means to discipline black ethical bodily practices to represent an idea of authentic black self. Along with an analysis of how Malcolm represented the black nationalist project, I will show how the Nation of Islam produced a normative idea of authentic blackness and accompanying set of authentic black personal, social, and civic ethical practices. Discourses of Black Authenticity and Personal Ethics

The Nation of Islam guided their followers and recruits on how to master a set of personal ethical practices in relation to an idea of black authenticity. They

184

used discourses of black authenticity to produce a set of personal ethical practices, the relationship black had with the self, which distinguished a normative idea of authentic blackness from the deracialized black self and associations of whiteness. The idea was that all blacks, especially black addicts, dealers, pimps and prostitutes confined to the extreme margins of society, needed to improve their personal ethical practices. Indeed, Malcolm approached the black nationalist political project as a self-help project, "We need a self-help program... Black nationalism is a self help philosophy. This is a philosophy that eliminates the necessity for division and argument, so that if you're black, you should be thinking black" (Malcolm [1964] 1968: 208). Indeed, the Nation of Islam used discourses of black authenticity to organize personal ethical practices that limited and excluded all associations with whiteness, including Christianity, Marxism, and any political strategy that sought civic inclusion. For the Nation of Islam, the prolonged exposure to an inferior white culture has created a docile black subject not capable of thinking or practicing as a black man, "The Negro's position is most strategic, but his mental condition is too pathetic for him to take intelligent advantage of this vital position 'fate' has placed him in. The American Negro is suffering from a mental sickness" (Malcolm [1960] 1964: 311). In order to cleanse black citizenship, the black nationalist project sought to limit personal ethical practices corrupted by whiteness that led blacks to a life of vice and crime, which reproduced blacks subordinate social positioning to whites. Malcolm, especially, viewed the improvement of personal ethical practices as 'foundational' for a uniform and unified black identity (Malcolm [1963] 1992a:

185

147). Thus, the Nation of Islam defined techniques of self as what blacks should abstain from in order to purify the black body from whiteness.

In contrast to the mainstream civil rights movement, the black nationalist political project rejected the idea that blacks' exhibiting idealized good citizen practices was enough, "This young Negro educator in Georgia - he wasn't ragged, he wasn't uncouth, he wasn't uncivilized; he was an educator, he was as uppity and dicty as they were - and they still shot him. Why? Because he had nothing behind him. His education couldn't save him" (Malcolm [1964] 1992b: 159). Malcolm used discourses of black authenticity to argue that good speaking skills and a neat and clean body was not enough for racial equality. Black Americans would always be black first, then American citizens. We can isolate the types of personal ethical practices the Nation of Islam used to instruct their members on how to refrain from deracializing the black self and how to limit the harmful effects of white culture on blacks. Specifically, they instructed and enforced ascetic practices of 1) mastering the desire of 'improper' bodily pleasures 2) eliminating bodily mutilation and 3) shaping bodily postures that represented an authentic black subject.

The Nation of Islam outlined a set of acceptable and forbidden pleasures relating to the body - dietary, sexual, and the consumption of vice - in relation to improving black hygiene and care of the self, in order to produce a healthier and authentically black physical body. Part of improving the black mind and body was changing his or her eating practices. Authentic blacks mastered their desires for 'slave foods'. The Nation of Islam had strict dietary guidelines for all

186

members. Nation of Islam members were required to fast three days each month. Meals were limited to one a day, at sundown, consisting mostly of beans and vegetables. Restrictions on food sought to "eliminate physical and mental sluggishness and leaves more time for industry" (Lincoln 1961: 81). Black Muslims could not eat any hog, duck, goose, possum or catfish. Nor could they eat black-eyed peas or cornbread. The only animals black Muslims consumed were the lamb, the chicken and the cow. The Nation of Islam penalized black Muslims, by fine, if they were overweight. The Nation of Islam dietary restrictions all reflect abstinence from the typical rural black cuisine in southern geopolitical cultures. The idea behind dietary restrictions was to cleanse the body from associations with slavery and southern black rural culture historically dominated and corrupted by whites. However, dietary restrictions produced a strong and healthy black body that could work efficiently toward building and idealized black only community. Authentic blackness rejected the fat, lazy, dirty, and unhealthy associations of rural blacks.

The Nation of Islam emphasized the need to master personal ethical practices of abstaining from certain bodily pleasures associated with 'social vice', specifically marijuana, cocaine, heroin, tobacco and alcohol, because vice was defined as white and "western" pleasures (see Malcolm [1961] 1998: 234). The Nation of Islam approached addiction as producing an unproductive and corrupted bodily subject - the "prostitute", the "juvenile delinquent", the "fornicator" (see Malcolm [1963] 1992a: 111). They used discourses of black authenticity to rehabilitate the black body, corrupted by the vices of white culture,

187

and transformed it from a liability into an asset. Malcolm noted that Islam

supplied better personal ethical practices to 'rehabilitate' the black body than the

rights project,

Complete separation; not only physical separation but moral separation. This is why the Honorable Elijah Muhammad teaches black people in this country that we must stop drinking, we must stop smoking, we must stop committing fornication and adultery, we must stop gambling and cheating and uses profanity, we must stop showing disrespect for our women, we must reform ourselves as parents so we can set the proper example for our children. Once we reform ourselves of these immoral habits, that makes us more godly, more godlike, more righteous (Malcolm 1963: (Clark Interview): 141).

By abstaining from social vice, authentic blacks did not poison their bodies.

Rather, the ascetic practices created a productive body that debunked black

stereotypes that blacks would rather get 'drunk', 'high', or shoot dice, than go to

work. Sexual practices were strictly limited to heterosexual black men and black

women relations. In part, limiting sexual partners to same race/different sex

relations ensured a racially homogenous genetic lineage. More importantly, the

Nation of Islam used discourses of black authenticity to argue that black men had

to maser their desire for white women because it encouraged other bad

practices. Malcolm recounted in his autobiography how he and his friends'

involvement with white women reinforced their drug habits and criminal activities

(see Malcolm [1965] 1999: 133-153). Refraining from vice and limiting sexual

practice to black men and black women was important for building separate black

communities. It helped stabilize heteronormative black families and directed

excess money to black owned restaurants, automobile repair shops, and

188

temples. Thus, the negation of vice from an idealized authentic black subject

was a strategy to 'grow' black communities without black dependency on whites.

The consequences for blacks not mastering personal ethical practices

differed between political projects. For the rights project, failure to mater

techniques of deracialized self meant further segregation and inequality.

However, for the black nationalist project, the failure to master desires for social

vice was increased black exposure to whites and increased 'white' surveillance

through state administrative practices. Blacks that mastered their desire for

social vice kept black families in tact and themselves out of jail. It provided some

'invisibility' from the most hated whites - social workers and the police. Malcolm

argued that because of the urban ghetto culture, blacks were,

... exposed to every form of indecency and vice imaginable. Our young girls, our daughters, our baby sisters become unwed mothers before they are hardly out of their teens.... It becomes almost impossible to practice the rules of good hygiene. And therefore tuberculosis, syphilis, gonorrhea, and other destructive social diseases are on the rampage throughout our community (Malcolm [1963] 1989: 63-64).

In addition, addiction and sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), left untreated,

visibly dehabilitates the physical body. Addiction and STDs have a 'history', in

that they have been attached to marginalized groups to explain and justify their

civic exclusion57. Mastering pleasures associated with social vice was a strategy

to clean up the body, as in produce a physically clean and healthy body to

remove the symbols of pollution that provided the basis for black criminal

stereotypes.
