189

In addition to refraining from improper bodily desires, the Nation of Islam

used discourses of black authenticity to argue against black bodily modification

or mutilation. They associated bodily modification in relation to the deracialized

project emphasis on mastering vernacular speech patterns and limiting affective

responses. In contrast, bodily mutilation was associated with whiteness, where

blacks attempted to alter their body's physical features to reflect the physical

features of whites. Authentic blacks did not modify their hair texture or skin color

to mimic the whites' hair and skin. Malcolm noted that bodily mutilation was "my

first really big step toward self degradation: when I endured all of this pain,

literally burning my flesh to have it look like a white man's hair" (Malcolm [1965]

1999: 56). Malcolm argued that blacks' mutilated their bodies because white

culture associated cultural ideals of beauty exclusively with white bodies. Blacks

mutilated their bodies out of shame. This was especially true of blacks who

obtained higher levels of formal education. He noted that black men who

attended college or universities were less racially authentic than blacks who did

not obtain higher education. For example, he described black college graduates

as, "ashamed of what he is, because his culture has been destroyed, his identity

has been destroyed; he has been made to hate his black skin, he has been

made to hate the texture of his hair, he has been made to hate the features that

God gave him" (Malcolm [1962] 1969: 74). In contrast, Malcolm portrays Elijah

Muhammad as an authentic black leader, in part, because of his lack of formal

education prevented his identification with whiteness,

They ridicule him because of his lack of education and his cotton-field origin in Georgia. White America chooses to listen to the Negro civil

190

rights leaders, the Big Six. Six puppets who have been trained by the whites in white institutions and then placed over our people by these same whites as 'spokesmen' for our people (Malcolm [1963] 1971a: 126).

Elijah Muhammad was an authentic black man because his lack of a formal

educational training allowed him to interpret black bodily aesthetics as 'black is

beautiful'. Malcolm used discourses of black authenticity to question an

educational system that taught blacks to hate the racialized black self. In

contrast to college-educated blacks, whom Malcolm saw as practicing techniques

of deracialized self, he associated blacks not educated by the American school

system as more authentic than educated blacks.

Third, Malcolm used discourses of black authenticity to argue that blacks

needed to improve their bodily postures. Unlike black Americans who were

corrupted, demoralized and taught to hate the black self, Malcolm saw Africans

as exhibiting good bodily posture. In contrast to the rights project which saw

good bodily posture as a sign of dignity and good American citizenship, Malcolm

associated good bodily postures with dignity of pre-colonial African heritage. In

an attempt to recover prediscursive black bodily postures, Malcolm noted that

prior to being enslaved,

You were walking erect, upright. You ever watch your walk? Now you're too hip to walk erect. You've come up with that other walk. But when you're yourself, you walk with dignity... I was amazed when I was in Africa to see the sense of poise and balance that these people over there have, all throughout Africa and Asia (Malcolm 1970: 32).

Malcolm used discourses of black authenticity to argue that real blacks' practiced good bodily postures because it represented a powerful, self-assured and self-respected black political agent. Good bodily postures overcame the shame of

191

being black. Good posture communicated to whites that one was proud of who he or she was.

Specifically for black men, authentic black bodily postures represented hypermasculine ideals of toughness and sexual prowess. The Nation of Islam used training classes to train black Muslim men, primarily between the ages of 16-35, on practices of bodybuilding, physical hygiene, judo, military drills, and fighting with knives and black jacks, to shape a hypermasculine black body. Black male bodies should be muscular and physically intimidating. Black male bodies were disciplined to reflect, even emphasize, the black stereotypes whites feared the most. Similar to the rights political project, the black nationalist project included an idea how black men should act. The difference was how the black nationalist project used discourses of authenticity to associate black masculinity with violence, toughness to obtain power and respect, while the rights project argued that black men could still be masculine and nonviolent. Discourses of Black Authenticity and Social Ethics

The Nation of Islam used discourses of black authenticity to organize a set of social ethical practices, how blacks should have relations with other black political groups and other racial groups. In contrast to the rights project that defined social ethical practices in terms of good manners to ensure cordial and respectful relations between individuals, black and white, in public, the black nationalist project defined social ethical practices as the relations between racial and political groups in order to obtain power. They defined racial autonomy as the starting point for social ethical practices. On the one hand, the black

192

nationalist project rejected integration because integration forced blacks to abandon black racial identifications. Whites used integration as a "trick" to keep blacks subservient to the state. Even in places where whites 'allowed' blacks to integrate, Malcolm noted that whites all moved away to the surrounding suburbs to reestablish subtle and implicit forms segregation (see Malcolm [1963] 1989: 67). On the other hand, Malcolm drew from the idea of racial autonomy as a strategy for blacks use to purify a racial identify, necessary to govern and police black communities. Since they viewed all forms of community as racially organized, it was 'logical' to allow racial groups to govern their own. Specifically for the black nationalist political project, racial separation meant, "... once the black man becomes the political master of his own community, it means that the politicians will also be black, which means that he will be sending black representatives even at the federal level" (Malcolm [1963] 1992a: 153). Although they sometimes demanded racially geographic separation, in the form of a separate nation state within the United States, they never approached this as a realistic strategy58. However, they used an idea of racial separation to fashion a set of social ethical practices to define 1) how blacks should interact with other blacks to purify an authentic black identity 2) how blacks should use and interpret other domestic and global racial group successes as 'models' for developing business and inter-group political relations.

Typical of how the black nationalist political project used an idea racial separation to shape an identity was the following utterance by Malcolm X: "I believe that a psychological, cultural, and philosophical migration back to Africa will solve our problems. Not a physical migration, but a cultural, psychological, philosophical migration back to Africa - which means restoring our common bond - will give us the spiritual strength and the incentive to strengthen our political and social and economic position right here in America" (Malcolm [1963] 1992a: 152)

193

The Nation of Islam used discourses of black authenticity to define a set of social ethical practices that outlined how blacks should interact with other blacks. In contrast to how the rights project used discourses of good citizenship, which focused on the ethical relations between whites and blacks, discourses of black authenticity concentrated first on the ethical relations between blacks. The black nationalist project used discourses of black authenticity to disassociate black stereotypes attributed to the entire group, rather than stereotypes attributed to personal ethical practices. Specifically, the Nation of Islam sought to eliminate black-on-black violence. Malcolm blamed the white press for helping shaping an idealized black criminal identity that, "keeps the black community in the image of a criminal. And as soon as this impression is given, then it makes it possible, or paves the way to set up a police-type state in the Black community, getting the full approval of the white community" (Malcolm [1965] 1989a: 160). Malcolm noted that white continued to associate criminal and violent black stereotypes to blacks because they have mastered "a science that's called 'image making'. They hold you in check through this science of imagery. They even make you look down upon yourself, by giving you a bad image of yourself." (Malcolm [1965] 1989a: 160). Malcolm argued that blacks should stop fighting one another and concentrate their energies on the "real" enemy, whites, who were responsible for turning the black community on itself in order to control it. Blacks would obtain power only when they were equally willing to attack whites to claim respect as much as they are willing to attack blacks to claim respect. The black criminal may have had respect in the local black community, like Harlem, but only to the

194

extent that they did not cross bad cops and organized crime bosses - who were predominantly white.

In addition to limiting black-on-black violence, the black nationalist project defined how different black political projects should interact, so as not to present intra-group divisions and disagreements in public. Malcolm used discourses of black authenticity to emphasize that all black people faced common struggles because they were black first, therefore, they should resolve differences without whites, "Instead of airing our differences in public, we have to realize we're all in the same family. And when you have a family squabble, you don't get out on the sidewalk. If you do, everybody calls you uncouth, unrefined, uncivilized, savage" (Malcolm [1963] 1989: 251). Malcolm noted how the 1955 Bandung Conference sought a way to combat colonialism and establish national sovereignty in relation to the west. For Malcolm, it was the idea that 'people of color' got together and sought to solve their problems without whites. Indeed, the Bandung Conference did not invite nations that identified with western nations, including South Africa, Israel, and Taiwan. The Bandung Conference was important for developing ideas of 'pan-Islam' 'pan-Arabism' and 'pan-Africanism' (see Wright 1956, Kahin 1956).

The Nation of Islam organized a second set of social ethical practices that outlined how blacks should model their political strategies and interracial relations off of other 'models of racialized successes' of differing domestic and global racial group struggles. They divided domestic and global racial groups based on how each model obtained a particular 'form' of power. Domestic racial

195

groups, including all whites, Jews, as well as Chinese and Latin American immigrants, provided a model to obtain cultural and economic power. Global racial groups, notably African and Middle Eastern anti-colonial movements, but also Native Americans, provided models to obtain political power. They considered all racial groups struggles for power as autonomous from other racial groups. The differences between domestic and global racial groups is that domestic racial groups have obtained primarily economic power in order to obtain civic inclusion, whereas global racial groups have struggled for political power to gain "freedom", or independence from the dominant racial group. Global racial struggles have embraced violence as a means to end, where domestic racial groups have used economic power to get access to political power. The black nationalist project drew from both models. The idea was that if blacks could not obtain domestic economic and political power, then blacks should use global revolutionary struggles to secure power.

The black nationalist project argued that blacks should copy how American white ethnic groups racially organized their communities to secure power. They viewed Irish, Italian and Jewish communities as racially homogenized groups that improved their social standing as a racially whole. Malcolm noted, "Every immigrant ethnic group that has come to this country is now a genuinely first-class citizen group - every one of them but the black man" (Malcolm [1963] 1992b: 128). For instance, postwar urban blacks, stretching between New York and Chicago, would have viewed Irish pubs, Italian Bakeries, Jewish Jewelers, and Polish outdoor markets as indicators of racially organized

196

communities that produced racial elites, e.g. Chicago Mayor Richard Daly. Malcolm also associated Latin American immigrants and political refugees as obtaining power like other previous white ethnic groups. Malcolm saw little distinction between Cuban and eastern Europeans. He noted that America's practice of extending benefits to non-juridical citizens provided evidence that being the good citizen was not going to help blacks. He noted, "it is not surprising that the Hungarians and Polacks and Cuban can come to this country - who have never fought for this country, who have never contributed anything to this country's economy, who have never contributed to the defense of this democracy - can come here and get all the benefits of it" (Malcolm [1963] 1971c: 110-111).

Since whites were not going to give blacks power, Malcolm used discourses of black authenticity to argue that blacks model how they built black communities after the Jews and Chinese. The Nation of Islam often drew from racial stereotypes of other groups, especially strains of anti-Semitism that portrayed Jews as greedy and money-hungry. Despite facing discrimination from white Christians, Malcolm argued that Jews became powerful because "The Jew never went sitting-in and crawling-in and sliding-in and freedom riding, like he teaches and helps Negroes do. The Jew stood up, and stood together, and they used their ultimate power, the economic weapon" (Malcolm [1963] 1992b: 117). Similarly, the Chinese obtained economic power because they governed and managed Chinese communities, "The reason Chinatown is not regarded as a segregated community is that Chinese in Chinatown control all their own

197

business, all their own banks, their own politics, their own everything, whereas

the so-called Negro community everything is controlled by outsiders" (Malcolm

[1963] 1971b: 75). Thus, the black nationalist project approached all domestic

racial groups as obtaining power only after they racially separated themselves.

Although Jews and Chinese did not have the same amount of cultural inclusion

as Irish and Italians, they did have economic power, which made other white

ethnic groups respect them and grant them political access.

Global racial struggles provided a revolutionary model for obtaining power

if whites resisted black control over black communities. The Nation of Islam

viewed the Native Americans struggle as one example of a revolutionary global

racial group. Although Native Americans lost, Malcolm argued whites respected

Native Americans more than they did blacks because Native Americans used

violence,

The Indian is in worse shape than we are... But they [whites] have more respect for the Indians than they do for you and me. You know why? Because they fought them... Sure, they'll claim the Indians, but nobody is going to claim you and me - because we're non-violent, nobody. You're going to be a peaceful slave, a nonviolent slave. No, that Indian, brother, he drank blood, he tomahawked (Malcolm 1970: 50).

Despite Native American life on the reservation that hovered at levels of absolute

deprivation, Malcolm nevertheless viewed reservation life an alternative because

he viewed Native Americans as having the respect of whites. Native Americans

fought back, and whites 'rewarded' them with land that Native Americans

controlled. In contrast to the rights project, which outlined idealized ethical

practices that blacks and whites should exhibit, the black nationalist project

suggested blacks use racially organized and violent practices because it

198

produced material gains, such as land and power, over symbolic gains like desegregating buses and lunch counters.

African independence models were the other global racial struggle Malcolm suggested blacks model themselves after. How the black nationalist project drew from global struggles differed form the rights project in two key ways. First, the rights project emphasized how African nations gained freedom then incorporated into the world capitalist system. In contrast, the black nationalist project used the developing ideas of pan-Africanism to get American blacks to stop identifying as western subjects, and start identifying with other global minority group struggles. Rather than understand African nation states as joining the global world order, the black nationalist project saw the Bandung conference and pan-African ideology as proof that global black people were trying to separate and withdraw from a corrupted white-dominated global system. Second, whereas the rights project emphasized the nonviolent and democratic aspects of decolonialism, such as India, Ghana, and Kenya, the black nationalist project emphasized the violent and cleansing practices African nations practiced to rid themselves of all colonial residue. For Malcolm, African colonial struggles also provide an alternative model for blacks to draw from: "And when you see that you've got problems, all you have to do is examine their historic method used all over the world by others who have problems similar to yours. Once you see how they got theirs straight, then you know how you can get yours straight (Malcolm [1963] 1991: 253). Malcolm used discourses of black authenticity to depict anti-colonial struggles, such as the Mau Mau in Kenya, as a struggle

199

between two races. The Mau Mau used violence to overthrow Europeans and answer questions of land squatters, unemployment, lack of housing and lack of available land in rural areas (see Maloba 1993). Part of the Mau Mau violent strategies were using the servants to kill the white families they worked for, burn down colonial huts, and killing black government workers, teachers, and African bureaucrats aligned with the British. For blacks, the African independent struggles provided an alternative to the domestic models and rights projects nonviolent struggles. If white domination and violence increases when blacks begin to obtain economic power, or if white violence continues despite black nonviolence, then blacks can look to draw from the successful African struggles to organize political and revolutionary practices. Civic Ethics

The Nation of Islam did not directly get involved in politics. They abstained from voting or supporting any politician because they viewed every president and white politician reneging promises to help black Americans (see (Malcolm [1960] 1964: 313, Malcolm [1961] 1998: 225). However, Malcolm X articulated a set of civic ethical practices, based on the use of violence, which he presented as a strategy to neutralize white violence and as an alternative to demonstrating. The idea behind using violence was that if blacks wanted to be equal citizens, then they should use the civic practices that resonated with American white history. Malcolm argued that Americans, starting with American revolutionary heroes59, have always used violence to solve their problems

59 For instance, Malcolm often used the French and American revolutions to illustrate that whites shaped the western world via violent struggles, and they have idolatrized violent men was icons.

200

because violence produced a winner embodied with respect and freedom. This was especially true of civil rights struggles in the south. He argued, "It'll never get any better until our people in this country learn how to speak the same language that the racist speaks... And the language of the racist in the South is the language of violence. It's the language of brutality, and power and retaliation" (Malcolm [1964] 1992a: 169). In contrast to the rights project, Malcolm defined independence with ideas of freedom and respect. Nonviolence may win concessions from the state, but it did guarantee cultural change that defined blacks as equals.

We see in Malcolm's text the broad use of the term violence, which I will use to refer to any practice that induces fear, through bodily and/or affective violence, in other groups, causing those groups live in shame and accept their unequal social positioning. Based on this idea of violence, we can see how Malcolm argued that blacks could only obtain power by using "operational" and "figurative" forms of violence. By operational violence, I am referring to practices of self-defense and revolution rather than practices of nonviolence and civic inclusion. By figurative violence, I am referring to mastering techniques of self that organized the body to exhibit threatening and intimidating demeanors, such as expressing emotions like anger, hate or exhibiting a 'tightly' disciplined body (e.g. military or solider like). I used the term figurative violence to indicate how

A sample text is, "And you know what Patrick Henry had to do to get some respect: He said liberty or death. He didn't talk any kind of peaceful suffering or passive resistance. George Washington didn't talk peaceful suffering or passive resistance. No one here who is respected by whites ever tried to propagate some kind of peaceful suffering or passive resistance" (Malcolm [1963] 1971c: 116).

201

Malcolm suggested that blacks use the body, as a 'figure' that signified violence.

For Malcolm, the overall use of violence in the black nationalist project was

meant to eliminate white violence targeted at blacks. Rather than prepare the

body to absorb physical punishment and master affective response, Malcolm

approached racial equality by using black violence and the appearance of

threatening affective and bodily demeanors to neutralize the use of white

violence.

One civic ethical practice associated with an idea of operational violence

is 'fighting back'. As indicated in the previous chapter, southern whites,

specifically the police, sheriffs and Klan, beat, hit and hung black bodies to

inscribe white sovereignty into southern culture. Southern violence did not

'discipline' the black population, as in correcting or shaping black practices to

coincide with a set of southern norms. Therefore, Malcolm urged blacks not to

hesitate to resist this particular form of domination.

Let him know you're peaceful, let him know that you're respectful and you respect him, and that you're law-abiding, and that you want to be a good citizen, and all those right-thinking things. But let him know at the same time that you're ready to do to him what he's been trying to do to you. Then you'll always have peace" (Malcolm [1964] 1992a: 176-177).

Malcolm viewed nonviolence as an idealized civic practice that did not confront

the 'realities' of black life. Since the government failed to protect blacks, it was

time for authentic black men to fight back to create a respected black self. When

asked if he was training blacks on "how to use knuckle-dusters and guns",

Malcolm replied, "The black man in America doesn't need that much training.

Most of them have been in the army - have already been trained by the

202

government themselves. They haven't been trained to think for themselves and,

therefore, they've never used this training to protect themselves" (Malcolm [1965]

1992: 185). For Malcolm, the question was not that the black nationalist needed

to prepare or train black men to fight. Rather, the question was how use the

violence to obtain power.

A second civic practice associated with operational violence is revolution.

When alternative strategies of fighting back to stop white violence and creating

independent political and economic power centers failed to work, Malcolm used

discourses of black authenticity to construct a revolutionary black political agent

capable of using violence to end white control over black communities. Malcolm

dismissed any association of the rights political project of inclusion as a

revolution. Malcolm noted that rather that obtain power for blacks, their

nonviolent practices were cementing blacks in an inferior position to whites,

The only kind of revolution that is nonviolent is the Negro revolution. The only kind of revolution in which the goal is loving your enemy is the Negro revolution. It's the only revolution in which the goal is a desegregated lunch counter, a desegregated public toilet; you can sit down next to white folks - on the toilet (Malcolm [1963] 1989: 253).

Although desegregation symbolized racial equality, Malcolm argued real blacks

should expect material gains. There should be massive public investment in

black schools, elected black officials in black communities, and provisions to

guarantee blacks jobs. Unlike the mainstream civil rights movement's claims that

they represented the black revolution, Malcolm responded that, "Revolutions are

destructive and bloody. Revolutionaries don't compromise with the enemy"

(Malcolm [1963] 1971a: 137-38). The idea of using operational violence

203

preemptively was a technique of last resort. Nevertheless, blacks should be

prepared to fight if whites become more aggressive at preventing blacks from

controlling black communities.

In addition to using operational violence in place of nonviolent direct

action, Malcolm proposed blacks should shape their bodies in relation to

figurative violence. In part, Malcolm used discourses of black authenticity to

fashion a hyper-racialized body designed to be racially threatening. On the one

hand, the figurative violent body did not practice bodily mutilation. There were no

hair conking or hair activators. Yet, the black nationalist project's biggest

opposition to the rights projects' deracializing strategy was the idea that

managing affective responses 'repressed' authentic black anger that prevented

black nationalists from mobilizing black communities. Malcolm noted,

here the man has got a rope around his neck and because he screams, you know, the cracker that's putting the rope around his neck accuses him of being emotional. You're supposed to have the rope around your neck and holler politely, you know. You're supposed to watch your diction, not shout and wake other people up - this is how you're supposed to holler. You're supposed to be respectable and responsible when you holler against what they're doing to you... He dies with a responsible image, he dies with a polite image, but he dies. The man who is irresponsible and impolite, he keeps his life (Malcolm 1970: 21-22).

On the one hand, Malcolm suggested that affective responses, such as anger

and hate, signified black public renouncement of unfair treatment. He rejected

the rights project's techniques of good black self that limited emotional public

outbursts. Malcolm read the lack of affective response as blacks accepting their

inferior social positioning to whites. Training blacks to not hate was preparing

them to be docile and obedient to whites. In part, fighting back, acting hysterical

204

and publicly expressing one's anger was a strategy to communicate to other blacks that they were no longer to accept discriminatory treatment.

On the other hand, mastering figurative violence meant using affective responses that did not represent the black man as feminine. Malcolm noted that authentic black people "are tired of following these handpicked Negro 'leaders' who sound like professional beggars, as they cry year after year for white America to accept us as first class citizens" (Malcolm [1960] 1964: 314). The black nationalist political project would force, "every one of these civil rights organizations making these Uncle Tom Negro leaders stand up and fight like men instead of running around here nonviolently acting like women" (Malcolm [1965] 1989b: 126). The black revolutionary political agent did not cry out hysterically when hit, nor did his voice rise in pitch. He did not publicly get on his knees and pray for whites because the same bodily posture of kneeling down represented begging. Therefore, Malcolm suggested blacks were better off using emotions to gain power. This included appearing angry and fed up to convince whites that they are no longer going to take abuse. Malcolm argued that whites preferred working with the mainstream civil rights groups because they did not scare anyone (Malcolm [1965] 1989a: 173). Whites 'knew' they could integrate blacks without treating them as equals. Instead, Malcolm argued whites would only negotiate with blacks once they feared them. Thus, the black nationalist project, especially with the rejection of nonviolence, sought to shape a revolutionary black political agent who physically intimated whites to prepare blacks for revolutionary struggles against whites.

205

In addition to fashioning civic practices with operational and figurative

violence, Malcolm proposed other alternatives to demonstrating in favor of

challenging and confronting specific whites who 'had power'. Authentic blacks

'knew' who their enemies were. Malcolm portrayed the rights political project as

fighting the complexities and abstractions of power, in that they were fighting

ideas and cultural norms, rather than specific enemies,

The days of demonstrations and protests are over... a protest demonstration is an act that is a reaction to what someone else has done... we don't go to just to walk around the block with a sign. No, we go to get the one who harmed us - that's a demonstration, that's what's known as positive action... If we're going to demonstrate, it should be a demonstration based upon no-holds-barred" (Malcolm [1964] 1992d: 105-106).

The black nationalist project argued blacks should direct their protest practices

and resources at powerful and influential whites and material forms of white

power, such as white police and police stations, white landlords, white schools

and their school superintendents etc. In part, the black nationalist project

suggested fighting for influence locally rather than seek national reforms because

blacks were more likely enjoy the immediate benefits of a black sheriff, black

schoolteacher, and black home ownership.

Although Malcolm rejected the rights project's approach, he did support

and admire how SNCC drew from a grassroots project to organize black

Mississippians. Rather than an integrated struggle, Malcolm felt there should be

"racially paralleled" efforts - equal, but never intersecting. Malcolm commended

SNCC's efforts in rural Mississippi because, "They're not trying to integrate,

they're trying to get our people registered to vote, which is good, because it puts

206

them in a position to strike right at the base of all of their misery" (Malcolm [1964] 1992c: 114). Although Malcolm "misread" SNCC's organizing efforts in Mississippi (the MFDP was not an all black party, and remained an integrated geographically defined political project after SNCC declined), Malcolm used discourses of black authenticity to argue that SNCC was creating independent black power centers that did not have to submit to the white controlled Democratic Party. He identified their efforts to register black voters in relation to an independent black party because it was the first step in obtaining political power. Because a black only political party did not have to negotiate with white intraorganizational leaders, they would represent 'real' black interests and take care of black problems. Another authentically black civic practice supported by Malcolm was the idea of black capitalism.60 Black capitalism was a strategy that limited black mass consumption to black only businesses. The idea was that blacks could obtain economic power, thus creating black independence and power, because it "will eliminate the necessity of you and me having to act ignorantly and disgracefully boycotting and picketing some cracker someplace else trying to beg him for a job" (Malcolm [1964] 1968: 208).

Thus, Malcolm used discourses of black authenticity to articulate a set of ethical practices blacks should exhibit in order to distinguish a black identity that resisted black stereotypes, deracializing strategies, American nationhood and

Although I do not discuss the black capitalist project here, it was a contested project which drew support from some members of the rights project, such as Jesse Jackson and SCLC's Operation Breadbasket and black nationalists like CORE leader Floyd McKissick, it was also sharply criticized by more socialist inspired black nationalist groups, who referred to black capitalist supporters as "black pimps" (see SAV 48-7 "Total Control as the Only Solution to the Economic Problems of Black People")

207

white domination. We can see how the set of authentic black ethical practices

produced a new representation of the black political agent in how Malcolm

'remixed' Alain Locke's (1925) idea of the Harlem Renaissance's "New Negro" to

distinguish the normative idea of the authentically black political agent claims of

what counted authentic black practice. Malcolm associated the "old Negro" with

blacks who could not abstain from bodily practices indicating whiteness, and who

were not prepared for revolutionary and separatist practices. Malcolm portrayed

the rights project's good black citizen as a modern day house slave, who enjoyed

a better standard of living in relation to black slaves who picked crops and dug

ditches,

You have the modern counterpart of that slavery-time Uncle Tom... He doesn't wear a handkerchief around his head, sir. He wears a top hat. He speaks with a Harvard accent or a Howard accent... That negro runs around talking about how rich we are, how enlightened we are, how educated we are, or this is the free world or this is a free county, and at the same time he is begging the white man for civil rights and integration and all that kind of stuff he doesn't have (Malcolm [1963] 1971c: 89-90).

In contrast to the black nationalist project of producing an authentic black self by

recovering and preserving powerful black history, the rights political project is

associated with preserving an idealized American nationhood. The black

nationalist project approached American nationhood as a product of black

'repression', and to appeal to idealized American citizenship equated to rejecting

black culture.

Malcolm used discourses of black authenticity to construct an idealized

black political agent, a "New Negro", who rejected American nationhood because

historically, "He was the one that felt the brunt of the masters whip - and he

208

hated his master. If his master got sick, he didn't say, "Are we sick?" He prayed that his master would die" (Malcolm [1963] 1971c: 88). Malcolm's idea of the authentic black subject was made in relation to urban blacks, who suffered from lack of available jobs and were forced to live in public housing projects riddled with social vice. Civil rights leaders who are seeking integration for an elite segment of the black population excluded the northern urban blacks. Because authentic blacks are confined to the margin of society by whites and the rights political project, their only hope for recourse is situating their struggle outside of American cultural ideals of good citizenship. 'Real' black men, "He sees the entire world. And when he sees the world he sees that the majority of people on this earth are dark people and these dark people outnumber the whites" (Malcolm [1963] 1971c: 92). In part, Malcolm drew boundaries between the rights project an the black nationalist project based on identifying with an idealized nation-based civic identity versus an idealized black only identity, that crossed nation-state borders. THE BLACK NATIONALIST POLITICAL PROJECT AND SNCC

SNCC drew primarily from Malcolm's elaborations of the black nationalist project. In part, this was due some encounters with Malcolm, coupled with Malcolm's expanding influence and popularity in black political cultures. Before his death, Malcolm briefly interacted with current and future SNCC members. Student activists that were part of the Nonviolent Action Group (NAG), including Carmichael, sponsored a debate between Malcolm and Bayard Rustin in 1962. In 1964, John Lewis had a chance encounter with Malcolm in Nairobi, Kenya,

209

which led to SNCC bringing Malcolm to Selma, Alabama to speak at a 1965 voting rights rally61. Although the Nation of Islam persisted after Malcolm left the organization, and his subsequent death, their rigid system of bodily restraints did not appeal to all blacks. Subsequent black nationalist projects drew primarily form the ideas of abstaining from bodily mutilation, the appeal of racial separation, and Malcolm's idea of violent civic practices (operational, figurative) and alternative strategies for mobilizing black communities (black capitalism, independent black political parties).

Although SNCC slowly began to incorporate discourses of black authenticity into their mobilization strategies, the publication of The Autobiography of Malcolm X in 1965 represented a sharp change in the debate on how to proceed for racial equality. For example, a white civil rights activist Jack Minnis published a periodical titled "Life with Lyndon in the Great Society" as a critique of 1960s liberalism.62 The periodical was published between 1965-196663. Next to Bob Zellner, Minnis was arguable the most influential white member in SNCC, who helped oust John Lewis as chairman in favor of Carmichael, and remained part of SNCC's central committee and internal education program until the fall 1966 (Carson 1995: 236). Before the publication of Malcolm's autobiography, the periodical reported on issues pertaining to the relations between civil rights struggles and southern governments, and the

61 No transcripts exist on what Malcolm said to SNCC or any of Malcolm encounters and meetings with African leaders. For reference, see Carson 1994: 135-136

62 See RY Box 1 Folder Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee Life with Lyndon in the Great Society

63 No information is available for the number of issues printed, but it was a weekly publication, and part of SNCC's central committee's internal education program that would have been sent to all active political cells.

210

expanding southern military-industrial economy. This included topics on the local white supremacist groups' influence over local geopolitical legislature, the Southern State Industrial Council (SSCI) lobbying efforts and connection to northern industry, and corporations like General Electric that were manufacturing and supplying weapons in Vietnam. Starting in the November 1965 issue (Volume 1 #41), the tone and focus of the periodical changed from Selma and Vietnam to power. Minnis urged, "All civil rights workers and all black Americans who are interested in what we call 'freedom' should read this book... One of the reasons the book is important, is that when Malcolm X spoke, he leveled right down on his point, and he talked in the language of the people of the streets of the ghetto."64 As the students became aware of the black nationalist project, they distanced themselves from the logistics and networks of the power elite, to ideas that they needed to concentrate on 'real' black issues. The rights project spent considerable effort developing black civic vocabulary to debate civic topics such the workings of a local power structure. However, the black nationalist project proposed a competing political vocabulary that changed how SNCC mobilized southern blacks. Despite members of SNCC never mastering or adopting many of the Nation of Islam's authentic black practices, Malcolm X represented an idealized revolutionary black political agent to emulate. Next, I will compare how SNCC used discourses of black authenticity to change their approach to question of the racialized self, the question of whites in the movement, and the question of violence.

64 RY Box 1 Folder Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee Life with Lyndon in the Great Society, "Life with Lyndon in the Great Vol 1 #41 (11 November 1965)

211

The Question of the Racial Self

SNCC began to use discourses of black authenticity to define techniques of authentic black self. Until 1965, SNCC used discourses of good black citizenship to organize a set of personal ethical practices that allowed SNCC members to access and navigate through unfamiliar rural black communities. As noted in chapter 3, SNCC outlined how to practice good manners by defining how members should initiate contact with local blacks, the subject matter of discussions, and how to take second readings of what the local residents said. In addition to bonding with families and networking with potential allies, mastering techniques of good black self to limit black stereotypes was important to the activists overall safety. SNCC handed out security handbooks detailing personal practices to exhibit and to avoid. The security book indicated that SNCC volunteers should, "Try to avoid bizarre or provocative clothing or beards, be neat". When traveling through the community, volunteers should "Remove all unnecessary objects from your car which could be constituted as weapons (hammers, files, iron rulers, etc.) Absolutely no liquor bottles, beer cans etc. should be inside your car. Do not travel with names and addresses of local contacts" (RS 1-3). As a SNCC activist working in the 'field', it was important to not to appear racially threatening because it could save your life. SNCC activist had to navigate both black stereotypes and juridical-prohibitions that policed black stereotypes. It was important not to be in possession of any object that whites could define as a weapon. In addition to debunking black stereotypes, drinking alcohol or smoking marijuana violated Mississippi prohibition laws, which

212

gave police a reason to raid SNCC offices and freedom houses. In 1962 SNCC activists Bob Zellner, Dion Diamond and Charles McDrew were arrested on charges of criminal anarchy in Baton Rouge, Louisiana for possessing protest literature - a charge that carried a sentence of the death penalty (see Carson 1995: 53).

In part, SNCC's grassroots project was already practicing the idea of building independent black communities. Along with decline of SNCC members who associated nonviolence with Christian ideals, and the increase of secular activists not wedded to the ideas of nonviolence as Christian doctrine, SNCC focus on organizing practices based on a shared local geopolitical culture opened opportunities to use alternative discourses. SNCC's adoption of the black nationalist project was due to both the 1) geopolitical nature of organizing the rural south and 2) the shift in membership that was more open to using alternative discourses to organize and sustain the grassroots project. SNCC activists faced more intense forms of violence and experienced less change from the Civil Rights Act than SCLC's national efforts. Thus, SNCC became part of the black nationalist project once they began using discourses of black authenticity to reinterpret the question of using of violence, the question of working with whites, and why they were mobilizing black communities. Although the rights project idea of good black citizenship continued to dominate public discourse, the newer SNCC members had little history using discourses of good black citizenship, and the practice of organizing local black communities to

213

provide real and symbolic distance from the other parts of SNCC that still drew from the idea of producing good black citizens.

SNCC began rejecting the idea that mastering techniques of good black self provided the right way to approach racial equality. They questioned whether it provided southern blacks and SNCC activists security from violent whites. SNCC began using discourses of black authenticity to argue that blacks needed to exhibit personal ethical practices associated with an authentic black subject. In their 1966 pamphlet titled "The Story of SNCC", SNCC argued that "in the schoolroom and in all aspects of daily life, black people are denied access to their own culture; they are taught that white is right, white is beautiful. A reawakening of cultural identity - the rebirth of what might be called psychological equality - is essential" (RS 1-10). It was not the case that a black identity needed reawakening. SNCC used discourse of black authenticity to create a black political agent they claimed to represent. SNCC members, who never dressed conservatively anyway, began to grow out their natural hair, sideburns and, indeed, began to project the very personal appearance they previously saw as too dangerous. One SNCC member Bill Ware wore traditional African garb and grew a beard to signify his identification with pan-Africanism (see Carson 1995: 193).

We can see how SNCC changed their pedagogy once they adopted the black nationalist political project. Despite never organizing an equivalent to freedom summer, SNCC published new materials for black children and engagement calendars for black adults. In 1965, SNCC published a 51 page

214

booklet Negroes in American History: A Freedom Primer developed by Bobbi Cieciorka and Frank Cieciorka. Unlike good citizenship pedagogy, where students developed civic vocabularies and learned the history and ideas of the movement by practicing their handwriting and constructing sentences and narratives, Negroes in American History supplied a history of black struggles and practiced coloring pictures. Rather than represent an idealized history of the current civil rights struggles, the booklet sought to represent an idealized history of black resistance. The Cieciorka's noted the book was a "history about us" and as black students read the book, "ask why haven't I learned about Cherokee Bill, Nat Turner, Pete Sulam, Sojourner Truth and many others in this book who fought against being slaves, and fought for freedom in this country and weren't happy and satisfied". The Cieciorka's had asked this rhetorical question in response to general public education and the civil rights citizenship schools. Regarding the former, public schools did not teach black history, nor did they refer to the presence of blacks in history. As for the citizenship schools, they concentrated on the history of the civil rights movement under King's leadership and the importance of nonviolent civic practice. As noted in chapter 3, the citizenship schools discussed Gandhi and India, and the Montgomery Bus Boycott, not slave revolts or African anti-colonialism.

215

Second, the Cieciorka's replaced handwriting with coloring . Rather than organize a set of techniques to master by practicing good speaking and listening skills, then writing the words and constructing sentences on why good manners were important for the civil rights movement, Negroes in American History featured pictures for the students to color (see Appendix 1). The idea behind coloring the pictures was to learn a different set of racial practices associated with black resistance. For example, Images 1 and 2 represent black anti-slavery resistance. Image 1 represented a heroic and hypermasculine black man, posed like a comic book superhero. He stands tall, somewhat muscular, with his shoulders back, his eyebrows slightly frowned, and nostrils slightly flared, which signified a look of conviction. The man is holding a flaming torch, and the flames trace back to a large, four pillared house in the style of a southern plantation owner's house. Image 2 represented a child, with grown in 'afro', reading in the bushes out of sight from surveillance of the slave master. The child looks stoic, eyes fixated on the book with slight smile over his face. One the one hand, these images challenged southern revisionist historians claim that slavery was not as bad as some thought, and that many blacks preferred the stability and routine of slave life to freedom66. On the other hand, these images demonstrated the idea that blacks resisted by not being the good citizen. The images provided alternatives to the conservatively dressed and racially non-threatening

65 Similarly, Julis Lester has continued to publish children's books with African themes and black characters. Although the children books do not represent a black nationalist project, and since the civil rights movement Lester has noted that his black nationalism was not very sincere, they nevertheless represent the black nationalist project legacy amongst academics and pedagogy. See Lester 1976 on how he notes the paradox in hi writing a book on black power, but never fully embracing the idea.

66 For example of the southern revisionist perspective that downplayed the brutality of slavery and its impact on black Americans, see Lingley and Foley 1935, and Coulter 1950.

216

techniques of good black self. Authentic blacks looked menacing and threatening to project a powerful image. They were sly, cunning, and sought knowledge about 'blackness' rather than idealized American nationhood.

Images 3 through 5 dealt with the subject of contemporary rural black southern culture. Three images represent three distinct southern subjects - the black farmer, the white southern sheriff, and violence inflicted upon civil rights protesters. Image 3 is the black farmer plowing his fields. For SNCC's grassroots and black nationalist project, the rural black farmer represented their idea of the authentic black. He was the subject that needed to rise up and become a leader He is pushing the plow with his left hand and carrying a single shot rifle with his right. He is looking over his shoulder, were the farmers eyes direct us to his 'shack' - a log cabin without any windows or a door. The image creates the idea that he is looking over his shoulder, or 'watching his back', for bad whites, such as an arsonist or bomber. Image 4 represented a southern sheriff holding a gun in his left hand while he leans on a box marked 'ballot box'. The sheriffs piercing eyes and look of indifference signified how whites did not care if blacks won the right to vote. Image 5 represented a police officer, in either riot gear or state police uniform, hitting the protesters. The protesters were 'covering up' just as SNCC had instructed. One protester had his arms folded over his head to protect his ears and back of his head. The other protester is crouched over, using his back to absorb the blows. The common theme of violence binds images 3 through 5. The rural black farmer survived in a violent southern culture by carrying arms. The southern sheriff used violence to

217

reproduce an idea of white power. The police attacked and beat nonviolence protesters attempting to do create social change the 'right way'. The idea was that blacks had to first live and struggle for racial equality in the 'real' world, a world organized by violence and racial differences, before they could entertain ideas of a deracialized good polity.

SNCC also began publishing engagement calendars. The engagement calendars appeared after SNCC ceased publication of the Student Voice in 1967 (CC 2-18). Rather than tell the story of Montgomery, Birmingham or Selma, the 1967 engagement calendars presented images of who counted as an authentic black subject. The 1967 calendar included pictures of Malcolm X and images of southern black poverty - dirt roads, a black man literally holding his pot to piss in, and malnourished black children. The 1968 calendar included pictures of a black women with an 'afro' kissing a black baby, an anti-war demonstration, more pictures of southern poverty, urban poverty (black girl playing with white dolls on the front stoop) and coca-cola sign that read "Selma, Al. Progressive and Friendly". The images sought to define authentic blacks and authentic southern poverty. Malcolm X, and black women without processed hair, represented blacks who practiced authentic black personal ethics. Dirt roads, no plumbing, and little black girls learning to hate being black signified 'real' relations between blacks and whites.

In sum, SNCC used discourses of black authenticity to tell a black nationalist story of black resistance rather than idealized American story of the black civil rights movement. They sought to shape black ethical practices that

218

distinguished blacks from both black stereotypes and idealized good citizenship. Real blacks emphasized bodily techniques that whites found scary and intimidating. The idea was that stereotypical depictions of blacks as irrational and prone to violence could be used to blacks advantage. Despite using discourses of black authenticity to shape a black nationalist identity amongst many SNCC members, SNCC could not systematically organize any effective ways to mobilize southern blacks into ethical black nationalist subjects (see Chapter 5). The Question of Whites and Racial Purity in SNCC

The second major question SNCC faced was the question of how they should approach working with whites and the number of whites in the organization. The white question was not new by the time SNCC adopted the black nationalist project. Indeed, SNCC consistently struggled with questions of the ratio of whites to blacks, how to use white skills for mobilization, and sexual tensions between black men and white women. SNCC began as an interracial group fighting for black equality. They drew their pool of volunteers from students, both white and black, who worked intimately with one another on their respected programs. This was different from the virtually all black run NAACP and SCLC. Therefore, more opportunities existed in SNCC for both interracial tensions and possibilities. SNCC had used discourses of good black citizenship to deracialize the black/white tensions and organize interracial ethical practices. For example, an early-1963 memo from Julian Bond represented how he was

219

concerned about the ratio of whites to blacks. However, Bond did not argue for

fewer whites. Rather, he was concerned with not having enough good blacks:

We are attracting large numbers of northern and western whites, but do not seem to gather sizeable numbers of young Negroes... I emphasize college age, because I think we have a need for people with skills we commonly associate with young persons in college. By skills I mean typing, writing ability, speaking ability, organizing ability and thinking ability (EB 6-3)

The Bond text indicated that SNCC needed more black volunteers with good

writing and good speaking ability who could represent the organizations as good

black citizens. The quantity of black volunteers was not as important as the

quality. In 1963, SNCC still held on to ideas that it was important for rural blacks

to get used to whites, and vice versa, for interracial practices and political

coalitions to work. Furthermore, Bond associated the question of whites with the

need for good manners and increased discipline in the movement, "All of SNCC

needs to return - if we have slipped away - to a more serious consideration of

what we are about. We need to think more courteously of each other, others

outside SNCC and those who work with" (EB 6-3). For Bond, SNCC could

overcome the difficulties and cultural differences by emphasizing good mannered

social ethical practices. Bond's memo indicates that SNCC sought to settle

questions and debates within SNCC by placing the responsibility on SNCC

volunteers to master interracial social ethical practices.

Despite SNCC leaders, like Bond, emphasizing good manners and being

cordial when practicing interracial social ethical practices, the white question

persisted. By 1964, SNCC members compiled a list of problems stemming from

white-black interactions. Notes gathered from a SNCC meeting, labeled "Some

220

Aspects of Black-White problems as seen by field staff", indicated the following problems: 1) the "fears that Negroes have of being associated with an interracial group in Mississippi", 2) black "insecurities [to] whites superior education", 3) the "past racial incidents that are still bugging people, not solved by talking", 4) that blacks grew "up hating whites", 5) the question of not wanting "whites visible in places where people have not learned to trust Negro leadership", 6) the "obsession of Negroes with whites", and 7) the "sexual problems that racism produces" (CC 1-1). SNCC was finding it increasingly difficult to overcome cultural differences that were both racial and geographical. Many whites involved with SNCC did not realize they contributed to the problems they wanted to solve. In Mississippi, whites lynched, beat or killed blacks if they publicly associated with whites, especially black men and white women. Whites took for granted that their increased levels of education and prior leadership positions were not equally available to blacks. Southern blacks did not trust whites and would often tell whites what they wanted to hear to make them go away. 'Sexual problems that racism produces' referred to tensions between white and black females over black males approaching white females, and white females feeling that if they did not accept the advances of black males then they would appear racist. At this time, SNCC was still trying to solve interracial problems in discourse of good black citizenship. There was an idea that if whites could become more familiar and achieve a better understanding of southern black culture, the tensions between whites and blacks would decrease.

221

Thus, the white question was an ongoing problem. Since SNCC's

grassroots project deemphasized formal leadership, they placed the

responsibility to work out existing black-white problems on individual members.

What changed in SNCC is that a new group of leaders began using discourses of

black authenticity to interpret the problem of whites as the physical presence of

whites, and the solution that blacks could no longer work with whites.67 For

instance, by 1965 even seasoned SNCC activists, like John Lewis, who did not

support the black nationalist project began looking for new solutions,

Is it possible for negroes and whites in this country to engage in a certain political experiment such as the world has never yet witnessed and in which the first condition would be that whites consented to let negroes run their own revolution, giving them the necessary support, and being alarmed at some of the sacrifices and difficulties this would involve? ... Much as it may anger some die hard white, the fact that a negro sits down next to a white woman at a lunch counter and orders a coke and hamburger is still short of revolution (CC 2-18).

According to Lewis, the physical presence of whites was the problem. Racial

differences precluded whites from understanding what blacks 'really wanted'.

Whites believed integration counted as progress, while blacks wanted respect

and political power. Thus, some SNCC members began using discourse of black

authenticity to argue for the merits of racial exclusion without ever embracing a

black nationalist project. Therefore, discourses of black authenticity shaped the

changes SNCC made in organization to eventually become a black nationalist

group.

Carson noted that the activists involved in forming SNCC as a nonviolent and religious organization were gone by 1965, and replaced by secular members not committed to ideals of nonviolence and the importance of interracial cooperation (1995:192)

222

In 1966, SNCC held a meeting where members could outline their position

on working with whites. Carson noted that initially the majority of the 100

attendees rejected dismissing whites, but black nationalist members swayed

them through debate to agree to expel whites (Carson 1995: 240). For our

purposes here, the debate represented how discourses of black authenticity

shaped the white question. At the meeting, the black nationalist faction of the

SNCC argued that SNCC had to remove whites from the group if blacks ever

wanted to achieve power. In a position paper, Bill Ware argued that whites,

they can participate on an intellectual level. They cannot participate on an emotional level... By this I mean they can not participate where arms are necessary. They cannot participate where violence is necessary. They cannot participate where anger is necessary. They cannot participate where revenge is necessary. They can not participate where hate is necessary.68

We can see here how Ware used the idea of black authenticity to contrast the

black revolutionary agent with whites. Whites lacked the necessary affective

responses indicative to a revolutionary black subject. Because whites did not

endure racial discrimination, they were not angry enough to engage in revolution.

Nor were they capable of practicing violence or revenge on other whites. Only

the authentic black revolutionary subject embodied the hate and anger necessary

to exhibit violent practices. This differed from how SNCC used discourses of

good black citizen to argue that it was necessary for white involvement because

blacks and whites had to learn to work together and trust one another as a

condition for racial equality. At the close of the meeting, SNCC officially voted to

expel all whites from the organization.
