223

We can see how SNCC began using discourses of black authenticity to shape how they approached the struggle for civil rights. First, they stopped attaching the black self to American nationhood in favor of attaching the black self to the black racial group. Second, they increasingly defined the black movement as a "nomadic" struggle instead of a domestic struggle. Three, there was new focus on how to deal with blacks not considered 'black enough'. Finally, there shift in how they problemized the role of black women.

First, SNCC switched their mobilizing strategies from voter registration to organizing black only political parties to obtain power and govern black communities. In their pamphlet titled "What is Black Power and Why Do We Need It", SNCC used the idea that it was better for blacks to govern blacks: "They aim to take power at the local level first: to put a black man in the sheriff's uniform, make a black man tax assessor so he can see that taxes are collected to build better roads, schools, homes for black people" (RF 1-1). The idea of obtaining power shifted how SNCC mobilized blacks around ideas of integrating into the existing power structure to organizing black communities to challenge the legitimacy and authority of the existing power structure. When SNCC mobilized the MFDP, it did so around the idea of 'empowering' local impoverished Mississippians despite ones race. They organized the group by geopolitical and spatial-cultural location. The MFDP did not exclude whites. It was predominantly black, only four whites made the trip as delegates to Atlantic City, because whites refused or feared joining due to reprimands from other whites. MFDP was nonviolent and sought social change by challenging Mississippi's mainstream

224

Democratic Party to allow blacks into the party and renounce their opposition to desegregation. In contrast, Carmichael organized Lowndes County, Mississippi, after the 1965 voting act around the idea of an all-black independent party (see Chapter 5). Carmichael helped form the Lowndes County Freedom Organization (LCFO) in relation to the question of how blacks should organize without formal barriers, like literacy tests, taking up the majority of field workers time. The LCFO excluded whites from joining the organization because they wanted to build an independent all-black political party to challenge southern Democratic parties. They rejected nonviolent practices because of the local geopolitical context of rural Mississippi - specifically white violence. SNCC and the LCFO used the black panther as a symbol of their authentic blackness, and began posting armed guards at their meetings.

Second, SNCC began to portray American blacks as nomads who lacked a nation and civic belonging. The idea of being a nomadic meant that American blacks did not have a home, or nation, and therefore should not feel constrained by idealized American nationhood. Their juridical status as American citizens was a temporary status. Lacking geopolitical and territorial belonging, nomads organized racially in relation to similar global racial groups. The idea of blacks as nomads organized the migration back to Africa argument, which has been foundational idea in black nationalist thought since Delany and Garvey. SNCC drew from the nomadic idea, especially after visits to Africa, to argue that blacks could seek inclusion with Africa if the American struggles fail. In 1967, various SNCC members visited Africa. Carmichael met with African Algerian and

225

Guinean leaders and questioned why blacks were not migrating back to Africa (Carson 1995: 276-277). James Forman circulated to SNCC members a letter regarding the back to Africa question, suggesting, "We should return to Africa. We should use our skills where they are wanted."69 The back to Africa question represented how SNCC sought to attach SNCC with world struggles. Lacking geopolitical belonging, they used discourses of black authenticity to divide the world into struggles between racial groups. Drawing from Malcolm, SNCC argued blacks should model themselves after global racial groups. On the one hand, this included greater discussion of Native American and pan-African post-colonial struggles (see Carmichael [1967] 1969: 115). On the other hand, discussions between SNCC and the Oakland based Black Panther Party sought a relationship modeled after 'successful' communist groups. SNCC wanted the Panthers to serve as the military wing, and SNCC as the political wing, modeled after the Chinese revolution. The Panthers wanted to have a combined military and political operation, modeled after the Cuban revolution (see Lester 1976: 234).

Third, SNCC shifted their critique from the white racists to intra-group distinctions. SNCC began using discourses of black authenticity to paradoxically define what counted as techniques of an authentically black self and to criticize the how blacks continued to police and erect boundaries around the idea of who are real blacks. Racial exclusions within SNCC included whites as well as blacks associated with whiteness. They were especially concerned with the blacks associated with the 'Uncle Tom' and sought to control the black revolution for the

69 RY Box 1 Folder "SNCC and Lyndon and the Great Society"

226

benefits of whites. "White racists and uncle Tom's they create always try to divide us... we have to unite around the idea of independent political forces, independent economic forces" (RF 1-1). SNCC excluded blacks who did not conform to their idea of an authentic black political agent, including making intra-group distinctions on light versus dark skinned blacks. Carmichael gave a speech at Morgan State, an all black college in 1967, in which he criticized how southern blacks mimicked whites. He used discourses of black authenticity to argue that blacks should not hold debutante balls or organize fraternities and sororities. He noted that black fraternities were divided between light and dark skinned blacks: "So what did our brothers do - they turned around and formed something called Kappas, and only light skinned Negroes could get in...So the other dark skinned brothers, not to be outdone, set up Omega and Alpha" (Carmichael [1967] 1969: 111-112). Carmichael's text represented how the idea of bodily skin tone, rather than around just being black, hierarchically organized black fraternities, and was use of light skin to distinguish black elites. In 1967, the Student Voice published an 11-page booklet, titled "Black Body White Mind" that chastised the practices of black colleges, especially Howard, which "required you to submit a picture of yourself before you were admitted. Of course, the pictures established your color credentials. If white all right, if black get back; along with the 'palm test' - the palm of your hand had to come damn close to the color of your face in order for you to get in" (SAV 46). The text related the idea of privileging "light skinned" blacks to Howard's freshman orientation, which warned the black men "of the dangers of the surrounding community of northwest

227

Washington", the dangers of "block boys", and to avoid "parties in the black community". The message Howard sent, they argued, was "how to defend yourself from that savage, wild, uncivilized community."

Finally, how SNCC viewed black women changed. As noted in chapter three, black women resisted attempts to minimize their contributions and relegate them to secretarial duties. SNCC drew from how the Nation of Islam attached organized gendered relations. Black femininity was associated as inferior to black masculinity because they were prone to give in to passion or adopt 'immoral' ethical practices in order to gain social status. The Nation of Islam separated black women from all sexual and social relations with white men. Concerning white men, the Nation of Islam argued, "no white man has honorable intentions toward any black women" (quoted in Lincoln 1961: 172-173). Because of the history of rape in the slave system, and white men's failure to acknowledge their interracial offspring, white men were classified as 'sexual deviants'. White women also posed a threat to the purity of black women. The Nation of Islam argued that black women copied white women by "displaying their bodies, neglecting their children and abandoning their men" (quoted in Lincoln 1961: 172-173). Black women only achieved self-worth and an authentic black identity by remaining in the house. In their "Muslim Girl Training Classes", the Nation of Islam taught all Muslim women domestic practices of how to cook, manage the house and children, as well as good hygiene and medial practices, in order to accent their femininity.

228

Carmichael drew from these associations of black femininity, and placed the responsibility on black women to reject techniques of bodily mutilation and reject careers in social work. He suggested that if black women wanted to start being authentic black women, then they should stop being "...ashamed of your hair and you don't cut it to the scalp so that naps won't show?" Black women have to stop using Nadinola cream and mimicking the aesthetic practices of white women because black college campuses "are becoming infested with wigs and Mustangs and you are to blame for it" (Carmichael [1967] 1969: 121). In order for black women to master authentic black techniques of self, they should limit all practices that mutilated the body, in order to represent an idea of whiteness. Secondly, authentic black women did not become representatives of state administrative power. Specifically, black women should no longer seek to become teachers in segregated schools, and most importantly, should stop becoming social workers. Carmichael argued that going to college to become a social worker helps the state 'repress' poor blacks in exchange for the benefit of a few blacks. He asked if the reason why black women went to college was, "So that you can keep the kid in the ghetto school, so that you can ride up in a big Bonneville with [an] AKA sign stuck on the back?" (Carmichael [1967] 1969: 121).

In part, the critique of the black social worker represented the black nationalist rejection of how social workers have 'destroyed' black communities by breaking up black families. However, it also represented a critique of how black women had been 'closer' to whites than black men had, in their jobs as

229

domestics. The same practices of a domestic - maid, nanny - applied to the social worker: mastering techniques of a nurturing self to keep the white family (the state) healthy at the expense of the health of their own black family (black ghettos). However, Carmichael also contrasted real black women to black women who learned from their mothers to "Be sure to pick a nice-looking fellow with curly hair when you get married dear." Or if your lips are too thick, bite them in. Hold you nose; don't drink coffee because you are black" (Carmichael [1967] 1969: 121). SNCC formed boundaries between blacks based on limiting aesthetic practices associated with southern, 'waspy' whites in favor of mastering ethical practices associated with black authenticity. Authentic black women were concerned with the well-being of the black family and black community before whites and American nationhood.

In sum, the question of how to mobilize with whites preceded SNCC's adoption of the black nationalist political project. SNCC used of discourses of black authenticity to argue that racial differences were irreducible, and future racial struggles should be racially homogenous. The expulsion of whites accompanied an increased focus on intragroup, the good black/bad black binary, ethical practices. SNCC attempted to racially purify the black struggle by mobilizing around the idea of obtaining power rather than civic inclusion, using the idea of blacks as nomads rather than American citizens, and marginalizing blacks who did not conform to their idealized image of blackness. The Question of Violence

230

The last major question SNCC faced was what counted as authentic black civic ethical practices. The question of using violence meant using self-defense, but also flirted with the idea of violent revolutionary practices. SNCC usually posed the question of whether or not they should permit self-defense civic practices. However, the question of violence included how to use emotions in protest, what counted as acceptable forms of individual resistance, and the relationship between violence and strategies to secure control over black communities. SNCC's rejection of nonviolence did not mean a switch to violent revolutionary practices. What the rejection of nonviolence did was create openings for additional techniques of resistance and altered what blacks in the movement considered acceptable ethical civic practices, which subsequently shaped an idea of the revolutionary black political agent.

As others have noted, SNCC's rejection of nonviolence in favor of self-defense reflected, in part, the violence context of organizing in the American south (Zinn 1965, Carson 1995). Rural southern black resistance had a history of blacks attempting to organize around idea of armed resistance. In 1957, Robert Williams rebuilt a fledgling NAACP chapter in Monroe, North Carolina around the idea of armed self-defense. He recruited black laborers, farmers, domestic workers and returning WW2 veterans to replace the black professionals who feared reprisals from the white community if caught as a member of the NAACP (Williams [1962] 1968). Part of Williams claims that blacks should use violence to defend their homes and families was that part of being black was to be emotional and be violent, "We know that the average Afro-American is not a

231

pacifist. He's not a pacifist and he has never been a pacifist and he's not made of the type of material that would make a good pacifist" (Williams. [1962] 1968: 197). Williams wrapped self-defense practices around the idea that it is not possible for authentic blacks to be nonviolent. Most likely drawing on images of the African warrior, he portrayed 'nature' as programming blacks as a violent people. Therefore, he created the idea that violent and self-defense practices are a better fit for black protest.70

Part of SNCC's adoption of violent practices was how they associated the 'black farmer' as the idealized authentic black subject. In part, discourses of Jacksonian democracy have idealized "the farmer" as the rugged, independent, survivor who is the moral superior to cosmopolitan urban citizens. Situated in discourses of black authenticity, SNCC used the distinction that the black farmers geographical and symbolic distance from urban blacks as and all whites as represented an idealized black culture. The paradox of SNCC's idealizing southern black culture of delta Mississippi blues music, southern 'soul food71' diet, and agricultural labor, was that it represented the antithesis of the Nation of Islam's authentic black subject. Nevertheless, SNCC workers emulated black farmers. SNCC workers dressed in blue jean overalls, what farmers wore in the fields, to signify their identification with rural black culture. Since black farmers armed themselves and carried guns in the field, to protect their crops, family and SNCC workers living at their houses, SNCC field workers adopted the same practice of carrying guns for self-defense. Indeed, in 1964 Carmichael argued

70 Williams eventually took exile in China, practicing as a Maoist, by the mid 1960's

71 Soul food commonly refers to a group meal consisting of, but not limited to, a combination of collard greens, black eyed peas, catfish, fried chicken, cornbread and others

232

that it was not ethical to tell farmers to stop carrying weapons to protect themselves, noting that SCLC does not mobilize in the same areas or work with the same people that SNCC does (Carson 1995: 164). Therefore, the practice of carrying guns made SNCC workers more authentically black and legit when mobilizing in rural Mississippi and Alabama.

Drawing from the competing and idealized violent southern black cultures, SNCC urged blacks to master two civic practices as an alternative to nonviolent practices. The first practice was the idea of using figurative violence. Specifically, blacks had to master the art of a hyperracialized black subject to intimidate and frighten whites into making political concessions. It was important to let whites know that blacks were willing to use violence if necessary, to stop white violence directed at blacks. This was the idea behind using the image of the black panther to represent "the newly aggressive and courageous spirit of Negro demands it stands for black power" (RS 1-10). However, it was more efficient to stop white violence if blacks appeared more menacing. This included growing out the hair, getting bigger muscles and not dressing conservatively. It included a using more slang and 'broken English' - such 'ain't', like Julius Lester's book titled Look Out Whitey! Black Power Gon' Get Your Moma. It also meant using hate and anger to their advantage. They viewed southern whites as preferring to deal with nonviolent blacks because there was no chance of the whites getting hit or hurt. That is, good black citizens did not frighten whites, but hyperracialized black men did. Whites feared many of the stereotypes they created - such as the violent, oversexualized, and out of control black male. For

233

SNCC, the use of figurative violence as a personal and civic ethical practice was a strategy to obtain power through violence and intimidation, notably used in their work in Lowndes County, Mississippi and in the 'Vine City' neighborhood in Atlanta (see Chapter 5).

In contrast to the rights project's instruction that black activists exhibit good civic practices at all times - including when being tear gassed and imprisoned - SNCC used discourses of black authenticity to suggest practicing individual forms of resistance, such as 'sabotage'. Sabotage was a practice used by those confined to the margins of society. For example, the engagement calendars SNCC produced told the story of how blacks undertook individual forms of resistance when whites were not looking, "Our resistance struggle has taken many forms. During slavery it took the form of song and story and the ingratiating smile which disturbed the tranquility of many a white man. It also took the form of spiders in the soup, broken farm tools, accidental-on-purpose fires and murder."72 SNCC argued that sabotage practices disrupted the 'normal' workings of 'white society' that confined blacks to the margins. The idea was that the history of authentic black protest was resisting whenever and however blacks could. When in the presence of whites, black resistance was limited to nonviolent mass protest. However, when not in the presence of whites blacks could sabotage food, machines, neighborhoods in place of boycotts and marches. Because the acts of sabotage are intimate and personal, requiring working from the inside, sabotage was a practice reserved for blacks' who could work with whites without minimizing emotional hatred toward them.

CONCLUSION

The idea behind an authentic black self was to produce a racialized black body attached to a culturally pure and idealized racial group. This contrasted to how the rights political project shaped an ethical black political agent attached to an idealized American nationhood. We can isolate two sets of ethical practices that represented an authentic black self. The black nationalist project defined and ranked authentic black practices in relation how they associated personal, social and civic ethical practices with whites. The first techniques of authentic black self were the ethical bodily ethics of mastering bodily pleasures, appearance, and postures. Mastering techniques of authentic black self meant mastering a set of dietary practices that abstained from southern cuisine, which included pork, which distinguished blacks from their enslaved and segregated past. The black nationalist project associated consuming a southern idea with accepting and reproducing a marginalized past. Many of the southern foods that constituted a black soul food diet, including chitlins, catfish and corn bread, lack nutritional value, and were prepared from the leftover food not good enough for wealthy whites to eat. Authentic blacks were encouraged to eat more cow/beef, and lamb, cuisine associated with dietary practices of powerful groups, as well as Middle Eastern and African diets. Similarly, mastering techniques of authentic black self required refraining from bodily pleasures that jeopardized the productive black body. Blacks' who failed to refrain from social vice, including drugs, alcohol, produced an unproductive black subject associated with black stereotypes of not willing or wanting to work or take care of the family. Mastering

235

pleasures stabilized heteronormative black families, shielding blacks from police and social workers, who the black nationalist project isolated as responsible for destroying black communities. Blacks could obtain power and control their community only after they neutralized white governing practices associated with controlling the black populace. Thus, mastering dietary and consumption pleasures produced a more racially pure black subject capable of obtaining power and responsibly governing black communities.

In addition to mastering bodily pleasures, the black nationalist project used discourses of black authenticity to define a set of practices aimed at preserving and producing an authentic black body. The idea of preserving the authentic black body meant refraining from bodily mutilation practices that straightened black hair or using cream to lighten and smooth out skin tone. The black body should be presented in its natural state. Preserving the black body also meant mastering pleasures associated with interracial sex. For black men, interracial sexual pleasures differed from intra-racial sexual pleasures because of 1) the cultural ideals of beauty attached to whiteness, and 2) the taboo of white women that made them off limits to blacks, made interracial sex more desirable, and provided a distinction for increased social standing among other black men. Mastering interracial sexual pleasures preserved the black body because it insured an all black genetic lineage. The absence of white genes makes the American black skin darker, whose appearance is more similar to that of an original African skin tone and bloodline. The idea behind mastering bodily postures meant producing a hypermasculine black male body and a feminine

236

black female body. Black men were encouraged to practice bodybuilding and fighting. Women were encouraged to practice good housekeeping. The idea of mastering gender specific bodily postures was to discipline the body to produce an idealized black only community. Powerful black men governed the black public sphere while domesticated black women managed the private sphere. The gender divisions within the black community represented, in part, ideas of 'traditional' gender roles, but it also represented practices designed to maintain and reproduce black communities that were independent from whites and state surveillance.

The second set of authentic black ethical practices was rejecting nonviolence in favor of civic practices designed to obtain power. In part, the black nationalist project attached violence to an idea of authentic black civic practice by distinguishing operational from figurative violence. Operational violence was the practice of self-defense or violent revolution to obtain power, while figurative violence was the practice of exhibiting bodily postures and affective responses that represented and idealized black revolutionary agent to frighten whites into granting concessions. The actual practice of using violence was downplayed in favor of techniques of figurative violence that intimidated whites. Physical black intimidation sought to decrease white violence and scare whites into granting political rights. Situated in discourses of black authenticity, rejecting nonviolence also produced additional strategies of organizing independent black political cultures and civic practices of self-defense, sabotage, and revolutionary violence.

237

Thus, the idea of authentic black civic practices created independent black political cells to obtain power rather than civic inclusion.

Although the black nationalist and rights political projects shared similar ideas of good bodily postures, conservative dress, and gender differences, competing discourses organized these practices for different reasons. The black nationalist project used discourses of black authenticity to define personal ethical practices for the purposes of keeping whites away. If blacks were not engaging in any illegal practices, if they groomed the body and refrained from dressing the body in clothes associated with gangsters or pimps, then blacks would be free from the surveillance of white police and social workers. In contrast, the mainstream civil rights project defined a similar set of personal ethical practices to prepare blacks for desegregation and civic inclusion. The idea was that conservative styles of dress, good manners and postures represented a racially non-threatening black citizen capable of governing and participating in racially diverse and cosmopolitan communities. Both political projects accompanied an idea of black masculinity, however, the competing discourses shaped two different ideas of the good black man. For the mainstream civil rights project, discourses of good black citizenship constructed black men in relation to being equal to good white men. The ordering process was deracialized, but gendered - male first, then female. On the other hand, the black nationalist project used discourses of black authenticity to construct black men in relation black women. They used an ordering process was race first, and then gendered. The emphasis on black first opened up more possibilities for black women to occupy

238

positions of leadership in black communities, whereas the emphasis on male first confined black and white women to the margins of the movement.

Other differences between the competing projects were more explicit. The primary difference between the competing political projects was producing a self attached to an idealized American nationhood or producing a self attached with an idealized and exclusive racial group. The mainstream civil rights project used discourses of good black citizenship to produce a black political agent attached to an idealized American nationhood. This meant instructing and training blacks on personal, social and civil ethical practices that represented the idealized good black citizen. It downplayed the importance of racial identity in favor of producing an idea of good citizenship, and accompanying set of good civic practices, for blacks and whites to exhibit. In contrast, the black nationalist project rejected the idea of a good black citizen in favor of organizing the black community as a racial group first. The idea was that racial groups, not individual citizens, made social gains and produced social change. Individual blacks could not be considered equal to whites if blacks, as a racial group, were inferior to whites, as a racial group. Therefore, the black nationalist project used discourses of black authenticity to define practices to purify the black self from associations with whites, in order to produce an authentic black self distinguished from whites and other black political projects. The improvement of the black community took preference over practices of civic inclusion.

Additionally, the competing projects organized mutually exclusive affective practice. The black nationalist project argued that authentic blacks expressed

239

their emotions because emotions were associated with the 'truth'. Unlike cognition, which is susceptible to manipulation, expressing emotions exhibited blacks' real reaction to discrimination and unfair treatment. They approached emotion as something that was natural and spontaneous in relation to the immediate context. Therefore, if one is unhappy, their real or authentic reaction should be unhappiness. The black nationalist project emphasized the expression of affective responses through bodily postures - yelling, screaming, kicking, pointing, fist waving, violent jerking the body, cringing the face etc. The black nationalist project used discourses of black authenticity to reject the rights project's idea that blacks should master affective responses in relation to white, and black adversaries. Because being angry and outraged were considered the natural and real black response to discrimination, the black nationalist project defined techniques to limit or manage affective outbursts as practice that denied what it meant to be black. Since the rights project used techniques of good black self to limit emotional outbursts in relation to nonviolent practices, encouraging emotional outbursts cemented ideas of violence and irrational practices with the black nationalist project. The idea was that authentic blacks used emotional responses to communicate their rejection racial discrimination, while good black citizens used rational dialog as part of their rejection of racial discrimination.

SNCC's adoption of the black nationalist project was related to questions of why and how groups become more 'revolutionary'. I have argued that the adoption of the black nationalist project resulted from how SNCC's grassroots project organized blacks and whites around the idea that they shared a common

240

geopolitical culture, thereby using discourses of good black citizenship to attach blacks and whites to a shared group of 'Mississippians'. Once SNCC made this move to organize around specified political groups located in shared local geopolitical cultures, rather than ideas that blacks and whites are generally 'Americans' and belong to the broadly defined nation-state territory, it provided openings for competing discourses of black authenticity to mobilize an idealized black only racial group in local geopolitical cultures. SNCC fully adopted the black nationalist project once they used discourses of black authenticity to mobilize a racially pure group that rejected associations with territory, becoming nomadic, and identifying with similar political projects and global racial groups.

SNCCs adoption of the black nationalist project can be broken down into stages. The first change in SNCC was how their grassroots project distinguished itself from the rights project by attaching the self to a political group within southern local geopolitical culture. We see a definitive change in mobilizing strategy in the shift from the rights project to the first transitional period. When they drew from the rights project, SNCC used sit-ins, and nonviolent practices in the Freedom Rides, and the Albany movement modeled after SCLC desegregation campaigns. During the first transitional period, when they began using a grassroots project SNCC organized the 1964 Freedom summer, resulting in the MFDP party. They instructed nonviolent civic practice, but also organized interracial political groups defined by Mississippi geopolitical culture.

The most important shift, which split the civil rights movement into two irreducible political projects, was the shift from the grassroots rights project to the

241

grassroots black nationalist project. Here, SNCC used discourses of black authenticity to racialize the political group identity. Between the grassroots rights and the grassroots black nationalist periods, we can see a definitive shift in social and civic ethical practice. The grassroots black nationalist period featured social ethical practices of racial separation to organize all black political parties and political cells, and by 1966 expelled all whites from the organization. In the grassroots black nationalist period, SNCC members rejected nonviolent civic practices in favor of practices of self-defense. Unlike interracial and nonviolent practices of the rights and grassroots period, the grassroots black nationalist period attempted to organize all black parties that practiced self-defense in Lowndes County and Atlanta, Georgia.

The final shift was from the grassroots black nationalist period to the nomadic black nationalist political project. In the final shift, SNCC used discourses of black authenticity to define an idealized black only racial group attached to global struggles. Unlike the three previous periods, the shift to a black nationalist group rejected all territorial associations, in favor of a nomadic identification. American blacks were defined as lacking ideas of home and belonging, and were encouraged to identify and model subsequent strategies after global racial groups, specifically African and Middle Eastern, who shared experiences as racial minorities dominated by whites and used violent practices to fight for power. The Nation of Islam's black nationalist project was based on governing local geopolitical black cultures, mostly in Northeastern urban American ghettos, and establishing symbolic identifications with African colonial

242

struggles. Malcolm's post-Nation of Islam political work, and SNCC's struggles under Brown's leadership, represented attempts to organize around an idealized black nationalist model. Malcolm and SNCC under Brown's leadership made the nomadic identification that the Nation of Islam would or could not make (see Chapter 5). SNCC's only political work at this time was an attempted merger of SNCC and the Black Panther Party, which failed, and suggestions that blacks migrate back to Africa.

The next and final chapter is a case study on how the rights projected attached the idea of good black citizenship to the Voting Rights Act, which represented a shift in American political culture, and how it contributed to the split, and subsequent decline, of the civil rights movement. I concentrate on how the Voting Rights Act changed the subject and object of each political project. Specifically, I contrast 1) how the competing projects differed in directing their political practice at the national or local level for continued reform, 2) how each political project organized political programs and 'measured' black citizenship, 3) how each political project approached civic ethical practices, and 4) how they approached economic reform and urban revitalization.

243

CHAPTER 5: THE 1965 VOTING RIGHTS ACT AND BLACK POLITICAL PRACTICE

The last chapter left off explaining the impact of the black nationalist political project on the civil rights movement. It explained how the black nationalist project arose in response to the rights projects deracializing strategies, and how SNCC used discourses of black authenticity to produce a normative ideal of a revolutionary black political agent that contrasted to the rights political project idea of the good black citizen. In this chapter, I will analyze how the events surrounding the 1965 Voting Rights Act, including the Selma Movement 1963-1965 until the "end" of the movement in 1968, in order to understand 1) how the 1965 Voting Rights Act changed the object and subject of black civic practice and 2) the legacy of each political projects normative ideal of the black political agent. In essence, this chapter will show the importance of understanding reciprocity of cultural change and the development of social policy and political legislation on political practice. The rights project's normative idea of good black citizenship was the dominant representation of black citizenship attached to 1965 Voting Rights Act enabling it passage. However, the post-Voting Rights Act culture also affected subsequent civil rights strategies, as well as state juridical and police practices. Thus, the point of the chapter is to understand how political cultures influence the passage of major laws, legislation or political events, and the subsequent impact those major changes had on the civil rights movement civic practices.

244

The Voting Rights Act was a major piece of legislation that represented both the impact of the civil rights movement on American civic culture and the major turning point in how citizenship rights were distributed and interpreted. The Voting Rights Act ended all restrictions on voting for juridical citizens. The rights project's idea of basing citizenship on individual good citizen ethical practices rather than skin color helped displace the race-first distinction practices, and influenced the broader American and civic governing practices. Indeed, this change in political culture was not limited to blacks, whites or native citizens. The 1965 Immigration Act replaced the practice of basing immigration on country of origin in favor of basing immigration on skilled labor, to ensure the admittance of the "good immigrant".73

Previous texts vary in their explanation of the importance of the Selma movement and 1965 Voting Rights Act. Fager (1974) used C. Vann Woodward's thesis on a new southern class structure to argue that Selma was important because it represented how the rise of a new southern class, which was racially tolerant and politically moderate, displaced the old agrarian southern elites that controlled southern life. For Fager, the Voting Rights Act represented the end of a larger transformation in the southern class structure, which allowed blacks to begin the process of integrating into a new southern society. David Garrow (1978) argued that the importance of Selma and the Voting Rights Act were

73 For information on how the Immigration Act changed American immigration, see King 2000 and Hing 2004. Additionally, the Asian-American groups, especially the Japanese and South Koreans, have benefited the most from the US need for high skilled labor, producing what sociologist refer to as the brain drain and the model minority myth for Asian American groups (see Prashad 2000). On the other hand, the Immigration Act has negatively affected Mexican immigrants, who fulfill menial and agricultural labor, and generally fulfill the scorn of American Immigration (Garcia 2002).

245

simply the instrumental gains of winning new rights. Therefore, Selma represented the end of a long struggle geared around winning the right to vote. Doug McAdam (1999) representing the political process tradition, argued that the Voting Rights Act signaled the closing of a political opportunity. For him, the movement subsequently declined not because voting rights were the goal of the movement, or because a new southern class emerged that was more accepting of blacks. Rather, the movement declined because the black movement lacked 1) inter-organizational cooperation and 2) violent adversaries that prevented the movement from constructing their democratic and nonviolent frames to communicate their grievances with the rest of America.

There are major shortcomings for each of these explanations. First, there is no reason to believe that social class determines the degree of racial tolerance. Wealthy and middle class whites racially discriminated against blacks just as often as poor whites. Indeed, the rise of the White Citizens Council throughout the south was due to white professionals, lawyers, businessmen, and government administrators distinguishing themselves from the associations of rural poverty and "white trash" attributed to the Ku Klux Klan. Second, it makes little sense to reduce political legislation to measurements of instrumental gains. In light of how the cultural turn in sociology, which highlighted the many ways social movements are important i.e., solidarity, empowerment, etc, illustrated that legislation has broader political and cultural implications. Third, the idea of a political opportunity closing after the 1965 Voting Rights Act neglects how the Johnson Administration continued ties with the movement on a proposed 1966

246

Civil Rights Act (eventually passed in 1968) that tackled housing discrimination. Furthermore, each of these explanations placed too much emphasis on the piece of legislation, assuming that changes in political structure created cultural changes. The previous four chapters have argued that the civil rights movement's symbolic citizenship claims produced a cultural change that allowed for the passage of the Voting Rights bill. Our task here is to understand how reciprocity existed between cultural changes and political acts and legislation.

Based on archival data (movement reports, manuals, meetings, correspondences) and historical comparative methodology, this chapter uses Selma and the 1965 Voting Rights Act as a case to understand how the competing political projects symbolic citizenship claims changed American political culture, state governing practices, and subsequent civil rights political practices. The Voting Rights Act main impact was that it made the struggle for the right to vote and organizing around voter registration practices obsolete. Although the rights project continued to use discourses of good black citizenship to organize their citizenship schools and produce good black citizens, the main functions of the citizenship schools and community centers was instructing blacks how to beat the literacy tests. The competing projects and cultures were open to new questions of urban revitalization of black ghettos, slums and neighborhoods, and questions of whether to pressure the nation-state or local state levels of government for economic rights. Additionally, I propose that we understand the decline of a social movement separately from the outcomes of a political project. The movement declined for a number of reasons, including new

247

and more intense forms of state police practice and the failure of competing civil rights groups to work together. However, the rights and black nationalist political project remained important in shaping a black identity politics that emerged on the American political scene in the late 1960s and early 1970s. I argue the black nationalist project forced the rights project to consider the good black/bad black normative distinction, which the rights project could not, because they were unable to deracialize a claim of racial authenticity. Although the black nationalist project retreated to the margins of national public sphere, primarily to the subaltern publics found in local urban cities, its lasting legacy provided the implicit argument undermining subsequent black political practice - is it black enough? Next, I will provide a brief history and overview of the events leading up the Voting Rights Act, and points of contestation between the rights project and grass roots project, which opened up ontological space for the black nationalist project.

HISTORY AND OVERVIEW OF THE SELMA MOVEMENT AND 1965 VOTING RIGHTS ACT

The Selma movement began to take shape in 1963, when SNCC's grassroots project began organizing Dallas County's black community. An important part of SNCC's grassroots project was the practice of collecting and documenting information on local blacks, especially relations between local blacks and Selma's police, government, and economic workings. They did this in order to produce a working knowledge of the area that helped inform civil rights organizations of the challenges each local geopolitical culture posed. This

248

included SNCC's use of the existing black gangs in Selma, especially the gang's networks within the black community, and high school students to help with voter canvassing, registration and organizing weekly citizenship training meetings.74 In 1963, SNCC reported that only 0.9% of Selma's black population was registered to vote, despite comprising 57.7% of Selma's overall population.75 Because blacks were the numerical majority in many rural black-belt counties, SNCC began their "One Man One Vote" campaign to increase the number of black voters. SNCC argued that, "the Negroes of Selma and Dallas County are politically impotent without the vote. They have no way of influencing the choice of those who hold public office, even though they are in the majority" (RF 1-1). Thus, the idea that the right to vote would provide the foundational practice to gain political power emerged at the start of the Selma Movement.

While the struggle to produce voting rights legislation was important for gaining political power, the political projects symbolic citizenship claims organized how they made claims for voting rights. SNCC, as well as SCLC when they arrived in 1965, used discourses of good black citizenship to instruct blacks how to master civic ethical practices. As police violence and brutality increased, the movement brought in medical personnel and physicians to instruct blacks how to control the body when tear-gassed. One medical doctor instructed how to respond to tear gas: "You think you're blinded and the danger is you'll panic and rub your eyes. Don't rub your eyes. You'll be blinded temporarily. Don't

74 SAV48-4 "Survey: Current Field Work, Spring 1963"

75 SAV48-2 "SNCC Special Report: Selma Alabama 26 September 1963"

panic. Additionally, the movement instructed blacks on how to manage being trampled by horses, by not running from the horses but "try to grab the reins and stay in front of him."77 However, SNCC noted that protecting the body was difficult when being trampled by a horse because police were also using tear gas, and that practicing bodily postures of the limp position was useless when kicked by a horses hoof. Thus, despite the increasing influence of the black nationalist project, the Selma movement continued to train blacks how to master good black citizenship practices.

That SCLC and SNCC last worked together in Selma is important to understand why and how the movement split and declined. They both used discourses of good black citizenship that 1) attached the idea of the good black citizen with the images of the black political agent that was being integrated into the national polity and 2) represented the symbiotic relationship between the rights and grassroots political projects. Because both political projects used discourses of good black citizenship, the good black citizen was the symbolic citizenship claim attached to the Voting Rights Act. The symbiotic relationship between the rights and grassroots project was also important because it allowed the civil rights movement to pressure the state on different levels. The rights project focused their civic practices on the nation-state level, to induce the national government to enforce existing rights and produce new rights to protect blacks from racial discrimination. In contrast, the grassroots project sought to organize blacks locally, to train them how to integrate and pressure city, county

and state governments to enforce desegregation laws. When the rights and grassroots projects worked together, they were able to organize broad movements, like Freedom Summer, Birmingham and Selma.

While the civil rights movement used discourses of good black citizenship to discipline and organize black civic practice to pressure the state on different levels, the different political levels - federal, state, county and city - differed on how to police the movement. The difference was rooted in the competing "new south" and "old south" revitalization projects. The idea behind the new south revitalization project was to produce a cosmopolitan civic image and set of practices that 'modernized' the south, by embracing a service sector economy, limiting the political influence of rural counties, and minimizing racial tensions. In contrast, the old south revitalization project attempted to strengthen the south's existing, but declining, industrial and agricultural bases with corporate tax cuts and suppressing black and white wage earners, in order to produce southern autonomy from northern cultural influence and federal legislation. Whereas the new south project attempted to integrate the south into the broader American governing structure, and in turn benefit from federal money and investment, the old south project sought southern autonomy from the federal government and northern cultural influence. The primary difference between the southern revitalization projects was how they policed the civil rights movement. Although neither revitalization project sought racial equality, the new south project sought desegregation and limited the use of violence on protesters. The differences and struggles between the competing projects became more important after

The old south project organized police practices around the idea of violence and containment. For the old south, the idea of violence encompassed physical violence, verbal harassment, and figurative bodily violence. In 1963, the Dallas County police chief Jim Clark organized a 'semi-professional' police force. In contrast to a professional police force that was organized bureaucratically and received institutionalized training on techniques to handle crowds and keep order, Clark's semi-professional police force was more of patronage based private security team, which received no professional training and was loyal to him. They were autonomous from the authority of the Alabama State Police and Selma's public safety director. Because Americans have the right to form independent militias, Clark never violated any state or federal laws. When SNCC began organizing Dallas County blacks in 1963, they documented how Clark had deputized between 200 and 500 white males into a "special vigilante force." Clark's semi-professional police dressed in old army fatigues, army helmets and boots, and attended SNCC meetings holding guns and electric cattle prods.79 Secondly, the idea of containment practices refereed to isolating black protesters in certain geographical segregated spaces. Policed restricted blacks from leaving the black neighborhoods, and forced them to enter through the back doors of the segregated courthouse building. The Selma movement, therefore, escalated their civic practices in January of 1965. They began a series of marches to the Dallas County courthouse, looking to isolate situations where they could situate good black civic practices against old south police practices. On the one hand, the new south police practices, led by Public Safety Director Wilson Baker, used surveillance practices to watch and manage the marches, by forcing them to march 2 or 3 to a group, with spaces in between each group of protesters. The idea behind surveillance practices was to limit any momentum and excitement generated by the protests. On the other hand, the old south police practices, led by Jim Clark, harassed, arrested, and eventually began using physical violence. The 'tipping point' for the old south project was when civil rights protester Amelia Boyton berated Clark over his treatment of blacks, eventually hit him, baiting Clark into beating and dragging her a block.80 The irony of that situation was Boyton's lack of self-mastery over her affective and bodily practices helped the movement. In this case, the gendered assumption of black women helped 'excuse' her lack of self-mastery and hysterical response, thereby maintaining the good black/bad white binary. THE MOVEMENT SPLITS: THE RIGHTS PROJECT VERSUS THE BLACK NATIONALIST PROJECT

The passage and events surrounding the Voting Rights Act had immediate impact on the civil rights movement's civic practices. The movement as a whole faced the question of what to do next. For the rights project, the questions were whether the right to vote was enough to obtain political power, and what would replace voting as the dominant issue to organize movement programs and attract new black activists? Indeed, these questions permeated throughout SCLC's Dallas County Project. In a 'Church Service Pamphlet' asking for donations of books, green stamps and money, the project's director Shirley Mesher wrote "But what was behind the need for the vote - oppression and a never ending cycle of 85 CC 1-7 Catherin Clarke's notes on the Montgomery March

257

poverty - remains... And the vote is meaningless unless people have a choice. In light of continued forms of black-white inequality, the rights project began to focus more on, in Marshall's terms, the economic and social rights of impoverished blacks and whites. In contrast, after the Voting Rights Act, SNCC abandoned its grassroots project in favor of black nationalist project, and pressured local governments to enforce existing political and economic rights.

To understand how the movement 'split', we need to understand how the two competing political projects 1) approached citizenship and 2) how the Voting Rights act shaped the question and practices of what to do next. First, as I argued in chapters 1-3, the rights project made symbolic citizenship claims that produced a deracialized black self, which represented idealized American citizenship, in an effort to attach the black self to the nation-state. That is, the rights project used ideas of liberalism that isolated each individual and their set of rights/duties as an indicator of the basis of membership and exclusion. In contrast, the black nationalist project attached the black self to the racial group first, then the nation-state. That is, they rejected the idea of individual rights in favor of the idea that citizenship is the property of groups - primarily racial and ethnic groups. Therefore, the differences between the rights and nationalist project approach to citizenship represented the difference, in part, between a liberal and multicultural approach to citizenship.

Although the competing political projects split the movement, some activists never fully embraced either project 100%. However, since the rights and black nationalist project were the two dominant positions producing 86 CC 1-7 "Church Service Pamphlet"

258

influential normative ideas of black political agents, black activists gravitated toward one pole or the other. In other words, activists tended to cluster at either extreme, staking out positions in this debate. For instance, the NAACP's national office, the Urban League and SCLC's governing committees definitely supported deracialized strategies, but were made up of many supporters who did not fully embraced the use of nonviolence. Even King used armed bodyguards to protect him from the increasing death threats. How activists responded to SNCC's transition to a black nationalist group was even more nuanced. SNCC's local projects in Atlanta, Pine Bluff, and Lowndes County increasingly used discourses of black authenticity to organize all black groups in relation local setbacks, and the perception that the rights project national campaign excluded blacks bounded by urban ghettos. After Selma, SNCC activists who did not agree with the all black organizing joined SCLC's SCOPE program or dropped out. Lester (1976) noted that many in the Atlanta project, including himself, struggled with the black nationalist position. Coincidently, an influential white activist in SNCC, Jack Minnis, led the political coup to out John Lewis, because many in SNCC saw his religious conviction as interfering with SNCC's revolutionary potential (Carson 1995). Minnis rallied SNCC members to replace Lewis with Carmichael, because of Carmichael's socialist and secular leanings. Despite the apparent hesitation and reservation of some activists, they nevertheless took positions within this political debate. Therefore, my focus will remain on how projects drew from competing discourses to organize normative symbolic citizenship claims and how these claims marked political projects.

259

In addition to the different approaches to citizenship, the Voting Rights Act shaped the questions, and subsequent practice, of what to do next. Each political project had to adapt their set of ethical practices in a political field that no longer practiced blatant racial discrimination, such as voter restrictions or legal segregation. In contrast to civil rights historiography that conflates the movements split with its decline/end, and views the Selma to Montgomery March as the conclusion to the movement, I will show how the split between the political projects did not end the movement. Indeed, the rights project continued the struggle in Chicago over economic issues of open housing, and sought to produce an economic bill of rights with a national "Poor Peoples Movement" (see Garrow 1986: 431-624, Ralph 1993, McKnight 1998). Additionally, I will show how the Atlanta Project and the Lowndes County Freedom Organization (LCFO) used discourses of black authenticity to organize civic practice in relation to questions of urban revitalization and the black sovereignty. The remainder of this section will analyze the differences in each political projects 1) strategy of local versus national organizing, 2) the pedagogy of movement programs, 3) civic ethical practice and 4) urban revitalization practices. Local Organizing Versus National Organizing

After the Voting Rights Act, the rights project sought integrated civic practices, based on coalition of groups stratified by race and issues, which sought influence on the nation-state level. The rights project continued to use a discourse and language of rights to make claims that Americans needed an 'economic bill of rights' that would "guarantee a job to all people who want to

260

work and are able to work" and "guarantee an income for all who are not able to work" (King [1968] 1986: 67). However, they shifted their strategy from voter registration to using the black vote as a way to form political alliances. The rights project argued that blacks should form political alliances based on what is best for blacks and the political party, without giving up black political independence as a voting bloc or influential political group. Blacks were to be a political group no different from a labor or political advocacy group. This differed from SNCC, as both a grassroots and black nationalist project, which favored pressuring local geopolitical cultures (e.g. the city, county and federal state level) and organizing black only racial groups. After the Voting Rights Act, SNCC produce a memo tiled "How to take advantage of the 1965 Voting Rights Act". They argued, "A large segment of the national power lies in the Congressional seats from states and districts that have from one forth to one half of their voters Negro... registration concentrated in a selected number of states and congressional districts should produce a marked change in the political complexion of the country."87 This included running black candidates in primaries and elections to unseat southern senators and congressmen who sat on key committees.88 Whereas the rights project felt that pressuring the federal government was the best approach, in part because the federal government could supersede local governing practices, evidenced in the Birmingham and Selma movements,

SNCC focused on removing bad whites from powerful and influential positions in local government and congressional seats to produce more immediate change.

For the rights project, the most important post-Voting Rights civic ethical practices to master were the affective responses in relation direct action and coalition politics. While nonviolent direct action rested on the ability to master bodily postures and affective responses, coalition politics required mastering the affective style of rhetorical practices. It was important for blacks to master a rational style of speech because it helped establish mutual understanding and benefits for the involved political groups. In part, the style of rhetorical ethics of coalition building were the antithesis of Habermas's rational-critical discourse, where strength of argumentation is decisive (see Habermas [1962] 1991). Ideally, the rights project sought to replace direct action with coalition politics. The rights project used direct action to force whites into positions of negotiation. By using coalition politics, the rights project hoped to bypass the first step and enter directly into negotiation practices. In an influential 1964 essay titled "From Protest to Politics", Bayard Rustin argued the civil rights movement would have to consider how to act on the larger political (federal) stage without direct action. He noted that as blacks began to obtain political power through voter education and registration efforts, "a tactical shift is being effected. Direct action techniques are being subordinated to a strategy calling for the building of community institutions or power bases" (Rustin [1964] 1971: 112). Rustin argued that coalition strategies allowed the movement to organize blacks they were registering into a political voting bloc. Although the black vote did not hold that

262

much power nationally, it could alter election outcomes in southern states where blacks made up a sizable minority population. Black voting blocs meant neither Southern Democrats nor Republicans could ignore blacks or take them for granted.

Although many black leaders, specifically King, did not fully embrace the idea of abandoning direct action in favor of coalition building, the idea of pressuring the federal government and forming interracial coalitions dominated the rights projects in Chicago and SCLC's Poor Peoples Movement. The rights project sought to combat urban poverty in Chicago. They settled on housing issues, which was the dominant issue in the 1968 Civil Rights Act. The rights project attempted to use Chicago as a case that represented 'dual-housing' market that denied good black citizens the right to buy housing in more affluent and middleclass white neighborhoods. SCLC networked with local Chicago civic organizations, including the Chicago Council of Community Organizing (CCCO), the Catholic Church, academics and the CFL-IUC labor union. Additionally, the rights project used this same discourse of rights issues to argue why impoverished citizens needed protection from poverty. They sought to recruit blacks, whites, Mexicans, Puerto Ricans, and Native Americans based on the idea that they all shared common economic hardships. McKnight described this last phase of the civil rights movement as a "populist crusade calling for the redistribution of economic and political power" (McKnight 1998: 23).

In contrast to the rights project strategy of forming coalitions and using local movements to pressure the federal government into producing new rights,

263

SNCC directed their political practices at the local level. This change of political practice and local strategy in SNCC produced two semi-autonomous political groups, the Lowndes County Freedom Organization (LCFO) and the Atlanta Project, linked by common discursive strategies that tied both to a single political project and with SNCC's central committee. The Atlanta Project, also called the Vine City Project, formed after the Georgia Legislature refused to allow Julian Bong to assume his newly elected position in the state senate because of his anti-Vietnam war position. The Atlanta project represented how SNCC's semi-autonomous political cells adopted black nationalist practices. Although the Atlanta project was the largest in terms of activists and influence over the SNCC's central committee, there was also SNCC projects in Pine Bluff, Arkansas and Lowndes County Alabama who were also adopting black nationalist practices. As far back as 1963 in Pine Bluff, for instance, SNCC worker, NAACP member and black Muslim Robert Whitfield sponsored and encouraged stand-ins, sit-is and the picketing of a McDonald's restaurant to protest the continued practice of segregated diners.89 In 1964 in Lowndes County, Alabama, under the organizing efforts of Stokely Carmichael, blacks began adopting black nationalist practices of forming independent black political parties, which resulted in the formation of LCFO. Below, I will focus primarily on the Atlanta Project, with some reflections on how they adopted political strategies from the other political cells. For the purposes of this dissertation, the Atlanta Project provides the best case of how the black nationalist project political practice and organizing strategies in

SNCC, and especially the Atlanta Project, wanted to prove to blacks that they could master techniques of authentic black self while interacting with whites and still represent the interests of the black community without compromise. Therefore, the Bond seating issue provided an opportunity for the Atlanta Project to declare their break from the rights project and implement black nationalist practices. After Selma, the rights project continued using discourses of good black citizenship to organize citizenship schools and role-playing workshops. Their main attempt at establishing citizenship schools throughout the south was through the Southern Community Organization and Political Education (SCOPE) program. SCLC modeled the SCOPE program after the 1964 Freedom Summer. The SCOPE project sought to continue the pedagogical practice of instructing good black citizenship, and even sought to include training sessions on public health and the body, specifically "information on medical, dental hygiene, nutrition education, and birth control information" (CC 3-3). The idea behind SCOPE was to take advantage of the impending 1965 Voting Rights Act and register thousands of blacks to vote in order to change southern politics.

Although SCLC's citizenship schools were intertwined with the movement's ability to attach the idea of good black citizenship onto the southern black polity, the Voting Rights Act denied the citizenship schools their manifest function of voter registration and creating new political rights, which brought in teachers, students, and economic funding. The Voting Rights Act outlawed literacy tests and poll taxes. SCLC used the idea of passing citizenship tests as main reason to attend the schools. Armed with the right to vote, SCLC had to convince blacks that the citizenship schools were still useful. SCOPE, therefore, functioned more like the pre-citizenship school program that measured black

270

citizenship in terms of number of black voters registered rather than the quality of citizenship practice. This is not to say that ideas of good black citizenship became less important. Indeed, the black nationalist challenge had the opposite effect on the rights project. It meant that without a practical obstacle like literacy tests, the SCOPE program lost a very important recruiting and organizing issue to get blacks to attend their schools.

A second post-Voting Right effect on the SCOPE program was the shift in types of volunteers. The post-Selma SCOPE recruits desired more action and confrontation rather than the mundane labor of the political organizer. Movement programs, such as citizenship schools and Freedom Summer relied more on volunteers willing to teach, instruct and correct personal and social ethical practices rather than concentrate on mastering civic ethical practices. Indeed, the restlessness of the recruits prompted a memo from SCOPE'S program director Hosea Williams that indicated SCOPE was a voter registration project and that "this is not a time for demonstrations" (CC 3-3). Furthermore, the rights project's strategy of appealing to the federal government and new involvement in the north, which limited their presence in southern communities, also affected the rights project surveillance and disciplining practices of the volunteers. This led to the abuse of SCOPE funds, and lackadaisical volunteer labor. Consequently, the SCOPE project increased infighting amongst SCLC staffers and community leaders, as well as FBI surveillance on the SCLC (see Garrow 1986: 440-442, 451-452).

271

Similar to SCLC, SNCC was never able to organize anything on the scale of the 1964 Freedom Summer Campaign. SNCC's split from the other political projects limited their capacity to organize large-scale movement programs. The overall infrastructure and organization of Freedom Summer was based largely on SCLC's Citizenship School model (see chapter 3). Although SCLC continued to invite SNCC to participate in citizenship schools and workshops, SNCC did not take part. SNCC also refused to use the SCLC citizenship model, in part, because SNCC's black nationalist project wanted to organize the black community without the black church, and viewed the citizenship schools as too white.101 Despite the split, SNCC continued to plan and attempt new schools and community centers designed to help blacks at the local level. This included 1) tutorial programs 2) domestic management programs 3) community center programs and 4) medical self-care programs.

First, SNCC's grass roots and black nationalist project designed tutorial programs, which focused on school-aged children, to supplement existing public school education. In the summer of 1965, SNCC set up five tutorial centers, 227 workshops, and enrolled 943 students.102 Rather than report cards that graded students work on a scale of A - F, the tutorial program rated how the students mastered personal practices from a scale of "below average to above average". The tutorial program evaluated the students eagerness to learn, attentiveness,

Civic Practices and Black Leaders

The rights project continued to instruct black activists how to master nonviolent civic practices. They used workshops to train blacks how to protect the body, absorb pain, and master affective responses while marching and picketing. During the Chicago campaign, for example, SCLC held workshops before each march through white neighborhoods. Whites responded to the marches by throwing rocks, bottles, and burning cars. However, the Voting Rights Act and SNCC's adoption of the black nationalist project changed how they organized two forms of civic practices: 1) the increased importance of the black leader and 2) the use of affective stimuli in public protests.

First, SNCC changed how they trained activists to be political leaders. In contrast to SNCC's grassroots leadership training, which emphasized mastering social ethical practices necessary for establishing networks amongst various

275

black groups, SNCC emphasized the role of black leaders providing the example for other blacks to follow. SNCC used discourses of black authenticity to attach a sense of idolatry to black leaders. In some respects, this is how SNCC viewed Malcolm X - as an authentic black man who mastered techniques of authentic black self, and whose 'body and soul' were worthy of emulation. We see this change in a manual produced by Jim Forman in 1967 titled "On Political Organizing" that was distributed to activists attending the 1967 meetings.107 Forman wrote this manual in an attempt to increase the amount of self-discipline within SNCC, which he saw as lacking and the major reason for SNCC's declining relevance in the civil rights movement. For Forman, SNCC activists had to focus on mastering personal ethical practices, so that other blacks knew how to model their own practices.

Forman defined the good leader as one who mastered personal ethical practices of hard work. More than any other practice, the quality of the leader's labor determined how affective he/she was. Forman argued that there was a set of characteristic inherent to all black organizers and leaders. The characteristics inherent of a "good organizer" included creativity, a self-starter, a self-pusher, has a goal in mind, does not expect others will follow a phony lead, and pays attention to detail.108 A bad leader was one who could not master the work ethic of a self-starter. He failed not because of resistance or reluctance of the black community to be involved, but "from taking on too many jobs, inadequate

SAV48-5 "On Political Organization" by Jim Forman (for the Feb 1967 SNCC Meetings) SAV48-5 "On Political Organization" by Jim Forman (for the Feb 1967 SNCC Meetings)

planning or record keeping, and sometimes downright laziness."109 The idea of mastering personal ethical practices legitimated authentic 'strong' black leaders, who were necessary to govern black communities. Leaders provided a physical and symbolic presence that represented the unity and strength of the black community to whites. In contrast to the notion of charismatic leadership associated with the black preacher-turned-activist, which organized how SCLC selected leaders (see Morris 1984) authentic black political leaders lead by practice. That is, they show they are willing to do what it takes, including the mundane and banal work of political organizing, to set an example of how things should be done. Forman made no mention of the importance of social ethical practices when working with others. Rather than let volunteers set up and run political meetings, the black leader assigns administrative duties to members. The black leader should transfer "certain skills, information, contacts, training and association" that 'he' posses to others.110

The lack of reflexivity between organizer and organized heightened the sense of personal responsibility of black leaders, which Forman argued should be constantly examined. He argued the, "The acid test of effective leadership by the political organizer is his willingness to submit his role for examination, evaluation and criticism... naturally, he must be willing to evaluate his own efforts, to admit mistakes, to correct them and move on, for there is work to be done."111 Good leaders examined the self because their practices reverberated throughout the organization and affected the civic practices of others. The second change in civic practice was the use of affective stimuli to provoke anger and 'moral shocks' in blacks and whites. Although the idea of a political demonstration was not the civic practice of choice for the black nationalist project, the Atlanta Project continued to protest, albeit with style of civic practice that represented their break from the rights project and rejection of American political policy and cultural norms. For example, they organized a picket line to protest the drafting of black men for the Vietnam War. For the black nationalist project, overcoming black apathy was just as important as overcoming white oppression. Urban Revitalization

We can observe the differences between local and national organizing, civic practice and training programs in how the rights and black nationalist projects approached urban revitalization. For SNCC, urban revitalization became important because 1) the southern revitalization projects effect on the economy, political relations and built environment and 2) the increasing importance of the urban black subject, which began to replace the rural black subject as the representation of authentic blackness. Regarding southern revitalization, blacks were looking to be included in the federal subsidies, especially Johnson's War on Poverty programs. The south was in the midst of an economic boom received and a disproportionate amount of federal money for transportation, defense industries, and new technologies (Sale 1975). Indeed, SNCC based their 1965 boycott of the new Hammermill Paper factory in Selma on disrupting the new south revitalization project of producing a modern civic image. Based on the Hammermill Boycott, the Atlanta Project challenged the idea that Atlanta was the city 'too busy to hate', and noted that "Atlanta, as a city, is quite vulnerable and all of the myths about 'progressive Atlanta' can be destroyed with just the

As early as 1964, SNCC noticed that Harlem stores were full of products to treat the problems of cockroaches and rat bites.118 Based on his observations of Harlem's black political culture and visits with the Harlem group HARYOU, Bill Hall associated the idea of urban renewal with "Negro removal". He proposed that blacks wanted to remain in black communities, therefore, black urban renewal practice should be directed at improve existing black communities by tearing down the slums and replacing them with public housing, rather than move blacks to another part of the city.119

The issue of urban revitalization became important to the rights project after they failed to organize the Chicago Movement around the very broad and abstract issue of 'ending slums'. Although the rights project identified problems specific to urban blacks, such as the breakup of the black family, overcrowded and substandard schools, refusal of hospital admission and bank loans, they settled on housing discrimination. In part, the focus on housing discrimination was due to the existing black civic organizations in Chicago already working on that problem. However, housing discrimination fit the pattern and strategy of associating idealized citizenship and deracializing practices with a political issue. Housing discrimination was wrong because it denied good blacks who deserved and could afford better housing the opportunity to better themselves.
