In contrast to the black nationalist project, the rights projects focus on the idea of housing discrimination did not tackle the issues of how to govern and 'care' for the black neighborhood. The rights project focus of providing access for blacks to the more affluent neighborhoods represented the projects broader idea of civic integration.

The rights and black nationalist projects differed in how they approached the ghetto's physical environment. The physical environment is important to the process of urbanization because it is the point at which urban planners, residents, and existing meanings all converge to define new spatial-cultural meanings (see Lefebvre 1991, Gottdiener 1994). The black nationalist project sought immediate gains in the urban black community by focusing on the quality of the physical environment, and whose responsibility it was to maintain the property. Since blacks lived in slums controlled by white slumlords, the black nationalist project directed questions of how to improve the environment by enforcing existing housing codes and clearing slums in favor of public housing. The black nationalist project distinguished a body-environment relation experienced by urban blacks but not by urban whites. The most important point was the presence of rats and other disease-carrying varmint. An important authentic black practice was purifying the black body by limiting bodily mutilation. This included rat bites. The Atlanta project documented the conditions of the physical environment in the black ghettos, and Markum Street in particular:

282

"There are pockets of dilapidated, rodent infested unheated dwellings scattered throughout the predominant Negro area city. Here live people who are sapped up by parasitic slumlords, lying peddlers, cheating insurance men and election day only politicians."120 Thus, an important part of establishing the black nationalist project in an area was improving the immediate black neighborhood to show that they were capable of governing and organizing better than both the rights project and the white political infrastructure.

The rights project also identified the squalid living conditions of blacks living in American ghettos. Their approach to urban revitalization was similar to their approach to voting rights legislation, in that they did some local organizing, but the main emphasis was on getting the federal government to intervene. The Chicago movement organized some local protest practices, such as Bernard Lafayette's youth program to demonstrate the danger of lead paint and lead poisoning to the city (Ralph 1993: 48). Nevertheless, the Chicago Movement preferred civic practices that raised national awareness about the plight of blacks living in American Ghettos and Federal support for new housing. Similar to his practice of going to jail to bring media attention to the Birmingham and Selma movements, King moved his family to the North Lawndale section of Chicago, into a building Corretta Scott King described as dirty and smelling of urine. Because of the buildings poor condition, King and other members of the Chicago Movement took 'trusteeship' of the building. They dressed themselves in work clothes, grabbed shovels and brooms and began cleaning up the building. They also used a 'mild' rent strike, and withheld rent until the landlord agreed to fix the 120 MS - "Untitled/No Author - Atlanta Project Draft for housing Project"

283

building. Ralph (1993) noted that these attempts failed because the slumlord was an 80-year-old man who did not conform to an idea of a greedy and overzealous slumlord, and that the Chicago Project did not comprehend the realities that many of the ghetto slumlords were also black. In addition, King only 'lived' in Chicago Wednesday thru Saturday, so this protest practice appeared somewhat disingenuous to Chicago activists.

Therefore, instead of focusing on specific slumlord practices, the rights project focused on the system of economic exploitation that allowed slumlords to control black urban areas. The Chicago Movement organized the East Garfield Park Union to End Slums (EGPUES). They called upon two slumlords, who owned over 30 apartment buildings, to attend a mass meeting with ghetto residents. The slumlords fielded questions from audience members, and rather than change, the slumlords assigned blame to the bankers and mortgage lenders who would not lend them the economic capital to fix up the homes. When the audience's affective responses transformed into personal attacks on the slumlords, King reminded that audience that the system was on trial, not the two slumlords. After a picketing and a performing a rent strike, the slumlords and renters negotiated a deal, the 'Condor and Costalis Agreement', which limited the amount of control landlords have over property, and bestowed some property rights to tenants (see Ralph 1993: 64). The collective bargaining agreement changed the relations between landlords and renters, and each of their relations with the property. Slumlords were required to perform prompt and routine maintenance on the buildings. Residents were required to follow specific rules

284

governing "tenant behavior". We can see how the collective bargaining agreement shared responsibility between tenant-slumlord represented the rights projects emphasis on mastering personal ethical practices, and why they trained southern blacks on domestic housekeeping practices. For the rights project, being good tenants equated to other good black ethical practices. Good tenants were neat, organized, and paid their bills in a timely manner. Consequently, good tenants deserved good housing, and it was the obligation of slumlords to provide good housing. Thus, the rights project attached the idea of good black citizenship to black economic rights (property rights) in Chicago.

In contrast to how the rights project directed their civic practices at cultural norms and national centers of power, the Atlanta project drew from the black nationalist approach that sought specific places and individuals to protest. The Atlanta Projects' solutions to fixing the urban environment were not to devise a system of shared and reciprocal responsibility for the maintenance and upkeep of the homes without black ownership. The Atlanta's project solution differed in three ways. First, they selected the black section of Markham Street and the Vine City neighborhood. Vince City was the 'known' part of Atlanta that represented some of the worst housing conditions in the city. Indeed, even SCLC leaders King and Abernathy noted how Markham Street was some of the "worst conditions ever seen."121 Rather than wage an abstract fight against 'poverty' or 'housing conditions', the Atlanta project outlined specific slumlord practices, 'named names' and sought to confront specific landlords. FROM A CIVIL RIGHTS MOVEMENT TO IDENTITY POLITICS

No single cause ended the civil rights movement. Indeed, scholars have traced the many reasons that prevented the movement from achieving additional rights and why the movement ended (see Blumberg 1984, Haines 1984, Garrow 1986, Eyerman and Jamison 1991, Carson 1994, McAdam 1998).133 Yet, the many explanatory models center on two related themes. One explanatory theme credits the changing relationship between the movement and the state. Because of movement's anti-Vietnam war stance, and the antiwar movement in general, the state increased the quantity and quality of its police surveillance, and decreased working relations on passing subsequent civil rights legislation. Additionally, Democrats seeking to offset the number of white voters deflecting to the Republican Party, which made Nixon's "southern strategy" and dreams of a permanent republican majority based on a neo-conservative-religious right political alliance possible, devalued the southern black vote. The second theme credits the fragmentation of movement, including the disintegration of the

132 SAV 46 "News of the Field #5" 23 March 1966"

133 Also see chapter 1 for an analysis on how the movement's decline is based on each conceptual model that led to the rise/birth of the civil rights movement.

289

movements unified collective identity and the inability of various groups to work together. Thus, rather than review the already exhaustive explanations on why the movement declined, I will focus on how each of the political projects struggled over the question of the racial authenticity and the black political self. That is, while the movement ended, the political projects and their normative ideals of what counts as black citizenship continued, as did differences in the political level - national versus local geopolitical culture - that each normative ideal remained politically effective.

The question of the authentic black self was the question the black nationalist project introduced to the civil rights movement to reject deracializing strategies and any practice or process associated with whiteness. Although the rights project dominated civil rights discourse, primarily by incorporating the juridical and grassroots projects under a single discursive umbrella, they never dealt with the good black/ bad black normative distinction. In essence, the black nationalist project forced the rights project to answer how a black civil rights movement could represent blacks in the public sphere when they willingly excluded the majority of blacks that did not conform to idealized good black citizenship. Although the rights project continued to use discourses of good black citizenship to insist that race is not a determinate of good citizenship, they still needed a black political base to push for anti-poverty legislation. Thus, while the movement declined, it left us with a legacy of competing and irreducible normative ideals that remain implicit and underlie contemporary black political representations.

290

Black Authenticity and Decline of the Atlanta Project

The question of the authentic black political agent changed, and then shattered SNCC's civic practices. Indeed, who and what counted as authentically black became an internal point of contestation that SNCC activists drew from to solve seemingly minor squabbles between SNCC activists. The Atlanta project used discourses of black authenticity to outline ethical practices that established limits of who and what qualified as acceptable black practice. The ethical practices included both a rhetoric and set of bodily practices that defined what counted as an authentic black political agent. The idea that every practice was subject to evaluation in relation to idealized blackness created boundaries within SNCC. SNCC activists erected boundaries between the semi-autonomous politic cells and SNCC's central committee, as well as within SNCC's central committee. The transformation of an issue over a missing car into a discursive struggle over who represented the black nationalist project led to the dissolution of the Atlanta project. In 1966, SNCC central committee inquired about missing money and a missing 1965 Dodge Dart assigned to the Atlanta Project. SNCC member Cleveland Sellers used discourses of black authenticity to describe the act of a black man stealing from a black organization as "be the most unwarranted act any true brother could commit. With this, and this alone, one could questions where your loyalties and sincerities were"134 At first, Ware responded to Sellers claims that he (Ware) was not a 'true brother' by indicating that Sellers was overreacting because of a "personal hang up"

Global Nomads and the American Black Community

The question of black authenticity further crippled SNCC's central committee. SNCC's central committee, especially under the leadership of H Rap Brown, used discourses of black authenticity to attach ideas of whiteness and black 'race traitors' to geopolitical divisions, ultimately severing SNCC from the American black community. Although SNCC attempted to associated blacks with a world colonial struggle, and organized programs around a black colonial subject, blacks defined themselves as American citizens and no longer viewed SNCC as a serious or practical civil rights group. After the dissolution of LCFO, Atlanta Project, and the Mississippi based MFDP separation from the central committee based on their continued geographical and interracial focus, SNCC followed in Malcolm's OAAU model and situated their focus on global struggles. SNCC used discourses of black authenticity to define their shift from a nation-state based social movement to a global movement in terms of the east/west dichotomy. Since SNCC attached whiteness with anything associated with the west, including nation-states and capitalism, they associated themselves with the

293

African, Asian, and Latin American postcolonial struggles.136 This had a number of effects on SNCC's final attempted programs. SNCC became sanctioned as a Non-Governmental Organization (NGO) rather than a civil rights organization.137 They declared that they would practice as a human rights organization against colonialism, that they would strengthen their opposition to the Vietnam War with draft resistance, and planned to aid in the industrial development of Africa.138 They also increased their focus on black separation practices. Modeled after the Freedom Summer, LCFO and Atlanta Project movement programs, SNCC planned a "Peoples Sewing Center" to "to stimulate politicize, and channel all lasting energies of welfare mothers, black workers, [into a] viable revolutionary-conscious cadre".139 They also suggested an "Agrarian Reform Program" to unite black sharecroppers and tenant farmers in order to establish a common means of production, land purchases, and political education classes.140 Finally, they proposed a "People's Medical Center" to provide free health care to poor black people, and would form an all black political party to protect blacks from

Outside of the formality of operating with NGO status, SNCC never again managed to organize or implement any political program into practice after the dissolution of the Atlanta Project. SNCC completely broke from their grassroots past and used the idea of black authenticity to attach SNCC as part the white/nonwhite global and post-colonial struggles. They no longer organized movement programs around idealized black rural or urban subjects. Instead, the black colonial subject became the new authentic black political agent. Designing programs to provide free health care and survival practices when faced with severe military-political repression did not resonate with American black audiences. While American blacks were aware and supportive of the plight of Africans, and vice versa, American blacks were still American citizens, with new political rights and immediate concerns about economic discrimination, voter oppression and urban decay/revitalization projects. Furthermore, within a global framework and world capitalist system, SNCC could not bypass the nation-state to appeal to other supranational organizations like the UN. The power of the UN to intervene rests on the shoulders of its most powerful nation state members -especially the United States. Although SNCC, just like Malcolm, appealed to African nations for international support, African nations were still learning how to govern their own populations and how to negotiate their position in the Cold War.

Multiculturalism and Racial Authenticity: The Rights Project and Identity Politics

The rights project maintained their dominance over the civil rights movement because of their symbolic citizenship claims that stressed national integration and their ability to incorporate the juridical and grassroots political projects under a discursive umbrella of good black citizenship. Until the black nationalist challenge, especially the idea that blacks should organize around an idealized revolutionary political agent, the rights project did not have to answer questions about the good black/ bad black binary. That is, no one publicly challenged the deracializing strategy. Noting that black power was a "slogan without a program", King attempted to emphasize the idea that blacks could still master techniques of deracialized self without negating blackness or a black political identity, and even suggest replacing the slogan 'black power' with 'black consciousness' (King 1968: 18, 31). Thus, in an attempt to argue that the good black/ bad black distinction was 'not anti-black', we can identify three themes in King's later text. 1) Civic diversity allowed blackness to flourish more than cultural singularities. 2) Deracialized and integration practices provided more opportunities to obtain power than racial authenticity and separation practices. 3) The black nationalist authentic black revolutionary agent reflected whiteness based on the bad black and bad white's shared use of violence to obtain power.

First, King argued that the rights project and deracializing strategies promoted an idea of civic diversity, whereas the black nationalist project

296

produced homogenous "cultural singularities". I use the concept cultural

singularities to refer to a set dogma-like political practices that seeks to cleanse

internal differences while rejecting external associational practices. For the rights

project, we get a sense that the black nationalist authoritative claims to represent

blackness became the point the rights project would have to overcome if it were

to continue its political influence. The rights project colonized the idea of 'black is

beautiful' by attaching the idea of the pre-discursive and 'natural' black body with

deracialized personal ethical practices,

Our children must be taught to stand tall with their heads proudly lifted. We need not be duped into purchasing bleaching creams that promise to make us lighter. We need not process our hair to make it appear straight. Whether some men, black and white, realize it or not, black people are very beautiful... The Negro, through self-acceptance and self-appreciation, will one day cause white America to see that integration is not an obstacle, but an opportunity to participate in the beauty of diversity (King 1968: 123).

Influenced in part by the black nationalist rejection of black body mutilation, the

rights project argued that blacks should master personal body ethical practices

that projected a more natural black appearance. Good black citizens mastered

bodily posture, but they did not have to straighten their hair or even out their skin

tone. A neat, but not fake, black appearance produced a new idea of the black

self, which could only help the process of racial integration rather than promote

racial separation. Second, the practical danger of cultural singularities was that it

organized irrational civic practices by depriving blacks of their 'free will' to choose

among the best alternatives. King argued that organizing political support around

black candidates based on skin color rather than a candidate's political platform

was irresponsible and reckless, and emphasized that "The basic thing in

297

determining the best candidate is not his color but his integrity" (King 1968: 49). The danger of producing a cultural singularity was that blacks could be controlled by unscrupulous black leaders, similar to the 'Uncle Toms' who sold out the black community for their own personal gain, which placed blacks in the same or worse situation that they found themselves in. In contrast, civic diversity, including racial and economic diversity, as well as multiple public spheres, provided blacks will more choices and opportunities for success.

Second, the rights project rejected the notion that civic integration and obtaining power were discursive and strategic antimonies. The idea behind integration, King argued was power: "Integration is meaningless without the sharing of power. When I speak of integration, I don't mean a romantic mixing of colors, I mean a real sharing of power and responsibility" (King [1969] 1986: 317). Mastering good black ethical practices was a more effective way to obtain power than by separating. It gave blacks access to better jobs and political positions they otherwise could not get. Indeed, the idea of sharing power with whites was even more preferable because it established a new political culture not based on racial domination or skin color as markers of distinction, but a political culture based on upholding shared values of good citizenship. Thus, a deracialized project that disassociated black stereotypes meant obtaining power while being a better black citizen, albeit a black citizen who continued to be culturally 'black'.

Finally, King argued that the black nationalist project reflected the type of violent civic practices associated with the same bad whites the rights project

298

sought to displace. In essence, King used the same rhetorical practice as the black nationalist project of associating whiteness with undesirable practices. He argued, "One of the greatest paradoxes of the black power movement is that it talks unceasingly about not imitating the values of white society, but in advocating violence it is imitating the worst, the most brutal and the most uncivilized values of American life" (King 1968: 64). The rights project's deracializing strategy was based on the good black/ bad white binary, which aligned good blacks and good whites with idealized American citizenship at the expense of bad whites and bad blacks. King saw the black nationalist project as legitimizing and cementing black stereotypes to black citizenship. Rather than producing a normative black political agent capable of displacing whites, the rights project viewed the black nationalist project as reproducing the undesirable qualities of bad whites. Since bad whites maintained their control over the south with anti-democratic and violent practices, the black nationalists, at best, could hope to secure very limited, and unstable, political rule over isolated black areas. The deracialized good black citizen was the preferable alternative that allowed blacks to keep a black identity and still be good American citizens.

These three themes indicate how the rights project had to divert much of their resources and focus on maintaining their dominant position by fending off internal challenges to their idea that blacks should master deracialized techniques of self. They were trying to stake out a position that would satisfy their good white liberal allies, while preventing the spread of the black nationalist project to other parts of the south, and the increased fractioning of the movement

299

groups. The NAACP, Urban League, as well as influential figures like Rustin took out an ad in the New York Times denouncing black power. Rustin's refused to support a "Free DC Rally" because the DC committee would not include labor or religious groups.142 As noted above, SNCC refused to meet with the president or partake in SCLC's citizenship schools. Because they would not waver from their strategy to deracialize what counted as good American citizenship, since it had worked to produce the Civil Rights and Voting Rights Act, the rights and black nationalist project remained in a political standoff until the black nationalist groups dissipated. By the time the black nationalist groups were gone, the rights project had lost any momentum obtained by the legislation, as well a local political black bases that did not conform to their idea of good black citizenship.

Thus, the rights project's efforts to convince blacks that deracialized techniques of self did not equate to racial shame and black self-hate produced a style of political practice conducive to modern 'identity polities'. The idea behind identity politics was politically organizing around a shared ascribed status that served as a common point of oppression. As the woman's movement and queer movement of the late 1960s and early 1970s emerged onto the American civic scene, the political left was divided into fragmented political identity groups. Indeed, political coalitions between blacks and women, or blacks and gays, were harder to produce and maintain that coalitions between blacks and white labor groups. As the black nationalist groups drifted to the margins of the American political scene, primarily because they could not sustain their revolutionary programs, they left a practice of evaluating and interpreting black political

142 SCLC 1-3 "Rustin Letter to Herbert Kelsay of Free DC Committee" Dated 13 June 1966

300

candidates based on how they reflected black practices. The rights project attempt to weaken the boundaries produced by the good black/bad black binary without abandoning their normative symbolic citizenship claims left them with the residue of the practice of evaluating black political practice based on degrees of black authenticity. In part, the increased focus on economic equality and urban revitalization brought on by the 1965 Voting Rights Act would have forced the rights project to confront the good black/bad black distinction. However, the problem of evaluating and distinguishing black political practice, which differed from questioning blacks political allegiances and self-interest practices, was something introduced by the black nationalist project.

Despite the rise of identity politics, the competing ideas of mastering a deracialized technique of self versus mastering authentic black techniques of self continued to be important and effective on different political levels. At the national and global level, black politicians practiced the techniques of a deracialized self, to appear racially non-threatening, in order to draw from the widest political base. In contrast, black political leaders at the local level, especially in mayoral and congressional races, practiced the techniques of authentic black self to appeal to local black communities. Because neighborhood segregation and gerrymandering political districts already separated black political communities from white ones, black candidates appealed to all black audiences, and mastering techniques of the authentic black self was more important for caring for the all black community. CONCLUSION

301

This chapter outlined how the civil rights movement changed American political culture, represented by the Voting Rights Act, and how that new political culture led to the hardening of boundaries between the rights and black nationalist project, as well as to the decline of the civil rights movement. The new political culture was the development of a new way to approach racial differences in the public sphere. For the rights project, the idea of the good black citizen became associated with the need for voter rights legislation, and became the dominant normative representation of the black political agent. For the state, the voting rights act changed their legal and juridical practices of excluding racial minorities, redrawing exclusionary boundaries based on the idea of good citizenship. The rights project normative idea of the deracialized good black citizen, coupled with change in governing practices, produced new political relations that paradoxically downplayed blackness while at the same time making the management of the black self the central ethical practice for black political agents. That is, if blacks were to partake in a civically integrated public life, they would have to master the bodily and affective practices that represented them as good black citizens. The spread of the new south revitalization project's practice of using suburbanization, surveillance and decreasing rural political influence prepared the south to adapt to the new rules of the game. Although the black nationalist project was nurtured in northern urban environments, like Harlem and Chicago that already dealt with subtle forms of segregation, their experimentations with revolutionary practices in Atlanta never spread to the larger black population. The 'deracializing' of the public sphere served to further

302

marginalize the black nationalist normative idea of the authentic black citizen because set against the idea of the good black citizen, authentic blackness became an endorsement of black stereotypes, which isolated the local activists from whites and the other black groups.

Further complicating matters for the movement was the spread of the old south project on the state level despite setbacks and losing to the movement. We saw city municipalities draw from the idea of the new south to shield them from old south state policies, and create political autonomy from the old south project, yet, the old south project became the dominant regional and statewide position. In essence, southern whites could have their cake and eat it too. Wallace drew from the old south project to issue corporate subsidies with public funds to relocate northern business while southern urban areas reproduced the new south lived environment that corporate executives favored. The south produced as a set of governing practices that improved the lives of southern whites, and some southern blacks, without having to grant racial equality. Thus, the working relations between the old and new south project changed the south in ways it divided blacks and whites territorially, as well as how they used the post-Voting Rights Act political culture. By the end of the 1960s, the south was quickly becoming political and economic power center in American politics. Subsequently, the concentration of cultural influence, political and economic power to the southern cities reproduced the same patterns of urban segregation and subtle forms of racism that dominated northern areas. As long as the new

303

south did not engage good blacks with violence, they curtailed further protests for black equality.

Therefore, the post-Voting Rights political culture, which eliminated voting rights as a mobilizing issue, changed how the political projects approach racial equality. This chapter argued that the civil rights movements 'split' is better understood as the competing political projects differing strategies on how to politically organize blacks in the post-Voting Rights era. Using comparative methodology, I isolated four important differences in how each political projects symbolic citizenship claims organized black political practice to support this argument. First, the political projects differed in strategy of whether to pressure the nation or local government for continued reform. The rights projects' deracializing strategy attached the idea that good black citizens deserved fair and equable treatment that only the federal government could ensure. In contrast, the black nationalist project strategy of cleansing an all black political identity by organizing all black parties at the local level, attached the idea that real black citizens could govern and manage themselves, and did not need nor want the help of whites. The rights project view of the black vote as something blacks could use to integrate into the national polity because it transformed them into an asset, especially in the black belt and large urban cities. Rather than integrate into the national polity, the black nationalist project sought to form local all black political parties to gain control over black neighborhoods, win local city and state seats, and then negotiate and play politics with whites.

304

The second difference was how each political project organized movement programs and 'measured' black citizenship. The rights project used the voter registration exams as a recruiting tool to improve the qualitative level of black citizenship. Without this recruitment issue, the citizenship schools became a way to train black activists how to canvass for new voters without having to master personal and social ethical practices that represented good black citizens. Thus, the citizenship schools reverted to quantitatively measuring the number of black voters, and could no longer discipline black agents to be good black citizens. In contrast, the black nationalist project used tutoring and community center programs to measure black citizens based on the arbitrary ideal of authentic blackness. They emphasized black history, as well as domestic practices to enforce boundaries between black men and black women, but also to establish the sovereignty of black communities. With the right to vote secured, the black nationalist project decreased the importance of voting in favor of racially purifying the black community.

The third difference is how each political project approached civic ethical practices. The rights culture continued to use rhetorical practices of disassociating black stereotypes from black citizen, and held workshops on how to master the bodily postures and affective responses necessary to practice nonviolence and represent good black citizenship. However, the rights project sought to use the idea of good citizenship to produce and sustain political coalitions. Based on their larger strategy of pressuring the national government for reform, the rights project hoped to build a national 'left coalition', primarily of

305

labor and racial groups, to make the claim that they were good citizens who deserved minimal levels of social guarantees, as part of being a good American citizen. In contrast, the black nationalist project used figurative violence to intimidate whites into respecting existing black citizenship rights, and emphasized the importance of black leaders in the maintenance of all-black organizations and communities. Whereas the rights project saw black civic practice as part of a larger whole (or civil society), the black nationalist project defined black civic practice as a self-contained unit, used to produce black cultural and political sovereignty rather than racial and civic integration. Based on their local strategy, SNCC's black nationalist political cells emphasized black leaders mastering personal ethical practices that represented them as role models for other black political agents to draw from so they could govern black communities.

The post-Voting Rights Act political culture's final affect on the movement was how it structured the question of what to do next. Both political projects struggled for economic rights by fighting for, and against, urban revitalization. The rights project sought to make urban black poverty visible to the larger nation, especially whites, by having King move into the ghetto, organizing marches through white neighborhoods, and establishing a system reciprocal responsibility between black tenants and landlords that protected blacks from rental abuse as long as blacks mastered good tenant practices. They also struggled against urban revitalization, specifically white flight associated with suburbanization, by fighting for the rights of good black citizens (who could afford it) to move into

306

wealthier white neighborhoods. In contrast to the rights projects' concern with integrating wealthy white neighborhoods and sharing responsibility for white owned property, the Atlanta Project represented how the black nationalist project struggled for urban revitalization by focusing on the improvement and care of black neighborhoods. They pressured the city of Atlanta to enforce existing building codes, and targeted specific slumlords that had extraordinary amount of control over black neighborhoods. This differed from how the Chicago Movement targeted the abstract system of economic inequality, and sought cooperation between tenants and landlords. The two projects also differed in how they used similar civic practices. Whereas the rights project use of rent strikes led to negotiations, the Atlanta Projects use of rent strikes led to the formation of tent cities. For the rights project, rent strikes was a way to establish blacks desire to integrate only into a just society, where the black nationalist project used rent strikes to represent black desire for cultural and political independence from whites.

This chapter also allows us to rethink the relationship between ideas (or political ideology) and social movements. Based on my conceptual framework, I proposed we understand the political project separately from the social movement. My use of concept "political project" referred to the normative ideas, discourses, practices, and forms of knowledge produced by historically embedded political ideas of how political life should be, and how it should operate. In contrast, I defined "social movements" as a collection of heterogeneous political agents temporarily bounded together by the political

307

projects normative ideas, especially citizenship. By separating the two concepts, we can understand first, why the movement declined, and second, the legacy of each political project's normative ideas of black citizenship. The black nationalist project declined because of the idea of authentic blackness became the dominant form of political legitimation among supporters, which produced black infighting and limited forms of political strategy that could not navigate blacks in the changing political culture. In contrast, the rights project declined because they lacked a local based to compliment their national strategy, their inability to resolve the tension between their normative claims good black/bad black citizenship, and their failure to adapt and expand their civic practices in the changing political culture. In part, the rights project were the victims of their own success. Although the rights project was and remained the dominant position in the civil rights movement, their idea of good black citizenship excluded too many blacks historically confined to margins because rural poverty and white domination. Although the movement declined, the political projects left a legacy for subsequent generations of black political agents. Contemporary representations of black citizenship reflect the rights project deracialized good black citizen and support of universal good citizenship. On the one hand, good black citizens have been celebrated by larger civic culture as blacks who deserve rights, good housing, good jobs - that the system works for those who can master a set of ethical practices representing good citizenship. On the other hand, bad black citizens are anchored to margins and made invisible by a culture

308

that legitimates their hardships and destitute situations as evidence of blacks choosing an authentic black culture rather than a good Americans one.

EPILOGUE: WHERE WE WENT: SYMBOLIC CITIZENSHIP CLAIMS AND THE LEGACY OF THE COMPETING BLACK POLITICAL PROJECTS

"The good and just society is neither the thesis of capitalism nor the antithesis of Communism, but a socially conscious democracy which reconciles the truths of individualism and collectivism."

- Martin Luther King, 1968

The above quote from King represented how the post-war American left

sought out "new' leftist practices that did not perpetuate the capitalist versus

communist debate that undermined much of Cold War American political

discourse. The rights project, which sought an idealized American civic order

based on citizens mastering a set of ethical practices, sought to critique

democratic societies and democratic practices without rejecting democratic

ideals. The civil rights movement drew from ideals of good American citizenship

to produce a new black political agent that reflected the idealized good American

citizen. By using a set of rhetorical and bodily ethical practices, the movement

disassociated the idea of citizenship from race, and in turn influenced the state in

1965 to pass major legislation, the Voting Rights Act and the Immigration Act,

that downplayed racial ascriptions in favor of standards that assessed the

individual's qualities and character over their racial and ethnic status. This

dissertation has argued that the Voting Rights Act passed only because the idea

of the good black citizen was the dominate representation attached to that act. It

also argued that the rights project idea of good black citizenship excluded blacks

who did not or could not conform to this idealized image. It was the point in

which the boundary lines were drawn that allowed the black nationalist project to

310

gain influence, as they rejected the rights projects deracializing strategy in favor of producing an authentic black revolutionary political agent.

For black America, some unintended consequences accompanied The Voting Rights Act, which shaped American politics for 40 years. In his 1968 book, Where Do We Go from Here, King noted that the year after Selma "the white backlash had become an emotional electoral issue in California, Maryland and elsewhere. In several Southern states men long regarded as political clowns had become governors or only narrowly missed election their magic achieved with a witches' brew of bigotry, prejudice, half-truths and whole lies" (King 1968: 2). In 1967, Ronald Reagan was among the many political clowns to become governor. In 1980, he declared his presidential campaign in Philadelphia, Mississippi, where three civil rights activists were murdered, with a nod to "states rights", and in 1983 declared the Voting Rights Act was an insult to the south. Although the Voting Rights Act made democratic citizenship more fair, its legacy included a unifying point for bad whites and their practice of old south patronage and racism to ascend to the national level. Despite the rhetoric of states rights, religious values and anti-intellectual discourses, the defection of southern whites from the Democratic to the Republican Party centered on the Republican objection to racial integration, the 1964 Civil Rights and 1965 Voting Rights Act.

Throughout this dissertation, I have attempted to shed light on the importance of how the civil rights movement drew from various political projects, and how they used discourses to organize the pedagogical practice of their various programs. I also attempted to show the history of how and why they

311

constructed these programs in relation to the sociological importance of ethics, the body, good citizenship, and racial authenticity. The rights project used discourse of good citizenship to produce a deracialized good black citizen that reflected universal claims of good citizenship. The deracializing strategy made it possible to question and delegitimate associations of race, and specifically whiteness, with good citizenship. The rights project produced good black citizens by situating their pedagogical techniques in discourses of good black citizenship to shape bodily postures and teach affective self-management to shape bodily representations of good black citizenship. Although the citizenship schools, role-playing, community centers and grassroots leadership training attempted to teach lessons on voter canvassing, how to pass literacy tests, how to navigate unfamiliar black communities and healthy dietary practices, they instructed a set of ethical practices embedded in the practical lessons. Although the black nationalist project used competing discourses of black authenticity to construct black political agents capable of governing autonomous black communities, they also instructed ethical practices of how to preserver the natural black body and use affective response to intimidate and ward off whites. These ethical practices set the limits within a political context of how one should act, via rhetoric and practice, which limits/defines/stabilizes the unitary good black political agent. Therefore, ethics ties together, through discourse, emotions and cognition through the body, by emphasizing the historical situatedness of the social movement and political agent.

312

We have to understand this struggle between the rights project and the black nationalist project as competing leftist political projects struggling to represent the black political left. They both rejected the Uncle Tom political representation individual blacks benefiting from the continued exploitation of the black community. The Uncle Tom did not always appear in a suit and tie, telling the black community to be patient. In Birmingham, Bull Connor's main source within the black community was a downtown pimp and drug dealer. Robert Williams noted that the Uncle Tom appeared rolling through town in a Cadillac handing out money to blacks to stay uninvolved and remain subservient to local whites (Williams [1962] 1968). Civil rights groups drew from competing political projects to construct normative ideas of good black citizens and authentic black citizens to replace the existing representations of the Uncle Tom and docile, apolitical black. The key was not converting Uncle Toms, although the movement as a whole did pressure them into supporting the black struggle, but targeting the apolitical black population and bringing them into the civic sphere.

Concerning civil rights historiography, I have contributed to the importance of the movement programs, the transformation of SNCC into a black nationalist group, and post-Voting right SNCC practice. As mentioned in chapters one and three, civil rights movement scholars have glossed over the movement programs in favor of research questions pertaining to the formal organization of each group. Drawing from insights in cultural sociology, I have shown that the various movement programs were vital for the civil rights movement, as whole, success. As the movements' programs waned after the 1965 Voting Rights Act, so the

313

movement. Secondly, I have shown the importance of how SNCC used discourses of black authenticity to re-organize their grassroots project. By distinguishing SNCC's grassroots project from SCLC's rights project, I argued that SNCC's attempts to organize inter-racially, based on shared local geopolitical culture, provided the foundation for SNCC activists to use discourses of black authenticity to re-organize local black populations around normative ideas of the racially pure black political agent without the pressures of national and universal citizenship. This explains a key aspect missing in social movement theories that cannot be explain by structural shifts, race-class intersection, or organizational models: that SNCC's transformation into a black nationalist group was made in relation to spatial organizing practices and role of discourse. Finally, in contrast to SNCC scholars which saw the lack of instrumental gains as equating to a general failure of and rapid disintegration of the Atlanta Project, I have shown that they did indeed organize a black nationalist challenge to the city of Atlanta, and impacted black urban culture. Although the Atlanta Project did not win any rights, they did change how urban blacks perceived slumlords, disparities in incarceration, and their relations with the national rights project.

Just as the legacy of the Voting Rights Act continued many years after its passage, the competing political projects remain influential long after the decline of the civil rights movement. The rights and black nationalist projects have continue to shape contemporary representations of black citizenship. At the time of writing this dissertation in 2007, we see influential black figures, such as Bill Cosby, draw from the rights project's idea of mastering personal ethical

314

practices, especially manners of speech and dress, as the basis for civic integration and the reasons why black urban youth cannot succeed scholastically and economically. The PBS program, Tavis Smiley Show, debated the merits and legacy of Clarence Thomas's memoir, My Grandfather's Son. Thomas represents the black political agent both the rights and black nationalist project sought to avoid: the Uncle Tom who personally gained at the expense of other blacks, as indicated by Thomas's rejection of continuing to base school affirmative action and funding by race. During the program, Cornell West questioned why the media used Al Sharpton, who reflects many of the bad black stereotypes in rhetoric, ethical practices (mannerisms) and bodily postures (style of dress) rather than black intellectuals who opposed Thomas on ideological and juridical terms, noting that Sharpton represented just "one particular moment of Black people expressing their critique."

The question that dominates discussion of the black nationalist project is its legacy. What happened to it? Where did it go? The short answer, albeit the insufficient and wrong answer, was that the black nationalist project declined in relation to increased state and FBI surveillance, and the urban based black nationalist groups, like Oakland's Black Panthers, Chicago's Blackstone Rangers, or Philadelphia's famed Black Mafia, which used their organizational structure to enter the drug trade in the 1970s and 80s. Although specific black nationalist groups have come and gone, we see the legacy of the black nationalist project in cultural genres, such as academic circles and hip hop culture. Black intellectuals, such as Michael Eric Dyson and bell hooks, continue

315

to question and warn of the dangers of championing the implicit idea of good black citizenship the marker for racial equality, in light of high number of black school dropouts, divorce and incarceration rates, as well as pressuring the state to enforce existing citizenship rights. Although they black academics have sought to cleanse black nationalist of its sexist and homophobic practices, they have maintained the approach that society is ordered first on racial lines, and that black equality must be sought by solving internal 'differences' so that blacks may proceed as a group. In contrast to academic genres, blacks on the left and right have vilified hip hop cultures for exhibiting and championing many of the black stereotypes they fought against. A sub genre of hip hop artists have drawn from the black nationalist project to produce racially conscious lyrics that represent the plight of urban blacks. However, hip hop culture's inability to distance themselves from the hyper-sexualized and violent subject matter has associated the hip hop groups, from 1980s hip hop pioneers Public Enemy to contemporary groups like Dead Prez, with the more orthodox black nationalism of the 1960s. Thus, rather than a single black nationalist project, we generally see two forms of black nationalism based in different genres and social positioning of the actors. However, it should be noted that black nationalism in general remains firmly anchored at the political margins, providing the minority voice and challenge to the rights project influence over national black political matters.

Based on my theoretical approach that draws from approaches in cultural sociology that emphasizes the role of culture and power, and then applies them

316

to issues not readily addressed in the cultural genre, future research in social movements and political sociology should consider the following four ideas: 1. The importance of citizenship, specifically ideas of good citizenship, in relation to how political groups and social movements organize their strategies and produce normative ideals of political agents. Understandings of citizenship can vary. Social movements and political groups operating on the national scale, within the dominant public sphere, will most likely draw from and challenge universal claims of good citizenship. In contrast, social movements and political groups on the margins will most likely draw from multicultural, or even multinational, claims of citizenship, where by citizenship is perceived to be the property of groups. This has implications, especially on the margins, with our understanding of why groups organize and proceed as "groups" or "individuals" as they either challenge or attempt to enact civil reform. The extent that democracy can function or that civil society remains vibrant and stable will depend on how groups begin to transfer their self attachments from ascribed groups to a national civic identification with minimal exclusionary criteria. Future research should consider not only how we can reduce exclusionary criteria, but also question the very basis the idea of a single representation of good citizenship that influences how we govern ourselves. The development of cosmopolitan cultures in lieu of new forms of globalization may depend on the relation/tension between civic and group identification.

317

2. How social movements and political groups create the representations of the populations they claim only to represent. Social movements produce normative ideas as they make claims for civil inclusion or revolution. Social movement practices are not neutral bearers or transmitters of meaning143. I have used the concept of "symbolic citizenship" to refer to how groups create the normative ideas of good citizenship in relation to the dominant civic culture idealized citizen. I showed how the civil rights movement did not frame themselves as good democratic citizens or good Christians. Rather, groups, like SCLC, drew from the rights project to produced deracialized techniques of self that represented blacks as idealized citizens in relation to their constructs of bad white citizenship. Therefore, subsequent social movement research should follow the cultural turn in social movement theory, reject frame analysis, and consider how movement produce new identities, form of practices, and normative ideas of political agents, and how this varies between contrasting, and sometimes overlapping, political projects.

3. The distinction between political projects and social movements. I distinguished the social movement as the manifestation of the historically situated political projects. Social movements draw from ideas, discourses and narratives that organize political projects. This is important for subsequent research in political sociology and social movements because is allows us to analyze how 1) all actors in civil society, including advocacy groups and lobbyists, and draw from historically embedded projects and

Also see Steinberg 1998 on how the framing perspective is a based on a referential use of language

318

use specific discourses to make claims for rights, reform and civic inclusion. Although research notes the distinction of social movements and voluntary associations from advocacy groups, distinguishing the type of political project, and how the various groups use it, allows for a more nuance understandings of their points of difference and convergence. 2) It broadens our understanding of the cultural basis for state practices. Although the state and civil society are autonomous spheres, reciprocity exists between them. Social actors draw from various political projects to gain control over the state based on normative ideals of the 'good life' and the 'good community. In turn, these projects influence administrative and governing practices. Further research in political sociology and the governmentality genres would benefit by indicating the importance of normative political cultures in organizing state practices rather than immediate threats or political outcomes. It will help explain why states' employ seeming irrational and unproductive state practices as symbolic gestures designed to establish a single normative political order on populations. 4. The importance of the body and ethical practice in social movement research. My point in bringing in the body to the study of social movements and political sociology is to emphasize the historical situatedness of the political agent, in order to understand how social movements draw from political projects to produce normative ideas of political agents by training activists how to master bodily postures and

319

affective responses. I use ethics to refer to how political groups set limits within a political context of how one should act, via rhetoric and practice, which limits/defines/stabilizes a unitary political agent. Therefore, ethics ties together, through discourse, emotions and cognition through the body. It provides the link from how social movements use a political projects normative ideal to how they shape representations onto the populations they 'represent'. Subsequent research on social change and social movements that seeks to understand what changed and how it was changed would benefit by incorporating an approach that looks at the implicit normative ethical practices contained in movement pedagogy, narratives, and discourses, and how these ethical practices become part of a social movement's strategy.

Thus, how social movements continue to make symbolic citizenship claims to secured rights and favorable legislation should become part of our understanding, and conceptual frameworks for studying, how groups fight inequality. While not all movements are able to induce state response, they will contribute to the arbitrary idea of what counts as idealized citizenship. Despite the loss of state sovereignty and the dissolution of national borders/boundaries, how social movements, ethno-religious and racial groups discipline and shape ethical practices to represent citizenship and in-group ideals will continue to important as they challenge what counts as membership and political inclusion. We should also be aware of the dangers in making such symbolic citizenship

320

claims. The normative claims split movements into two or more factions, and ultimately attach one set of ethical practices to the dominant representation of the group, while delegitimatizing and anchoring its opposite to the political margins. Drawing from the lessons and warnings that Deleuze and Guartti taught us in Anti-Oedipus, perhaps future social movement will develop bodily postures and affective practices to teach us how to master our desires for power, without subscribing to the need to purify ourselves racially, sexually, or class-wise, in order to organize a new set of leftist civic ethical practice.
